ABW.description: Born from Dutch colonial history, this 'stuffed cheese' masterpiece transforms a hollowed-out Edam rind into a savory casserole. It was originally created by slaves who filled discarded cheese shells with table scraps, evolving into Aruba's national pride.
steps: Slice the top off the Edam cheese and hollow it out, leaving a thick shell. Save the scooped cheese.
Sauté onion, pepper, and tomato. Add shredded chicken, raisins, olives, capers, and some of the scooped cheese.
Simmer until thick. Remove from heat and stir in beaten eggs (binder).
Stuff the cheese shell with the mixture. Place the cheese 'lid' back on.
Bake in a greased dish at 350°F (180°C) for 30-40 mins until the cheese shell melts slightly and browns.

drink.description: Aruba’s signature party cocktail—tall, fruity, and usually finished with a splash of grenadine.
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice.
Add vodka, rum, banana liqueur, orange juice, and pineapple juice; stir.
Slowly pour grenadine down the side for a sunset effect.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool before using.
Warm pomegranate juice and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (avoid a hard boil).
Cool; stir in orange blossom water if using.
Bottle; add vodka if using for shelf-life.
Refrigerate and use within 3–4 weeks (longer if vodka added).

AFG.description: Afghanistan's national dish, a spectacular rice pilaf with lamb, sweet carrots, and raisins.
ingredients: 2 lbs Lamb leg or shoulder (large chunks)
steps: Fry onions in oil until golden. Add lamb and fry until brown.
Add water, salt, and spices. Simmer until lamb is tender (approx 1 hour). Remove lamb, save broth.
In a separate pan, sauté julienned carrots and raisins with a little sugar until glossy. Set aside.
Boil the soaked rice in salted water until 70% cooked. Drain.
In a large heavy pot, layer the rice, cooked lamb, carrots, and raisins.
Pour the reserved lamb broth and caramelized sugar over the rice.
Cover tightly with a cloth and lid. Steam (Dum) on very low heat for 20-30 minutes.
Mix gently before serving to distribute the ingredients.

drink.description: A common Afghan-style green tea, often served plain or lightly sweetened.
steps: Bring water just to a simmer (not a full boil).
Steep green tea 2–3 minutes.
Strain and sweeten if desired.
Mix spices thoroughly.
Store airtight up to 2–3 months.

AGO.description: Angola’s iconic chicken stew built around red palm oil, tomatoes, and okra; traditionally served with funge (cassava or corn porridge).
steps: Season the chicken with salt, pepper, and lime juice. Rest 15 minutes.
Heat vegetable oil in a heavy pot. Brown chicken in batches, 3–4 minutes per side. Remove to a plate.
In the same pot, sauté onion until soft, 6–8 minutes. Add garlic and ginger; cook 1 minute.
Stir in tomatoes and tomato paste. Cook until the paste darkens and the tomatoes begin to break down, 5–7 minutes.
Return chicken to the pot. Add stock, bay leaf, paprika, and (if using) chile. Cover and simmer gently until chicken is tender, 35–45 minutes.
Stir in palm oil and okra. Simmer uncovered 10–15 minutes until okra is tender and the sauce is glossy. Taste and adjust salt.
Serve hot, traditionally with funge or plain rice.

drink.description: An Angolan refreshment made from pineapple peels, lightly fermented for a bright, tangy-sweet drink.
ingredients: Peels and core from 1 ripe pineapple (well washed)
1/2 cup packed brown sugar (or to taste)
steps: Put pineapple peels/core, ginger, and (if using) cinnamon and cloves in a pot with the water. Bring to a boil, then simmer 10 minutes.
Turn off heat, cover, and steep 30 minutes. Strain into a clean jar or pitcher.
Stir in brown sugar and a pinch of salt while warm so it dissolves. Cool to room temperature.
Cover loosely and let sit at room temperature 12–24 hours until lightly tangy (time varies with temperature).
Refrigerate and serve over ice.

ALA.description: A custard-like oven pancake made from semolina or rice porridge, flavored with cardamom and served with stewed prunes.
steps: Mix porridge, eggs, sugar, milk, and cardamom.
Pour into buttered dish.
Bake at 400°F for 30-40 mins.
Serve with prunes and cream.

drink.description: Coffee is a common everyday drink in Åland, reflecting Nordic habits.
steps: Brew as filter/drip coffee; serve.

ALB.description: A beloved Albanian classic where tender lamb is baked in a souffle-like yogurt and egg sauce.
ingredients: 2 lbs Lamb shoulder, cut into chunks
steps: Season lamb with salt and pepper. Bake in a deep dish with butter and a little water at 350°F (180°C) for 45 mins.
Add the raw rice to the lamb pan and bake for another 10 minutes.
Meanwhile, make the roux: melt remaining butter, whisk in flour until golden.
Remove roux from heat. Whisk in yogurt, beaten eggs, garlic, and seasoning until smooth.
Pour the yogurt mixture over the lamb and rice.
Bake for another 30-40 minutes until the top is golden and puffed like a quiche.

drink.description: A chilled Albanian yogurt drink—salty, lightly tangy, and whisked until foamy. Commonly served with grilled meats and summer meals.
ingredients: 1 cup plain whole-milk yogurt (240 g / ~8.5 oz)
Optional: 2 tbsp sparkling water (30 ml) for extra lift
steps: Whisk the yogurt in a pitcher until completely smooth.
Add salt and whisk again.
Slowly whisk in the cold water (and sparkling water if using) until thin and frothy.
Taste and adjust salt. Chill 15–30 minutes.
Serve cold in small glasses.

AND.description: The national dish of the Pyrenees. A hearty two-course meal: first a rich broth with pasta shells, then the meats and veggies served solid. It is the taste of high-altitude comfort.
steps: Boil the bones, chicken, and chickpeas in water for 1 hour.
Mix ground pork with garlic, parsley, and egg to form a large oval meatball (La Pilota). Dust in flour.
Add the Pilota, sausages, and vegetables to the pot. Simmer another hour.
Strain the broth into a separate pot. Cook the Galets pasta in this broth.
Serve the soup with pasta first. Then serve the platter of meats and vegetables.

drink.dish: Ratafia de Nous Verdes (Ratassia / Green Walnut Liqueur)
drink.description: A traditional Pyrenean/Catalan-style walnut ratafia enjoyed in Andorra—green walnuts macerated in spirit with warm spices, then sweetened and aged.
steps: Put quartered green walnuts, orange peel, cinnamon, and cloves in a large glass jar.
Pour in the spirit, seal, and store in a cool dark place for 4–6 weeks, shaking the jar every few days.
Strain through a fine sieve, then through coffee filters until clear.
Make syrup: heat water and sugar just until dissolved; cool completely.
Combine the walnut infusion with syrup to taste (start with 1 1/2 cups syrup; adjust).
Bottle and rest at least 2 weeks (better after 1–2 months). Serve lightly chilled.

ARE.description: A Gulf staple especially during Ramadan and Eid: wheat and meat simmered for hours until silky, then finished with ghee and warm spices. The texture is somewhere between porridge and risotto—comfort food with ceremony.
ingredients: 1 1/2 cups (300 g) whole wheat berries or cracked harees wheat, rinsed
2 1/2 lb (1.1 kg) bone-in chicken pieces (or 2 lb / 900 g lamb shoulder chunks)
8 cups (1.9 L) water, plus more as needed
2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
1/2 tsp ground cinnamon, plus more for serving
1/2 tsp ground cardamom (or 6 cardamom pods, lightly crushed)
4 tbsp (55 g) ghee or unsalted butter, melted
steps: Soak the wheat in plenty of water for 4 hours (or overnight). Drain.
In a large heavy pot, combine chicken, onion, water, and salt. Bring to a boil, skim foam, then simmer 30–45 minutes (until chicken is very tender).
Remove chicken to a tray. When cool enough to handle, discard skin and bones and shred the meat. Strain the broth back into the pot.
Add soaked wheat to the broth. Simmer gently, partially covered, 2–3 hours, stirring often and adding water if it gets too thick, until the wheat breaks down.
Stir in shredded meat, cinnamon, and cardamom. Cook 15–20 minutes more, beating the mixture with a sturdy spoon (or use an immersion blender briefly) until smooth and porridge-like.
Serve hot with a generous drizzle of ghee, a dusting of cinnamon, and almonds if using.

drink.description: Light, aromatic coffee brewed with cardamom and saffron—served in small cups with dates across the UAE and the Gulf as a sign of hospitality.
ingredients: 2 tbsp (10–12 g) very lightly roasted coffee, ground (or a light Arabica grind)
1 tbsp (6 g) ground cardamom (or 10 pods, crushed)
steps: Bring the water to a gentle boil in a small pot.
Stir in the coffee. Reduce heat and simmer 8–10 minutes (do not hard-boil).
Add cardamom, saffron (and cloves if using). Simmer 3–5 minutes.
Remove from heat and let grounds settle 2 minutes. Strain into a serving pot.
Stir in rose water if using. Serve in small cups, unsweetened, with dates on the side.

ARG.description: More than a barbecue, Asado is a sacred Argentine ritual of fire and meat. Gauchos (cowboys) perfected this technique of slow-cooking beef over wood embers on the pampas, celebrating the pure, unadulterated flavor of world-class beef.
ingredients: 4 lbs Beef Short Ribs (Tira de Asado)
Chimichurri: Parsley, Garlic, Oregano, Red Pepper, Vinegar, Oil
steps: Build a fire using hardwood. Let it burn down until you have a bed of consistent, glowing coals.
Clean the grill grate. Spread coals under the grate (medium-low heat).
Salt the meat generously with coarse salt. Do not add other spices.
Place ribs bone-side down. Cook slowly for 1.5 to 2 hours. Do not flip constantly.
Add sausages (chorizo) halfway through.
Flip beef when the top feels warm and bone side is crispy.
Serve with fresh Chimichurri sauce and crusty bread.

drink.description: Yerba mate is a cornerstone of Argentine daily life, shared socially from a gourd with a metal straw (bombilla).
steps: Fill gourd about 2/3 with yerba.
Tilt to create a slope; insert bombilla into the empty side.
Add a small amount of cool water to moisten.
Add hot (not boiling) water and sip; refill repeatedly.

ingredients: 2 tbsp dried oregano (or 1/4 cup fresh, chopped)
1/2 tsp red pepper flakes (or to taste)
steps: Mix parsley, garlic, oregano, and chili flakes in a bowl.
Stir in vinegar, then olive oil; season with salt and pepper.
Rest 20–30 minutes before serving (better after a few hours). Refrigerate up to 3–4 days.

ARM.description: The national soul of Armenia. A velvety, slow-cooked porridge of korkot (dried wheat berries) and chicken (or lamb) that is stirred for hours until the meat dissolves into the grain.
steps: Soak wheat berries overnight.
Boil chicken and wheat in broth. Skim foam.
Simmer for 4-5 hours without stirring until chicken falls off bone.
Remove bones. Beat mixture vigorously for 30 mins until elastic and smooth.
Serve with melted butter and paprika.

drink.description: Armenia is well known for brandy traditions.
steps: Serve neat at room temperature; sip slowly.

ingredients: 6 dried red chilies (or 2 tbsp chili flakes; adjust heat)
steps: If using whole dried chilies, cover with hot water 20 minutes; drain.
Blend chilies with garlic, spices, lemon juice, salt, and olive oil into a thick paste.
Refrigerate up to 2 weeks (cover surface with a thin layer of oil).

ATG.description: A hearty duo rooted in African heritage. Fungee (cornmeal and okra) provides the canvas for Pepperpot, a rich, dark stew that historically simmered for days on colonial plantations, preserving meats without refrigeration using cassareep and spices.
ingredients: Tomato paste, Garlic, Thyme, Scotch Bonnet pepper
steps: Pepperpot: Boil salted meat until tender. Add vegetables and spices. Simmer until everything is soft and stew-like.
Fungee: Boil okra in salted water. Remove okra, keep water.
Whisk cornmeal into the boiling okra water. Stir vigorously with a wooden spoon (turn stick) to remove lumps.
Fold cooked okra back in. Cook until stiff and smooth.
Serve the fungee balls with the pepperpot stew.

drink.description: A classic island-style rum punch built around local rum, citrus, and warm spice—often served at gatherings.
ingredients: 1 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz / 15 ml simple syrup)
steps: Shake rum, lime juice, sugar, and pineapple juice with ice until cold.
Strain over fresh ice in a rocks glass.
Add bitters and nutmeg if using.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: Store-bought cassareep (recommended for safety and authenticity)
steps: Cassareep is traditionally made by extracting cassava juice, fermenting/settling, and boiling it down for a long time with spices.
Because raw cassava juice can contain cyanogenic compounds, the safest approach is to use reputable store-bought cassareep.
If you are set on making it from scratch, follow a trusted Guyanese/Caribbean method and boil the liquid thoroughly for an extended time; do not use any ‘quick’ method.

AUS.description: An Australian icon. Flaky pastry filled with a rich, thick minced beef gravy.
steps: Brown onion and beef in a pan. Break up lumps.
Add stock, sauces, vegemite, and pepper. Bring to boil.
Mix cornstarch with a little water to make a slurry. Stir into beef. Simmer until thick and glossy. Let cool completely.
Line pie tins with shortcrust pastry. Blind bake for 10 mins.
Fill cases with cooled meat mixture.
Top with puff pastry. Press edges to seal. Brush with egg wash.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 20-25 minutes until golden brown.

drink.description: A classic Australian/New Zealand mixed drink: bright citrus with a few dashes of aromatic bitters.
ingredients: 1 tbsp lime cordial (or 1/2 oz fresh lime juice + 1 tsp simple syrup)
steps: Fill a glass with ice.
Add lime cordial (or lime juice + simple syrup).
Top with lemonade and add bitters.
Stir gently and garnish with lime if desired.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: Zest of 4 limes (use a microplane; avoid bitter white pith)
steps: Rub lime zest into sugar with your fingers until fragrant (this pulls out citrus oils).
Add lime juice and stir until sugar dissolves (or warm gently to dissolve faster, then cool).
Bottle and refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

AUT.description: The golden icon of Vienna. By law, a true Wiener Schnitzel must be veal. The secret lies in the 'soufflé' effect—frying it swimming in fat so the breading separates from the meat, creating a rippled, crispy crust.
ingredients: 1 cup Clarified Butter (Schmalz) or high-heat oil
steps: Place veal between plastic wrap and pound gently until very thin (approx 4mm). Season with salt.
Set up 3 shallow bowls: Flour, Beaten Eggs, Breadcrumbs.
Dredge veal in flour (shake off excess), dip in egg, then coat gently in breadcrumbs. Do not press the crumbs into the meat.
Heat butter in a pan (meat must float). Temp should be approx 170°C.
Fry schnitzel, shaking the pan constantly to swirl oil over the top. This creates the rippled crust.
Flip once. Fry until golden brown (approx 3 mins total). Drain and serve immediately.

drink.description: A classic Viennese aperitif: crisp white wine lengthened with soda water—simple, cold, and refreshing.
ingredients: 5 oz dry white wine (Grüner Veltliner recommended) (150 ml)
steps: Chill a wine glass or highball.
Fill with ice.
Pour in the wine, then top with soda water.
Stir once gently.
Add lemon if you like; serve immediately.

AZE.description: The 'King of Pilafs'. Saffron-infused rice and tender meat encased in a crispy, golden lavash crust (Gazmaq).
steps: Parboil rice. Sauté meat and fruits.
Line a pot with buttered lavash sheets.
Layer rice and meat mixture inside. Add saffron butter.
Fold lavash over top.
Bake at 350°F for 1 hour until crisp.

drink.description: Black tea served strong, often with sweets or jam.
steps: Steep tea 3–5 minutes.
Serve with jam or sugar to taste.

Andaman and Nicobar Islands.description: A reflection of the island's tropical abundance. Fresh fish is marinated in turmeric and chili, then simmered in a light, tangy gravy made with coconut milk and local spices.
ingredients: 1 lb King Fish or White Snapper
steps: Marinate fish with turmeric and salt. Lightly fry.
Sauté mustard seeds, curry leaves, and onions.
Add tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add coconut milk and simmer.
Add fish and cook gently for 5-7 minutes.

drink.description: Island refreshment: cold coconut water straight from a young coconut.
ingredients: 1 young coconut (or 8–12 oz / 240–355 ml coconut water)
steps: Chill well.
Serve straight (over ice if desired).

BDI.description: A Burundian staple of slow-simmered beans with aromatics; commonly served with plantains, rice, or cassava.
ingredients: 1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Combine beans and water in a pot. Bring to a boil, then simmer partially covered until beans are tender, 1 1/2–2 hours (add water as needed).
In a separate pan, heat oil and sauté onion until soft, 5–7 minutes. Add garlic; cook 30 seconds. Add tomatoes and cook until jammy, 6–8 minutes.
Stir the tomato mixture into the beans. Season with salt, pepper, and cumin (if using). Simmer 15 minutes to meld flavors.
If using peanut butter, whisk it with a ladle of hot bean broth, then stir back into the pot. Simmer 5 minutes.
Serve hot with plantains, rice, or cassava.

drink.description: A traditional Great Lakes banana beer: ripe bananas mashed, strained, and fermented with sorghum flour.
ingredients: 6 very ripe bananas (the riper, the better)
1/2 cup sorghum flour (lightly toasted in a dry pan)
1/4 tsp active dry yeast (optional, for reliability)
steps: Peel bananas into a large bowl and mash thoroughly into a smooth pulp.
Add warm water and mix well. Strain through a fine sieve or cheesecloth into a clean fermentation jar.
Stir in toasted sorghum flour and a pinch of salt. Add yeast (if using).
Cover loosely and ferment at room temperature 12–24 hours until lightly effervescent and aromatic.
Strain again if desired, chill, and serve cold.
Toast sorghum flour in a dry skillet over medium heat, stirring constantly, until lightly nutty and fragrant, 3–5 minutes.
Cool completely before adding to the drink.

BEL.description: A national obsession pairing the bounty of the North Sea with the world's best fries. The mussels are steamed simply in white wine and aromatics, while the potatoes are fried twice in beef tallow for that signature Belgian crunch.
ingredients: 4 lbs Fresh Mussels, cleaned and bearded
Beef tallow or Oil for frying
steps: Fries: Cut potatoes into batons. Soak in water. Dry. Fry at 280°F (140°C) for 5 mins (do not brown). Cool. Fry again at 375°F (180°C) until crisp.
Mussels: In a large pot, sauté shallots and celery in butter until soft.
Crank heat to high. Add mussels and white wine.
Cover immediately. Shake the pot occasionally. Cook for 3-4 minutes until shells open.
Discard any unopened mussels. Toss with chopped parsley.
Serve the pot of mussels alongside the crisp fries and mayonnaise.

drink.description: A traditional Belgian style: lambic gently sweetened (historically with brown sugar or syrup). Lightly tart, lightly sweet—meant for easy drinking.
ingredients: 12 oz lambic (or gueuze) beer, well-chilled (355 ml)
1–2 tsp dark brown sugar or Belgian candi syrup, to taste
steps: Add sugar (or syrup) to a chilled glass.
Pour in the lambic and stir gently just to dissolve.
Taste and adjust sweetness.
Garnish with a lemon slice if desired and serve immediately.

BEN.description: A Beninese tomato- and palm-oil–tinted cornmeal paste, often served with fried fish, chicken, or a spicy sauce.
ingredients: 1 cup tomato purée (or crushed tomatoes blended smooth)
1/4 cup red palm oil (or vegetable oil)
4 cups hot water or warm vegetable/chicken stock
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Heat palm oil in a heavy saucepan over medium heat. Add onion and cook until translucent, 5–7 minutes. Add garlic and cook 30 seconds.
Stir in tomato paste and cook 1–2 minutes. Add tomato purée, salt, pepper, bay leaf (if using), and cayenne (if using). Simmer 5 minutes.
Pour in the hot water/stock, bring to a steady simmer, and taste for seasoning.
Whisk in the cornmeal in a slow stream to avoid lumps. Switch to a sturdy spoon and stir continuously until very thick, 5–8 minutes.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and cook 10 minutes, stirring and scraping the bottom every couple of minutes.
Shape into mounds with a wet spoon or serve family-style. Traditionally served hot with a protein and sauce.

drink.description: A Benin-inspired cocktail built on sodabi arrangé (infused sodabi), brightened with lime, mint, and cucumber.
steps: In a shaker, muddle cucumber and mint gently.
Add sodabi, lime juice, and simple syrup. Fill with ice and shake hard for 10–12 seconds.
Double strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.
Top with soda water and give a gentle stir. Garnish with mint and a cucumber slice.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan. Heat just until the sugar dissolves (no need to boil hard).
Cool completely and refrigerate in a clean jar up to 2 weeks.

BFA.description: A West African “fat rice” dish popular in Burkina Faso—tomato rice cooked with meat and vegetables until richly seasoned.
ingredients: 1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
2 cups green beans or cabbage, chopped
steps: Heat oil in a heavy pot. Brown the chicken/beef on all sides. Remove to a plate.
Sauté onion until soft, 5–7 minutes. Add garlic and cook 30 seconds.
Stir in tomato paste and cook 1 minute. Add crushed tomatoes, thyme, bay leaf, salt, pepper, and (if using) chile. Simmer 5 minutes.
Return meat to the pot and add stock. Bring to a simmer and cook 15 minutes.
Stir in rice and vegetables. Cover and cook on low until the rice is tender and liquid absorbed, 18–25 minutes (time depends on rice).
Rest 10 minutes off heat, then fluff and serve.

drink.description: A Burkinabè ginger drink often made with tamarind and a touch of millet for body; served cold.
ingredients: 1/2 cup tamarind pulp (or 3 tbsp tamarind concentrate)
3-inch piece fresh ginger, peeled and grated
steps: In a bowl, soak tamarind pulp in 3 cups warm water for 15 minutes, then mash and strain to extract the tart liquid. (Skip if using concentrate.)
In a pot, bring the remaining 5 cups water to a boil with the grated ginger. Simmer 5 minutes, then turn off heat.
Whisk millet flour with a splash of cool water to make a thin slurry. Stir it into the hot ginger water (off heat).
Add tamarind liquid (or concentrate), sugar, and salt. Stir well, strain if desired, and cool.
Chill thoroughly and serve over ice with mint.

BGD.description: The pride of Bengal. Hilsa fish cooked in a pungent, spicy mustard sauce.
ingredients: 1/2 cup Mustard Oil (essential for authentic taste)
steps: Soak mustard seeds in warm water, then blend into a smooth paste with 2 green chilies and a pinch of salt.
Rub fish steaks with turmeric and salt. Let sit for 10 mins.
Heat mustard oil in a pan. Temper with nigella seeds and slit green chilies.
Mix the mustard paste with 1 cup water and pour into the pan.
Gently slide the fish steaks into the gravy.
Cover and simmer on low heat for 10-15 minutes. Do not flip too often as fish is delicate.
Finish with a drizzle of raw mustard oil on top before serving with steaming white rice.

drink.description: Strong black tea commonly served with milk and sugar.
steps: Simmer tea in water 3–5 minutes.
Add milk and simmer 1–2 minutes.
Strain into cups and sweeten.

BGR.description: A symbol of Bulgarian hospitality. Whisked eggs and sirene cheese are layered between filo pastry sheets, then baked until golden. It is eaten for breakfast, Christmas, and New Year's—often with lucky charms hidden inside.
steps: Whisk eggs, yogurt, and baking soda. Stir in the crumbled cheese.
Brush a baking pan with butter.
Layering: Take a sheet of filo, brush with butter, spread a little filling, and roll it up like a cigar.
Coil the roll in the center of the pan. Repeat, coiling subsequent rolls around the center to form a spiral.
Brush the top with remaining butter.
Bake at 350°F (180°C) for 30-40 mins until crisp and golden.

drink.description: A thick, mildly sweet, gently fermented cereal drink popular in Bulgaria and the Balkans—served chilled, often with a sprinkle of cinnamon.
ingredients: 3/4 cup granulated sugar (150 g), plus more to taste
1/2 tsp active dry yeast (2 g) (or 2 tbsp plain yogurt as starter)
steps: Whisk millet flour with 2 cups of the water in a pot until smooth.
Add remaining water and a pinch of salt; bring to a gentle simmer, whisking often, 20–30 minutes until thickened and starchy.
Cool to lukewarm (about 90°F/32°C). Stir in sugar until dissolved.
Stir in yeast (or yogurt starter). Cover loosely and ferment at room temp 8–16 hours, until lightly tangy and gently bubbly.
Refrigerate until cold (it thickens more as it chills).
Serve cold, stirred; dust with cinnamon if you like.

BHR.dish: Machboos Dajaj (مجبوس دجاج) — Bahraini Chicken Rice
BHR.description: Bahrain’s signature spiced rice: chicken cooked in a tomato-and-aromatic broth with loomi (dried black lime), then the rice is steamed in the same stock for deep, layered flavor.
ingredients: 2 tbsp (30 ml) neutral oil or ghee
1 whole chicken (3–4 lb / 1.4–1.8 kg), cut into pieces
1 dried black lime (loomi), pierced with a knife
2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
3 cups (600 g) basmati rice, rinsed and soaked 20 minutes, drained
4 1/2 cups (1.1 L) water (or enough to cover chicken and later measure stock)
Optional: pinch saffron steeped in 2 tbsp hot water
Optional garnish: 1/3 cup (50 g) toasted almonds or raisins
steps: Heat oil in a large pot. Sauté onion until deeply golden, 10–12 minutes. Add garlic and cook 30 seconds.
Stir in tomato paste, then tomatoes; cook until jammy, 5–7 minutes.
Add chicken, loomi, bay, cardamom, cloves, cinnamon, cumin, coriander, turmeric, pepper, and salt. Add water to barely cover.
Bring to a boil, skim, then simmer covered 35–45 minutes until chicken is cooked.
Transfer chicken to a tray. Measure the cooking liquid; you need about 4 1/2 cups (1.1 L). Add water if short or boil to reduce if long. Taste and adjust salt.
Add drained rice to the pot. Bring to a gentle boil, then cover tightly and cook on low 15 minutes. Rest off heat 10 minutes.
Meanwhile, broil or oven-roast the chicken 8–12 minutes to brown.
Fluff rice, drizzle saffron water if using, and serve topped with chicken and optional nuts/raisins.

drink.dish: Karak Chai (شاي كرك) — Spiced Milk Tea
drink.description: Sweet, strong, and fragrant—Bahraini-style karak is black tea simmered with cardamom (often with saffron) and finished with milk.
ingredients: 2 tsp loose black tea (or 2 tea bags)
6 green cardamom pods, lightly crushed (or 1/2 tsp ground cardamom)
2 cups (475 ml) whole milk (or evaporated milk)
steps: Bring water to a simmer. Add tea and cardamom (and saffron if using). Simmer 3–5 minutes for a strong brew.
Add milk and sugar. Simmer 5–8 minutes, stirring occasionally, until slightly reduced and fragrant.
Strain and serve hot.

BHS.dish: Cracked Conch with Peas and Rice
BHS.description: The Queen Conch is the icon of the Bahamas. For this dish, the tough muscle is pounded until tender ('cracked'), battered, and fried to golden perfection, capturing the essence of island life alongside savory pigeon peas and rice.
ingredients: 1 lb Conch meat (cleaned and pounded thin)
Lime juice and Goat Pepper (or Habanero)
Rice: 2 cups Rice, 1 cup Pigeon Peas, Thyme, Tomato paste, Bacon/Salt pork
steps: Tenderize conch by pounding heavily with a mallet. Marinate in lime juice and spicy pepper for 15 mins.
Dip conch in egg wash (egg + milk), then dredge in seasoned flour.
Deep fry at 350°F (180°C) until golden brown (approx 3-4 mins). Do not overcook or it gets rubbery.
Rice: Fry bacon/pork. Add onion, thyme, and tomato paste. Add peas and water. Bring to boil.
Add rice, cover, and simmer until fluffy.
Serve conch with lime wedges, tartar sauce, and the rice.

drink.description: A famous Bahamian cocktail from Harbour Island: coconut rum + tropical fruit juices, sweet and beachy.
steps: Shake everything with ice.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice (or serve blended).
Garnish with pineapple or orange if you have it.

BIH.description: The Balkan king of kebabs. Small, hand-rolled sausages made of minced beef and lamb, grilled over charcoal and tucked into soft somun bread with raw onions and kajmak.
ingredients: 4 cloves Garlic (minced and boiled in 1/2 cup water - use the water)
steps: Mix meats, salt, pepper, baking soda, and the garlic water (strained). Knead well for 10 mins.
Refrigerate mixture overnight (crucial for texture).
Form into small finger-sized sausages.
Grill on high heat (charcoal is best) until browned and bouncy.
Serve tucked inside warm somun bread with a side of raw onions and a scoop of kajmak.

drink.description: Strong, foam-topped coffee made in a džezva and served with sugar cubes and lokum—central to Bosnian hospitality.
ingredients: 2 tsp very finely ground coffee (Turkish grind) (6–7 g)
To serve: sugar cubes and/or lokum (Turkish delight)
steps: Add water to a džezva (small long-handled pot) and heat until just below a boil.
Remove from heat, add coffee (and sugar if sweetening in the pot), and whisk to combine.
Return to low heat. When foam rises, remove before it boils over.
Let foam settle, then repeat the foam-rise once more for a richer top.
Pour slowly into small cups, dividing the foam between cups.
Let grounds settle 1–2 minutes before sipping.

BLR.description: The ultimate potato pancake. Belarusians claim to consume the most potatoes per capita, and this crispy, shallow-fried fritter—grated finely to release starch—is the delicious reason why.
ingredients: 1 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
Neutral oil for frying (about 1/4 cup / 60 ml)
To serve: sour cream; optional chopped dill
steps: Grate potatoes and onion on the fine holes of a box grater (or use a food processor).
Wrap in a clean towel and squeeze hard to remove excess liquid; pour off liquid and keep the starch that settles at the bottom.
Mix grated potato/onion with egg, flour, reserved potato starch, salt, and pepper.
Heat a thin layer of oil in a skillet over medium-high.
Drop heaping tablespoons of batter, flatten slightly, and fry 3–4 minutes per side until deeply golden.
Drain briefly on a rack or paper towels. Serve hot with sour cream (and dill if you like).

drink.dish: Birch Sap Kvass (Бярозавік / Fermented Birch Drink)
drink.description: A lightly fermented, gently sparkling drink made from birch sap (often sold bottled), sweetened and fermented with raisins or a pinch of yeast.
ingredients: 2 quarts birch sap (1.9 L), chilled (bottled birch sap works)
1/4 cup honey or sugar (60–70 g), to taste
Optional (for faster fermentation): 1/8 tsp active dry yeast
steps: In a clean 2–3 quart jar, dissolve honey/sugar in the birch sap.
Add raisins, lemon slices, and mint (if using).
If using yeast, sprinkle it on top and stir once.
Cover loosely (or use an airlock) and ferment at room temp 12–36 hours, until lightly fizzy.
Strain, bottle, and chill. Open carefully—pressure can build.
Drink within 3–5 days.

BLZ.dish: Stew Chicken with Rice and Beans
BLZ.description: The Sunday dinner of Belize. This comfort dish gets its signature crimson hue and earthy flavor from Red Recado (annatto paste), a Mayan spice staple, paired perfectly with rice cooked in fresh coconut milk.
ingredients: Rice & Beans: 2 cups Rice, 1 cup Red Kidney Beans (stewed), 1 cup Coconut Milk, Garlic
steps: Dissolve recado in a little vinegar/water. Rub over chicken with salt and pepper. Marinate.
Brown chicken pieces in a pot. Remove.
Sauté onions and peppers. Return chicken. Add water to cover. Simmer for 45 mins until tender and gravy thickens.
Rice: Mix cooked beans (with liquid), coconut milk, garlic, and uncooked rice in a pot.
Simmer covered until rice absorbs all liquid and is fluffy.
Serve with fried plantains and potato salad.

drink.description: A Belizean crowd-pleaser: coconut rum and pineapple juice, served cold and simple.
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice.
Add coconut rum and pineapple juice; stir.
Serve immediately.

ingredients: 2 tbsp bitter orange juice (or 1 tbsp orange + 1 tbsp lime)
steps: Toast achiote seeds briefly in a dry pan (30–60 seconds).
Grind achiote with peppercorns, cumin, cloves, oregano, and cinnamon to a powder (spice grinder).
Blend with garlic, citrus juice, vinegar, and salt into a thick paste.
Refrigerate up to 1 week, or freeze in portions.
Toast achiote seeds 30–60 seconds.
Blend or grind seeds with vinegar, garlic, salt (and cumin) until a red paste forms.
Strain if gritty. Refrigerate up to 1 week.

BMU.description: A British naval legacy adapted to island life. This dark, aromatic chowder is non-negotiable without its two sidekicks: a splash of Gosling's Black Seal Rum and a dash of Sherry Peppers sauce, added tableside to cut the richness.
steps: Sauté onion and celery. Add tomatoes and fish stock. Bring to a boil.
Add fish, herbs, and spices. Simmer for 30-40 mins until fish flakes apart.
Mash the fish against the side of the pot (it should be a chowder, not chunky stew).
Simmer for another 20 mins.
Serve hot. Crucial step: Each person adds a splash of Black Rum and Sherry Peppers sauce at the table.

drink.description: A Bermudian classic built on rum and fruit juices—often called Bermuda’s national drink.
steps: Shake all ingredients with ice.
Strain into an ice-filled glass.
Garnish if desired and serve.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool before using.
Warm pomegranate juice and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (avoid a hard boil).
Cool; stir in orange blossom water if using.
Bottle; add vodka if using for shelf-life.
Refrigerate and use within 3–4 weeks (longer if vodka added).
Combine all ingredients in a clean jar.
Cover and let steep at least 2–3 days (better after 1–2 weeks).
Strain if you want a smoother sauce; keep refrigerated up to 1 month.

BOL.description: The soup you can eat with your hands. These golden, braided pastries hold a sweet-and-spicy gelatinous stew that turns into rich broth upon baking. Legend says they were created by an exiled Argentine writer in Bolivia, hence 'Salteña'.
ingredients: Filling: 1 lb Beef (cubed), 1/2 cup Gelatinous Beef Broth (essential for juice), 2 Potatoes (cubed), Peas, Parsley
Flavor: Aji Amarillo (yellow chili paste), Cumin, Oregano, Sugar (for sweetness)
Dough: 4 cups Flour, 1 cup Lard/Butter, Achiote (for color), Sugar, Warm water
steps: Make 'Jigote' (Filling): Sauté beef with spices and sugar. Add broth and gelatin. Simmer until thick. Stir in potatoes and peas.
Chill the filling overnight. It must be solid (gelatinized) before wrapping.
Dough: Mix flour, hot lard (with achiote), and sugar water. Knead until smooth. Rest.
Assembly: Roll dough ovals. Place solid filling, egg, and olive in center. Seal with a braided seam (repulgue) on top.
Bake at very high heat (500°F/250°C) for 12-15 mins until golden and dark spots appear.
Eat carefully without spilling the juice!

drink.description: Bolivia’s classic highball: singani with ginger ale and lime—simple and refreshing.
steps: Fill a glass with ice.
Add singani and lime juice.
Top with ginger ale and stir gently.
Serve immediately.

preliminary_steps.item: Aji Amarillo Paste (Best: store-bought; quick homemade substitute)
ingredients: Recommended: store-bought aji amarillo paste, OR
2–3 yellow/orange hot chiles (or habanero in a pinch, not traditional)
1 tbsp white vinegar or lime juice
steps: For authenticity, use store-bought aji amarillo paste.
For a quick substitute: blend chiles with oil, vinegar/lime, salt (and garlic) into a smooth paste.
Refrigerate up to 5 days.

BRA.description: A gastronomic monument to Brazil's history. Once food for the enslaved using leftover cuts, it is now a national celebration. This smoky, inky-black stew of beans and salted pork is traditionally served on Saturdays with orange slices to cut the richness.
ingredients: 1/2 lb Carne Seca (Dried Beef) or Beef Jerky
steps: Soak beans and dried beef overnight (change water for beef to reduce salt).
In a massive pot, boil beans, beef, and ribs with the orange (helps cut the grease) and bay leaves.
Simmer for 1.5 hours.
In a pan, fry bacon and sliced sausage. Add garlic and onion. Sauté until fragrant.
Add a ladle of beans to the pan, mash them into a paste, then stir this mixture back into the main pot (this thickens the broth).
Simmer for another 45 mins until meat falls off the bone and broth is thick.
Serve with white rice, farofa (toasted cassava flour), and shredded collard greens.

Acre.description: A hearty, late-night-to-breakfast classic from Rio Branco markets: fluffy cuscuz de milho topped with well-seasoned carne moída and a runny fried egg. The name (“mess”) stuck because the plate looks chaotic — and the flavor absolutely works.
steps: Make the cuscuz: Mix flocão, water, and salt until evenly hydrated. Rest 10 minutes. Steam in a cuscuz pan for 10–12 minutes until fluffy. Fluff with butter.

Cook the beef: Sauté onion in a little oil until translucent. Add garlic, then ground beef. Brown deeply. Stir in tomato, cumin, paprika, salt, and pepper. Cook until the tomato melts and the mixture is juicy but not watery. Finish with cheiro-verde.
Fry eggs: In a hot pan with oil, fry eggs sunny-side up so the yolks stay runny.
Assemble: Mound cuscuz on plates, top with beef, then one egg per serving. Add hot sauce if you want it properly Acreano.

drink.description: An Amazonian fermented drink traditionally made from cassava/manioc—commonly associated with Indigenous communities in the western Amazon.
ingredients: Optional: pinch of yeast (for a modern, non-traditional assist)
steps: Mix mashed cassava with warm water in a clean jar; add sugar (and yeast if using).
Cover loosely and let ferment at room temperature 24–48 hours (until lightly tangy).
Stir, strain if desired, chill, and serve.

Alagoas.description: From the lagoons and mangroves around Maceió: sururu (small mussels) simmered in coconut milk with dendê and herbs. It’s coastal, Afro-Brazilian, and unapologetically fragrant.
steps: Sauté onion and bell pepper in dendê until softened. Add garlic and cook 30 seconds.
Add tomato and cook until it breaks down.
Add sururu, lime juice, and a splash of water. Cover and steam 3–4 minutes.
Pour in coconut milk, simmer gently 5–7 minutes. Season and finish with cilantro.
Serve immediately with rice (and farinha on the side if you’re doing it right).

drink.dish: Cachaça with Orange Peel (Alagoas-style Aguardente Aromatizada)
drink.description: Alagoas is known for sugarcane spirits; an orange-peel infusion is a common, simple local style.
steps: Add orange peel (and sugar if using) to a clean jar; cover with cachaça.
Infuse 2–5 days, tasting daily, then strain.
Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) neat or over ice.

Amapá.description: Macapá’s signature: shrimp steamed (“no bafo”) with aromatics and often a splash of cachaça. It’s simple, briny, and meant to be eaten with your hands and farofa.
steps: Toss shrimp with salt, lime juice, garlic, and cachaça. Rest 10 minutes.
In a wide pot, make a bed of onion, tomato, and bell pepper.
Add the shrimp on top. Cover tightly and steam over medium heat 8–12 minutes, shaking the pot once or twice, until shrimp are just cooked.
Serve hot with farofa and extra lime.

drink.description: A traditional ginger-based drink with cultural roots in Amapá’s Afro-Brazilian communities; often lightly fermented and served chilled.
ingredients: Optional: 1/8 tsp active dry yeast (for light fermentation)
steps: Simmer water with ginger 5 minutes; cool to lukewarm.
Stir in sugar and lime juice.
Optional: add yeast, cover loosely, and ferment 12–24 hours for light fizz.
Chill and serve over ice.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

Amazonas.description: A layered celebration dish from Manaus made with ‘bacalhau da Amazônia’ (salted pirarucu), bananas, potatoes, and farofa. Salty, sweet, crunchy, and built for a crowd.
steps: Desalt fish: Soak in cold water 12–24 hours, changing water 3–4 times. Poach gently 10–12 minutes, then flake.
Fry plantain slices until golden; drain.
Make the refogado: Sauté onions in oil until deeply soft. Add garlic, then tomatoes, cook to a thick sauce. Add flaked pirarucu and black pepper; cook 5 minutes. Stir in cheiro-verde.
Assemble in a baking dish: a thin layer of farofa, then potatoes, then fish mixture, then fried plantain. Repeat layers, finishing with farofa.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 20–25 minutes until hot and lightly crisped on top.

drink.description: A beloved regional guaraná soda from Amazonas—best served ice-cold.
steps: Fill a glass with ice.
Pour in Guaraná Baré and add lime if you like.
Serve immediately.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

Bahia.description: Bahia’s Afro-Brazilian icon: fish simmered with coconut milk and dendê, perfumed with coentro. It’s one of those dishes where the aroma hits before you even see the bowl.
ingredients: 2 lbs Firm white fish (grouper/snapper/monkfish), in chunks
Cooked rice, pirão, and farofa (to serve)
steps: Marinate fish with lime, garlic, salt, and pepper for 20 minutes.
In a clay pot or heavy saucepan, layer onion, tomato, pepper, then fish. Repeat layers.
Add coconut milk. Simmer covered 15–20 minutes until fish is just done. Do not stir aggressively (you’ll break the fish).
Stir in dendê and cilantro at the end. Simmer 2 minutes more.
Serve with rice and farofa; make pirão from the broth if you want the full experience.

drink.description: A creamy beach cocktail associated with southern Bahia (Porto Seguro), typically made with vodka, guaraná powder, and warm spices.
steps: Blend everything with a handful of ice until smooth.
Serve immediately in a chilled glass.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

Ceará.description: A Ceará staple: rice cooked with feijão-de-corda (cowpeas), often with queijo coalho and carne seca. It’s the Northeast in one pot — practical, rich, and communal.
ingredients: 1 cup Cooked feijão-de-corda (cowpeas) with a bit of broth
steps: Desalt carne seca overnight, then simmer until tender and shred.
Sauté bacon (if using) until fat renders. Add onion and cook until soft. Add garlic and cumin.
Add shredded carne seca and fry lightly.
Add rice and stir to coat. Add beans with enough broth/water to cook rice (about 2 cups total liquid).
Simmer covered until rice is tender. Fold in butter and queijo coalho at the end. Finish with herbs.

drink.description: A clarified cashew-apple drink closely associated with Brazil’s Northeast; served chilled and lightly sweet.
ingredients: 8–12 oz (240–355 ml) cajuína (bottled) or clarified cashew-apple juice
steps: Chill well.
Serve straight (over ice if desired).

Distrito Federal.description: A Brasília favorite with roots in the Center-West: chicken and rice cooked together with saffron-like color (açafrão-da-terra) and comfort built into every grain.
steps: Season chicken with salt, pepper, and garlic. Brown in oil until golden; remove.
Sauté onion in the same pot. Add turmeric and tomato; cook until jammy.
Add rice and stir to coat. Return chicken.
Add hot water/stock (about 4 cups). Simmer covered until rice is done and chicken is tender.
Fold in peas if using, rest 5 minutes, finish with herbs.

drink.description: Brazil’s national cocktail—widely enjoyed in Brasília and across the country.
steps: Muddle lime wedges with sugar in a rocks glass.
Fill with ice and add cachaça.
Stir well and serve.

Espírito Santo.description: Espírito Santo’s pride: moqueca without dendê or coconut — lighter, tomato-forward, and traditionally cooked in a panela de barro. It’s the ‘other’ moqueca and it’s not a consolation prize.
steps: Season fish with salt and pepper.
Layer onion, tomato, and pepper in a pot. Add fish and drizzle with olive oil and annatto oil.
Add stock/water, cover, and simmer gently 15–18 minutes until fish is done.
Finish with cilantro and serve with rice and lime.

drink.description: Espírito Santo is a major producer of conilon (robusta) coffee—typically brewed strong and served simply.
steps: Brew coffee using your preferred method (filter, French press, or moka).
Serve hot; sweeten if desired.

Goiás.description: Goiás’ emblematic savory pie stuffed with chicken, sausage, and often pequi. It’s rustic party food that eats like a full meal.
ingredients: Filling: 1/2 lb Linguiça, sliced and browned
steps: Dough: Rub flour and salt with cold butter until sandy. Mix in eggs, then add water just until it comes together. Chill 30 minutes.
Filling: Sauté onion and garlic, add tomato, then chicken, browned linguiça, olives, and corn. Cook until cohesive. Season well; cool completely.
Assemble: Line a deep pie dish with dough, fill, top with dough lid. Seal edges. Brush with egg wash.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 45–55 minutes until deeply golden. Rest 15 minutes before slicing.

drink.description: A Goiás/Cerrado specialty liqueur made from pequi’s distinctive aroma—served in small glasses after meals.
ingredients: 2–3 tbsp pequi pulp (or pequi flavoring, if available)
steps: Combine cachaça, pequi pulp, and sugar in a jar; shake well.
Infuse 2–3 days, then strain (or leave a little pulp for aroma).
Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) chilled or on ice.

Maranhão.description: Maranhão’s signature rice made with vinagreira (hibiscus leaves), sesame, and dried shrimp. Tart, savory, and unmistakably São Luís.
ingredients: 2 cups Cooked white rice (or 1 cup uncooked)
steps: Blanch vinagreira leaves 1 minute; drain and chop.
Sauté onion in oil until soft, add garlic.
Add vinagreira and sauté 2–3 minutes. Add dried shrimp if using.
Stir in rice and sesame seeds. Season and heat through until aromatic.

drink.description: A famous pink guaraná-flavored soda strongly associated with Maranhão—sweet, spiced, and best ice-cold.
steps: Chill well.
Serve straight (over ice if you like).

Mato Grosso.description: A Mato Grosso classic: rice cooked with carne seca and aromatics. A one-pot meal from cattle-country practicality.
steps: Desalt carne seca (overnight), then simmer until tender; dice.
Brown carne seca in oil. Add onion until softened, then garlic.
Add rice and stir to coat. Add hot water (about 3 cups) and simmer covered until rice is done.
Rest 5 minutes, fluff, finish with herbs.

drink.description: Cold-brewed mate traditionally sipped through a bombilla; common across the Center-West, especially in hot weather.
steps: Fill gourd/cup with erva-mate on a slant.
Pour in ice-cold water and sip through bombilla (or steep in a glass and strain).
Top up with more cold water as you drink.

Mato Grosso do Sul.description: A Japanese-Brazilian staple that became a state identity dish in Campo Grande: noodle soup with pork broth, omelet strips, and cheiro-verde. MS is one of Brazil’s strongest examples of migration shaping ‘regional’ cuisine.
ingredients: 1 tbsp Mirin (optional) or a pinch of sugar
1/2 lb Pork belly or shoulder, thinly sliced
steps: Broth: Bring broth to a gentle simmer. Season with soy sauce, mirin/sugar, salt, and white pepper to taste.
Cook noodles according to package; rinse briefly to remove excess starch, then reheat quickly in hot water.
Cook pork slices in the simmering broth until just done.
Make a thin omelet, roll and slice into strips.
Assemble: Noodles in bowl, ladle broth and pork, top with omelet strips and herbs.

drink.description: Mato Grosso do Sul is especially associated with tereré—cold mate, often with herbs or citrus.
ingredients: Optional: a few mint leaves or a squeeze of lime
steps: Add erva-mate to a gourd/cup.
Pour in ice-cold water (and mint/lime if using).
Sip and top up as you go.

Minas Gerais.description: Minas on a plate: beans tossed with farinha, eggs, and pork. Born from the tropeiros (muleteers) who needed durable, caloric food on long routes.
ingredients: 3 cups Cooked pinto beans (drained; reserve a little broth)
steps: Fry bacon until crisp; add linguiça and brown. Remove excess fat if needed.
Sauté onion in the fat, add garlic.
Add beans and warm through. Push to the side and scramble eggs in the same pan.
Add farinha gradually, tossing until everything is coated and lightly toasted. Adjust with a splash of reserved bean broth if too dry.
Season and serve with sautéed couve and orange slices.

drink.description: Minas Gerais is famous for small-batch cachaça; traditionally served neat in small pours.
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Sip slowly, often with snacks like queijo and torresmo.

Pará.description: Pará’s street-food rite: hot tucupi broth with jambu (the tingly leaf), goma de tapioca, and dried shrimp. If it doesn’t numb your lips a little, it’s the tourist version.
steps: Boil tucupi with garlic and salt for 15–20 minutes.
Blanch jambu until tender; drain.
Cook goma: Mix tapioca starch with water, then heat, stirring until it turns translucent and thick.
Assemble: goma in bowl, add jambu, pour hot tucupi, top with shrimp. Add chili sauce to taste.

drink.description: A Pará signature twist using jambu (the numbing herb of the Amazon) via jambu-infused cachaça.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) cachaça de jambu (or cachaça infused with jambu)
steps: Muddle lime wedges with sugar in a rocks glass.
Fill with ice and add cachaça de jambu.
Stir well and serve.

ingredients: 1–2 cups fresh jambu leaves and tender stems (and/or flowers), rinsed and patted dry
Optional: 1 tsp sugar (rounds edges; not required)
steps: Lightly bruise the jambu (crush gently with your hands or a muddler to help extraction).
Add jambu to a clean jar and pour in the cachaça. Seal.
Infuse in the fridge or a cool, dark place; start tasting after 6–8 hours.
Strain when the aroma and the numbing/tingly effect are noticeable but not harsh (often 12–48 hours).
Bottle and keep chilled. Use within 1–2 weeks for best freshness.
Combine tucupi, peppers, garlic, and salt in a saucepan.
Simmer gently 10–15 minutes.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

Paraíba.description: A Paraíba comfort dish: rice and beans cooked together with queijo coalho and often carne de sol. It’s creamy, savory, and built for family tables.
ingredients: 1 cup Cooked beans (feijão verde or feijão macassa) with some broth
steps: Desalt and cook carne de sol if needed; sauté until lightly crisp.
Sauté onion and garlic. Add rice and stir to coat.
Add beans plus enough liquid to cook rice (about 2 cups total). Simmer covered until rice is tender.
Fold in butter and queijo coalho at the end. Rest 5 minutes. Finish with herbs.

drink.description: Paraíba has a strong cachaça tradition; simplest is best: serve neat or as a lime-and-sugar caipirinha.
ingredients: Optional: lime + sugar + ice (for a caipirinha)
steps: Serve neat in a small glass, or use it as the spirit for a basic caipirinha.

Paraná.description: A coastal Paraná tradition (Morretes/Antonina): beef slow-cooked for hours in a sealed clay pot until it shreds into a thick stew, served with farinha and banana.
ingredients: Farinha de mandioca and sliced banana (to serve)
steps: Season beef with garlic, cumin, pepper, vinegar, and salt. Rest 30 minutes.
In a heavy pot, layer onions and beef with bay leaves. Add stock just to barely cover.
Seal tightly (foil under lid helps mimic the traditional clay-pot seal). Simmer on very low heat 4–6 hours until falling apart.
Shred beef in the pot and reduce to a thick stew. Serve with farinha and banana.

drink.description: Hot mate tea (chimarrão) is strongly associated with Southern Brazil, including Paraná.
steps: Fill a gourd/cup with erva-mate on a slant.
Add hot water (not boiling) and sip through a bombilla (or steep and strain).
Top up with more hot water as you drink.

Pernambuco.description: Pernambuco’s showpiece dessert: ultra-thin cake layers rolled with goiabada into a tight spiral. A colonial adaptation of European rolled cakes, made obsessively thin.
steps: Make goiabada spread: Melt goiabada with water into a smooth paste; cool.
Beat butter and sugar until pale and fluffy. Add eggs one at a time.
Fold in flour and salt just until smooth.
Bake very thin layers: Spread a paper-thin layer of batter on a parchment-lined sheet. Bake at 350°F (180°C) for 4–6 minutes, just set.
Flip onto a towel, spread a thin layer of goiabada, and roll tightly while warm.
Repeat with more thin cake layers, rolling onto the existing log to build spirals. Chill, slice thin, dust with powdered sugar.

drink.description: Pitú is a classic Pernambuco cachaça brand; used here in the national caipirinha format.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Pitú cachaça (or any cachaça)
steps: Muddle lime and sugar in a rocks glass.
Fill with ice, add cachaça, stir, and serve.

ingredients: 2 lbs ripe guavas (or 4 cups guava pulp)
steps: If using fresh guavas: simmer guavas with water until soft; blend and strain seeds.
Cook guava pulp with sugar and salt over medium-low heat, stirring frequently, until very thick and paste-like (30–60 minutes).
Add citrus if using. Pour into a lined pan and cool to set.
Refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

Piauí.description: Piauí’s traditional ‘paçoca’ is not candy: it’s carne de sol pounded with farinha and aromatics into a savory crumble. Portable, salty, and historically practical.
steps: Desalt carne de sol overnight, then simmer until tender. Shred very finely.
Sauté onion and garlic in butter until soft. Add shredded meat and fry until dry and flavorful.
Add farinha and toast, stirring until evenly crumbly. Season with pepper and herbs.
Serve with rice and beans or with banana; it’s also a killer stuffing for tapioca.

drink.description: Piauí is especially associated with cajuína (clarified cashew-apple juice), served chilled.
steps: Chill well.
Serve straight (over ice if desired).

Rio de Janeiro.description: Rio’s Saturday institution: black beans simmered with pork cuts, served with rice, farofa, couve, and orange. A dish that turned leftovers into a ritual.
ingredients: 1 lb Pork ribs or shoulder chunks
To serve: white rice, sautéed collard greens, farofa, orange slices
steps: Soak beans overnight.
Brown bacon and sausage; remove. Brown pork ribs/shoulder; set aside.
Sauté onion and garlic in the same pot. Add beans, bay leaves, browned meats, and water to cover.
Simmer 2–3 hours until beans are creamy and meats tender. Skim excess fat and adjust seasoning.
Serve with rice, couve, farofa, and orange.

drink.description: Iconic all over Brazil and a staple in Rio’s bars and beaches.
steps: Muddle lime and sugar in a rocks glass.
Fill with ice, add cachaça, stir well, and serve.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

Rio Grande do Norte.description: A Rio Grande do Norte staple: salted sun-cured beef with buttery cassava (macaxeira/aipim). The technique was a solution to heat and distance — now it’s pure comfort.
steps: Desalt carne de sol by soaking 6–12 hours, changing water. Pat dry.
Sear or grill the meat until browned and cooked through; slice.
Boil macaxeira until very tender; drain. Mash with butter and black pepper (or serve in chunks with butter).
Sauté onion and garlic in butter and spoon over the meat.
Serve meat with macaxeira and lime.

drink.description: A traditional ginger drink found in parts of Brazil, including Rio Grande do Norte; served chilled and sometimes lightly fermented.
steps: Simmer water with ginger 5 minutes; cool to lukewarm.
Stir in sugar and lime juice.
Optional: add yeast, cover loosely, ferment 12–24 hours for light fizz.
Chill and serve over ice.

Rio Grande do Sul.description: Rio Grande do Sul’s culinary identity: slow-roasted beef over wood embers with nothing but coarse salt. Technique and fire do the talking.
ingredients: 1 large Beef short ribs rack (costela), 6–10 lbs
Optional: chimichurri-style molho (parsley, garlic, vinegar, oil)
steps: Salt generously 40–60 minutes before cooking.
Cook over indirect embers (no flames) on a parrilla or churrasqueira for 4–6+ hours, turning occasionally, until deeply browned and tender.
Rest 10–15 minutes. Slice and serve with farofa or pão, and molho if desired.

drink.description: Rio Grande do Sul’s signature: hot mate shared socially, bitter and aromatic.
steps: Fill gourd/cup with erva-mate on a slant.
Add hot water (not boiling) and sip through a bombilla (or steep and strain).
Top up with more hot water as you drink.

ingredients: 2 tbsp dried oregano (or 1/4 cup fresh, chopped)
1/2 tsp red pepper flakes (or to taste)
steps: Mix parsley, garlic, oregano, and chili flakes in a bowl.
Stir in vinegar, then olive oil; season with salt and pepper.
Rest 20–30 minutes before serving (better after a few hours). Refrigerate up to 3–4 days.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

Rondônia.description: An Amazonian fish stew common in Rondônia: tucunaré (peacock bass) simmered with vegetables, herbs, and a rich broth for arroz and pirão.
steps: Season fish with lime, salt, and pepper.
Layer vegetables and fish in a pot; drizzle with olive oil.
Add stock to just cover, simmer gently 20–25 minutes until fish is done.
Finish with cilantro and serve with rice and pirão.

drink.description: Rondônia is known for robusta coffee cultivation; brewed strong and served simply.
steps: Brew coffee using your preferred method.
Serve hot; sweeten if desired.

Roraima.description: An Indigenous-origin stew in Roraima made with fish, peppers, and tucupi. It’s sharp, hot, and deeply regional — not a softened ‘Brazilian’ version.
ingredients: 2 lbs Fresh fish (firm, cut into chunks)
steps: Boil tucupi with garlic and salt for 15 minutes.
Add onion and peppers; simmer 5 minutes.
Add fish and cook gently 8–10 minutes until just done.
Finish with cheiro-verde. Serve with cassava or rice.

drink.description: A traditional fermented cassava beverage associated with Indigenous communities in northern Brazil; this is a simplified home method.
steps: Mix mashed cassava with warm water in a clean jar; add sugar if using.
Cover loosely and ferment 24–48 hours until lightly tangy.
Stir, strain if desired, chill, and serve.

Santa Catarina.description: A Santa Catarina coast tradition: a ‘sequence’ of shrimp courses — from crispy to creamy — showcasing local fisheries. This is restaurant culture turned regional identity.
steps: Season shrimp with salt, pepper, and lime.
Course 1 (fried): Bread half the shrimp and fry until golden; keep warm.
Course 2 (creamy): Sauté onion and garlic in butter, add tomato sauce, simmer 5 minutes. Add remaining shrimp and cook 2–3 minutes. Stir in cream and heat gently.
Serve the fried shrimp first, then the creamy shrimp over rice (or together, like many places do).

drink.description: A classic winter/Festa Junina drink popular in Southern Brazil: cachaça simmered with ginger and spices.
steps: In a pot, simmer water, sugar, ginger, and spices 10 minutes.
Add cachaça and heat gently 3–5 minutes (do not boil hard).
Strain and serve hot in mugs.

São Paulo.description: São Paulo’s classic plate: beans thickened with farinha, served with pork, couve, egg, banana, and rice. It’s a working-city meal that became tradition.
ingredients: 2 cups Cooked beans (carioca) with some broth
steps: Cook pork: Pan-sear chops/sausages until done; keep warm.
Virado: Warm beans in a pan, then stir in farinha gradually until thick and spoonable. Season.
Couve: Sauté garlic in oil, add couve and stir-fry quickly until just wilted; salt.
Fry eggs. Optionally fry banana slices.
Plate with rice, virado, pork, couve, egg, and banana.

drink.description: A classic São Paulo cocktail: cachaça and sweet vermouth, often with a dash of bitters.
steps: Fill a mixing glass with ice.
Add cachaça, vermouth, and bitters; stir 15–20 seconds.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Express orange peel if using.

Sergipe.description: Sergipe’s coast in a pot: crab cooked with tomatoes, peppers, and herbs, eaten the traditional way — hands messy, table loud.
steps: Sauté onion, pepper, and garlic in olive oil until fragrant.
Add tomatoes and cook into a rough sauce.
Add crabs, lime juice, a splash of water, cover and simmer 15–20 minutes until crabs are cooked through.
Finish with cilantro and serve with farofa and vinaigrette-style salad.

drink.description: Mangaba fruit is strongly associated with Sergipe; the juice is fragrant, creamy, and served cold.
steps: Blend mangaba pulp with water and sugar until smooth.
Strain if you prefer it thinner.
Serve over ice.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

Tocantins.description: A Tocantins hallmark: beef shank stewed slowly with aromatics until gelatin-rich and spoon-tender, typically served with rice and farinha. Simple, but when done right it’s luxurious.
steps: Season shanks with salt and pepper. Brown in oil.
Sauté onion and garlic, add tomatoes, cumin, and bay leaves; cook down.
Return shanks, add stock to cover halfway. Simmer covered 2.5–3.5 hours until very tender and broth is gelatinous.
Adjust seasoning, finish with cilantro. Serve with rice and farinha.

drink.description: Buriti (a Cerrado palm fruit) is used for juices in parts of the North/Cerrado; served chilled.
steps: Blend buriti pulp with water and sugar until smooth.
Chill and serve over ice.

drink.description: Brazil’s signature cocktail built on cachaça, muddled lime, and sugar—bright, grassy, and dangerously easy to drink.
ingredients: 2 tsp superfine sugar (or 2 tsp granulated sugar)
steps: In a rocks glass, add lime wedges and sugar.
Muddle gently to release juice and oils without pulverizing the bitter pith.
Fill the glass with crushed ice.
Add cachaça and stir well to dissolve the sugar and chill the drink.
Top with a bit more crushed ice if needed and serve with a short straw.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

BRB.description: The 'Land of the Flying Fish' on a plate. This dish pairs a smooth, polenta-like cornmeal and okra mash (Cou-Cou) with the island's abundant flying fish, stewed in a gravy bursting with Bajan seasoning and Scotch Bonnet heat.
ingredients: 4 Flying Fish fillets (or mild white fish like Tilapia/Snapper)
Seasoning: Lime, Thyme, Onion, Garlic, Scotch Bonnet pepper
Sauce: Tomato, Onion, Garlic, Curry powder (optional)
Cou-Cou: 2 cups Cornmeal, 10 Okras (sliced), 4 cups Water, Butter
steps: Season fish with lime and herbs. Let sit.
Make Sauce: Sauté aromatics and tomatoes. Add water and simmer. Poach the fish in this gravy for 10 mins.
Cou-Cou: Boil okras in water until soft. Remove okras but keep liquid.
Whisk cornmeal into the hot okra water gradually (prevent lumps). Stir constantly with a 'cou-cou stick' (wooden spoon).
Add cooked okra and butter. Cook until mixture pulls away from the pot sides.
Serve the smooth cornmeal mound with the fish and gravy in the center.

drink.description: Barbados has one of the Caribbean’s most iconic rum punch styles—lime, sugar, rum, water, bitters, and nutmeg.
ingredients: 2 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz / 15 ml simple syrup)
1 oz (30 ml) water (or chilled black tea)
steps: Shake rum, lime juice, sugar, and water with ice.
Strain over fresh ice.
Add bitters and grate nutmeg on top.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

BRN.description: Brunei’s iconic starch dish made from sago (ambulong). It’s intentionally mild and eaten by twirling the sticky gel onto a bamboo fork (candas) and dipping into punchy ‘cacah’ sauces.
steps: In a heatproof bowl, whisk sago starch with 1 cup (240 ml) water and salt until smooth.
Bring remaining 2 1/2 cups (590 ml) water to a rolling boil.
While whisking constantly, carefully pour the boiling water into the starch mixture. Keep whisking until it turns glossy and translucent and thickens into a stretchy gel.
Serve immediately with cacah dipping sauce (see preliminary steps).

ingredients: 1 tbsp tamarind pulp (or 1 tbsp tamarind concentrate + 2 tbsp water)
steps: If using shrimp paste, toast it briefly in a dry pan 30–60 seconds to mellow it.
Mix chilies, shallot, garlic, lime juice, tamarind, sugar, and shrimp paste (if using).
Season with salt. Let sit 10 minutes so flavors round out; adjust sweet/sour/salt to taste.

drink.description: ‘Pulled tea’—strong black tea sweetened with condensed milk and repeatedly poured between cups to create a foamy head. Brunei’s kopitiam classic.
ingredients: 2 tbsp loose black tea (or 4 tea bags)
1/2 cup (120 ml) evaporated milk (or whole milk)
Optional: 1–2 tsp sugar (usually not needed with condensed milk)
steps: Steep tea in boiling water 5–6 minutes for a strong brew; strain.
Stir in condensed milk and evaporated milk (and sugar if using).
‘Pull’ the tea: pour it back and forth between two mugs from a height several times until frothy.
Serve hot.

BTN.description: Bhutan’s emblematic comfort dish: chilies treated as a vegetable and simmered with cheese into a simple, fiery stew often eaten with red rice.
ingredients: 10–12 fresh green chilies (about 8 oz / 225 g), sliced lengthwise
7 oz (200 g) feta or farmer cheese, crumbled (traditional uses local cheese)
Optional: 1/2 cup (120 ml) milk for a creamier stew
steps: Combine chilies, onion, garlic, butter, and water in a saucepan. Simmer 10–12 minutes until chilies soften.
Add cheese (and milk if using). Simmer gently 5–8 minutes, stirring, until the cheese melts into a creamy sauce.
Taste and salt lightly (cheese may already be salty). Serve hot with rice.

drink.description: A warming Himalayan staple: strong tea blended with butter, milk, and salt for a savory, energizing cup—common in Bhutanese homes and monasteries.
ingredients: 2 tbsp black tea leaves (Assam works well) or 3 tea bags
steps: Boil water, add tea, and simmer 5–7 minutes for a strong brew. Strain.
Add milk and bring back to a simmer.
Blend with butter and salt (use a blender or immersion blender) until emulsified and slightly foamy.
Serve hot.

BWA.description: Botswana’s national dish: beef (or goat) simmered until falling-apart tender, then pounded/shredded and served with a starchy side.
ingredients: 3 lb beef chuck or brisket, cut into large chunks
2 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Place beef in a heavy pot. Add onion and bay leaves (if using). Add water to just cover.
Bring to a boil, skim foam, then reduce to a gentle simmer. Cover and cook until the beef is extremely tender, 2 1/2–3 1/2 hours.
Remove beef to a bowl. Reserve about 1 cup of the cooking liquid; discard onion/bay.
Shred and pound the beef with a wooden spoon or pestle until fibrous and fluffy.
Return beef to the pot with a splash of reserved liquid. Season with salt and pepper and cook uncovered 5–10 minutes to concentrate flavor.
Serve hot (commonly with pap/bogobe, rice, or bread).

drink.description: A traditional homemade ginger drink found in Botswana and across Southern Africa—lightly fermented and served well chilled.
ingredients: 1/2 tsp cream of tartar (optional, for tang)
1/8 tsp active dry yeast (optional, for consistent fermentation)
steps: Bring 6 cups of the water to a boil. Stir in sugar and grated ginger. Simmer 5 minutes.
Turn off heat. Add remaining 4 cups water to cool it down, then stir in lemon juice and cream of tartar (if using). Cool to lukewarm.
Pour into a clean jar. Add raisins and yeast (if using). Cover loosely and let ferment at room temperature 12–24 hours.
Strain, bottle, and refrigerate. Serve very cold over ice.

CAF.description: Central African pumpkin-seed meatballs simmered in a savory peanut-tomato sauce.
ingredients: 1 medium onion, divided (half grated, half chopped)
steps: Toast pumpkin seeds in a dry skillet until fragrant, 3–5 minutes. Cool, then grind to a coarse meal.
In a bowl, mix ground beef, egg, ground pumpkin seeds, grated onion, half the garlic, salt, and pepper. Form golf-ball meatballs.
Heat oil in a pot and brown meatballs lightly on all sides. Remove to a plate.
Sauté chopped onion until soft. Add remaining garlic and tomato paste; cook 1 minute.
Whisk in peanut butter and stock to make a smooth sauce. Add paprika and chile (if using).
Return meatballs to the pot. Simmer gently 20–25 minutes until cooked through and the sauce thickens. Taste and adjust salt.
Serve with rice, cassava, or plantains.

drink.description: A sharp, sweet ginger drink common across Central Africa; served cold.
ingredients: 6 oz fresh ginger, peeled and chopped
steps: Blend ginger with 2 cups water until very smooth. Strain through a fine sieve or cheesecloth into a pitcher.
Add remaining 6 cups water, sugar, lime juice, and a pinch of salt. Stir well.
Chill thoroughly and serve over ice.

CAN.description: A messy, glorious symbol of Quebecois culture born in 1950s rural diners. True poutine demands fresh cheese curds that 'squeak' against your teeth, melting slightly under a deluge of hot, savory brown gravy over crispy fries.
ingredients: 2 cups Fresh Cheese Curds (must be room temp for squeak)
steps: Cut potatoes into 1cm sticks. Soak in cold water for 1 hour.
Make gravy: Melt butter, whisk in flour to make a roux (cook 2 mins). Whisk in beef and chicken stock. Simmer until thickened. Season with pepper.
Deep fry potatoes at 325°F (160°C) for 3-4 mins. Remove and cool.
Increase oil to 375°F (190°C). Fry again until dark golden brown.
Assembly (Crucial): Place hot fries in a bowl. Add cheese curds on top.
Pour boiling hot gravy over the curds to warm them (slightly melt) but keep the squeak.

drink.description: Canada’s signature savory cocktail: vodka with Clamato, hot sauce, and Worcestershire, typically with a celery-salt rim.
steps: Rim a highball glass with celery salt (run a lime wedge around the rim, then dip in celery salt).
Fill the glass with ice and add vodka.
Add Clamato, Worcestershire, and hot sauce; stir.
Garnish with a lime wedge (and celery stalk/pickle if you like).

CHE.description: Alpine survival food turned global luxury. 'Half-and-Half' refers to the blend of Gruyère and Vacherin Fribourgeois cheeses, melted with white wine and garlic into a communal pot of liquid gold.
ingredients: 1 tbsp Cornstarch (dissolved in a splash of Kirsch)
steps: Rub the inside of the caquelon (fondue pot) with the garlic clove.
Add wine and bring to a simmer.
Gradually add the cheese, stirring constantly in a figure-8 motion.
Once melted, stir in the cornstarch/Kirsch mixture to stabilize.
Keep warm over a flame. Dip bread cubes and stir to prevent burning.

drink.description: A classic Central Swiss coffee drink: hot coffee “corrected” with kirsch (or other fruit brandy).
steps: Warm a mug with hot water, then discard the water.
Add kirsch (and sugar if using).
Pour in hot coffee and stir.
Serve immediately.

CHL.description: A summer classic fusing Andean corn (choclo) with Spanish influence. This 'corn pie' hides a treasure trove of 'pino' (seasoned beef), chicken, olives, and raisins beneath a sweet, caramelized corn crust, baked in traditional clay pots.
steps: Make the 'Pino': Sauté onions until soft. Add beef, cumin, salt, and paprika. Cook until browned. Stir in raisins and olives.
Blend the corn kernels with milk and basil until smooth. Cook this paste in a pot with butter and sugar until thickened (approx 10 mins).
Assemble: In a clay pot or baking dish, spread the beef mixture (Pino) at the bottom.
Layer the shredded chicken and slices of hard-boiled egg on top.
Cover everything with the thick corn paste. Sprinkle sugar on top for caramelization.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 30-40 minutes until the top is golden brown and bubbling.

drink.description: A South American classic (claimed by Peru and Chile): pisco shaken with lime, simple syrup, egg white, and bitters.
steps: Add pisco, lime juice, simple syrup, and egg white to a shaker (no ice) and dry-shake 15 seconds.
Add ice and shake hard 15–20 seconds until very cold and frothy.
Double-strain into a chilled coupe or rocks glass.
Dot the foam with bitters and serve immediately.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

CHN.description: Imperial cuisine. Requires technique to get the skin glass-like and crispy.
steps: Clean duck. Pump air under the skin to separate it from the meat (use a straw or pump).
Blanch the duck in boiling water for 1 minute to tighten skin.
Glaze: Mix melted maltose, soy sauce, and spices. Brush all over duck.
Hang the duck in a cool, breezy place for 24 hours to dry out the skin completely.
Roast vertically at 400°F (200°C) for 30 mins, then lower to 350°F until skin is mahogany red.
Carve the crispy skin first, then the meat.
Serve wrapped in pancakes with scallion, cucumber, and hoisin.

Anhui.description: Named after Li Hongzhang, a prominent statesman of the Qing Dynasty, who reportedly enjoyed this dish during his travels. It is a classic example of Huizhou cuisine, known for its rich broth and diverse combination of meats, seafood, and vegetables. Anhui cuisine, also known as Hui cuisine, is one of the Eight Culinary Traditions of Chinese cuisine. It is known for its use of wild ingredients and its emphasis on simple and precise preparation methods, with braising, stewing, and steaming being frequently used.
ingredients: 1 lb chicken bones or 1 whole chicken (about 2–3 lbs), cut into pieces
1/2 lb pork bones (optional, for richer flavor)
1/4 lb squid, cleaned and sliced into rings
1/4 lb fish fillet (e.g., cod or tilapia), sliced
4 dried shiitake mushrooms, soaked and sliced
1/2 cup wood ear mushrooms, soaked and sliced
1/2 cup firm tofu, cut into 1-inch cubes
1 cup glass noodles (mung bean vermicelli), soaked
steps: Prepare the Broth: In a large stockpot, combine the chicken bones (or whole chicken pieces) and optional pork bones. Add 8 cups of cold water, smashed ginger, 3-inch scallion pieces, Shaoxing wine, and 1 teaspoon of salt. Bring to a boil over high heat, then skim off any foam. Reduce heat to low and simmer, uncovered, for 1.5–2 hours until the broth is fragrant and slightly reduced.
Prepare Ingredients: While the broth simmers, prepare all the hotchpotch ingredients as specified in the ingredient list.

Sauté Meats: Heat 2 tablespoons of vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the minced garlic and minced ginger, stir-frying for 30 seconds until aromatic. Add the thinly sliced chicken and pork, stir-frying for 2–3 minutes until just cooked through. Remove and set aside.

Sauté Seafood: In the same wok, add the shrimp, squid, and fish fillet. Stir-fry for 1–2 minutes until the shrimp turn pink and the squid curls slightly. Be careful not to overcook. Remove and set aside with the chicken and pork.

Combine and Simmer: Bring the prepared broth to a gentle boil in the stockpot. Stir in the soy sauce, oyster sauce, sugar, and white pepper. Add the soaked shiitake mushrooms, wood ear mushrooms, bamboo shoots, carrot, and lotus root to the broth. Simmer for 5–7 minutes until the vegetables are tender-crisp.
Add Remaining Ingredients: Add the firm tofu, napa cabbage, and soaked glass noodles to the broth. Cook for another 3–5 minutes until the cabbage is tender and the noodles are cooked through.
Final Assembly: Return the sautéed chicken, pork, shrimp, squid, and fish to the pot. Simmer for 2–3 minutes to meld the flavors, ensuring not to overcook the seafood.

Serve: Drizzle 1 teaspoon of sesame oil over the hotchpotch for a nutty, aromatic finish. Ladle the hotchpotch into a large serving bowl or individual bowls, ensuring each portion has a balance of meats, seafood, vegetables, and noodles. Garnish with chopped scallions. Serve hot, ideally with steamed rice.

drink.description: A flagship baijiu from Anhui’s Bozhou area, typically enjoyed neat in small cups during banquets and toasts.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Gujinggong baijiu (or another Anhui strong-aroma baijiu)
steps: Serve at cool room temperature (or lightly chilled if you prefer).
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and drink in small sips (or ‘ganbei’ in one go, banquet-style).

Beijing.description: A world-renowned dish with a history spanning over 600 years, originating from the Ming Dynasty imperial cuisine. Initially reserved for emperors, it became a symbol of prestige and refinement. Its popularity grew during the Qing Dynasty, and it has since become a cultural icon, even playing a role in diplomacy. The specific breed of duck used is the Pekin Duck, known for its mild, moist flavor. The preparation is meticulous, involving air-drying for hours to achieve a paper-thin, crispy skin. The duck is traditionally roasted in a wood-fired oven and served with thin pancakes, hoisin sauce, and slivered green onions and cucumbers.
ingredients: 3 tbsp Shaoxing rice wine (or dry sherry/another white wine)
½ tsp ground star anise (or 2 whole star anise)
1 large cucumber, thinly sliced or julienned
½ bunch scallions, thinly sliced or julienned
