Serve hot atop a platter of Injera bread (fermented teff flatbread).

drink.description: An Ethiopian honey wine traditionally fermented and lightly spiced (often with gesho). This is a simplified home style.
ingredients: 1/4 tsp wine yeast (or active dry yeast for a rustic ferment)
Optional: a small piece of ginger or a strip of citrus peel
steps: Dissolve honey in water in a sanitized jar.
Add yeast and optional flavorings/raisins.
Cover with an airlock (or a loose lid) and ferment at room temperature until lightly fermented (several days).
Chill, strain if needed, and serve. (Traditional tej uses gesho; this is a simplified approximation.)
Mix all spices thoroughly.
Toast gently in a dry pan for 30–60 seconds to bloom (optional).
Cool completely and store airtight up to 2–3 months.
Melt butter over very low heat. Add onion, garlic, ginger, and spices.
Simmer very gently 20–30 minutes; do not let it brown.
Strain through a fine mesh (or cheesecloth) into a jar.
Cool and refrigerate. Use within 2–3 weeks (or freeze).

FIN.description: Karelian Pies. These iconic rye crust boats filled with savory rice porridge are a protected cultural heritage. They are baked at high heat and traditionally brushed with egg butter.
ingredients: For crust: 2 cups rye flour (240 g)
For crust: 1/2 cup all-purpose flour (65 g)
For crust: 3/4 cup warm water (180 ml), plus as needed
Rice porridge filling (see preliminary step), cooled
To finish: 2 tbsp melted butter (28 g)
To finish: 1/4 cup warm milk (60 ml) (optional for brushing)
Egg butter (see preliminary step), for serving
steps: Make rice porridge filling and cool completely (see preliminary step).
Make dough: mix rye flour, all-purpose flour, and salt. Add water and knead briefly into a firm dough (it should be pliable, not sticky). Rest 10 minutes.
Divide dough into 12 pieces. Roll each into a thin oval (about 1/16 inch).
Spoon a line of cooled rice porridge down the center of each oval and spread, leaving a border.
Crimp edges upward in small pleats to form the classic open boat shape.
Bake on a hot stone or sheet at 500°F/260°C for 10–12 minutes until the crust is firm and lightly browned.
Brush hot pies with melted butter (optionally mixed with warm milk) to soften.
Serve warm with egg butter.

drink.description: Finland’s iconic “long drink” (originally popularized around the 1952 Helsinki Olympics): gin lengthened with grapefruit soda—refreshing and dangerously easy.
ingredients: 6 oz grapefruit soda (180 ml) (or homemade quick grapefruit soda)
1/2 cup grapefruit juice (120 ml) (fresh or bottled)
1 tbsp simple syrup (15 ml) (or 2 tsp sugar)
steps: Stir grapefruit juice and simple syrup (or sugar) until dissolved.
Top with club soda and stir gently.
Use immediately as the “grapefruit soda” component.
Fill a highball with ice.
Pour in gin.
Top with grapefruit soda (or the quick homemade substitute).
Stir gently and garnish with grapefruit if you like.
Serve cold.
Rinse rice briefly. Bring water to a simmer and stir in rice.
Simmer 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until most water is absorbed.
Add milk and salt. Cook on very low heat 35–45 minutes, stirring often, until thick and creamy.
Stir in butter if using. Cool completely before filling pies.
Mash butter with a fork until spreadable.
Fold in chopped eggs and a pinch of salt.
Chill or serve at cool room temperature.

FLK.dish: Roast Mutton with Diddle Dee Jam
FLK.description: A dish born of the rugged South Atlantic landscape. With sheep outnumbering people, mutton is the staple, roasted simply and paired with the unique tartness of Diddle Dee berries, a native heath shrub that cuts through the rich meat.
ingredients: Diddle Dee Jam (or Cranberry/Redcurrant jelly substitute)
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C).
Rub mutton with garlic, rosemary, salt, and pepper.
Roast for 20 mins per lb plus 20 mins extra.
Add potatoes to the roasting pan in the last hour to cook in the fat.
Serve the roast slices with the tart jam to cut through the richness.

drink.description: A common everyday drink on the Falkland Islands is tea (British influence).
steps: Steep tea 3–5 minutes.
Add milk/sugar if desired.

FRA.description: A classic French boiled dinner: beef and marrow bones simmered gently with aromatics, then vegetables added so everything finishes tender. Traditionally served in two courses—first the broth, then the meat and vegetables with mustard, cornichons, and flaky salt.
ingredients: 3 1/2 lb beef for stewing (mix of chuck/shank/brisket), cut into large chunks (1.6 kg)
12 cups cold water (2.8 L), plus more if needed
2 tbsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
2 leeks, cleaned and cut into 3-inch pieces
4 carrots, peeled and cut into 3-inch pieces
1 bouquet garni (parsley stems + thyme + bay leaf, tied)
To serve: Dijon mustard, cornichons, coarse/flake salt; optional toasted baguette
steps: Put beef and bones in a large pot. Cover with cold water (about 12 cups).
Bring just to a simmer over medium heat. As foam rises, skim thoroughly for a clear broth.
Add salt, onion with cloves, garlic, bouquet garni, and peppercorns. Keep at a bare simmer (tiny bubbles), partially covered, 2–2 1/2 hours.
Add leeks, carrots, turnips, and celery. Continue simmering 45–60 minutes, until vegetables are tender and beef is very tender.
Taste broth and adjust salt. Remove bouquet garni and onion.
Serve traditionally in two parts: ladle broth into bowls first, then plate the meat/bones and vegetables. Offer mustard, cornichons, and coarse salt at the table.

drink.description: A French apéritif: crème de cassis topped with Champagne (or Crémant). Lightly fruity, dry, and celebratory.
ingredients: 1/2 oz crème de cassis (blackcurrant liqueur) (15 ml)
steps: Chill a flute or small wine glass.
Pour in crème de cassis.
Top slowly with Champagne.
Give a single gentle stir to combine.
Serve immediately.

Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes.description: A Savoyard gratin of potatoes, reblochon, lardons, and onions. Technique: waxy potatoes hold their shape; the cheese is cut through the middle so it melts into the layers; white wine adds acidity to cut the fat. Served blistering hot from the oven.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) waxy potatoes (e.g. Charlotte, Ratte), unpeeled, scrubbed
1 whole reblochon (about 14 oz / 400 g), rind on, at room temperature
6 oz (170 g) smoked bacon lardons or thick-cut bacon cut into 1/2-inch dice
1/2 cup (120 ml) dry white wine (e.g. Apremont or other Savoie)
2 tbsp (30 g) unsalted butter, for the dish and dotting
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: Mise en place: Boil the whole potatoes in well-salted water until a knife meets slight resistance (about 20–25 min). Drain; when cool enough to handle, peel and slice into 1/4-inch (6 mm) rounds. Do not overwork or they will break.
In a large skillet over medium heat, render the lardons without added fat until golden and some fat has released, 8–10 min. Transfer lardons to a plate; leave about 1 tbsp fat in the pan.
In the same pan, sauté the onions in the bacon fat until soft and lightly golden, 10–12 min. Season with a pinch of salt and pepper.

Butter a 9-by-13-inch (or equivalent) gratin dish. Spread half the potato slices in a layer; season lightly. Scatter half the onions and half the lardons. Repeat with remaining potatoes, onions, and lardons. Drizzle the wine evenly over the top.

Cut the reblochon in half horizontally through the middle (so you have two rounds). Place both halves rind-side up on top of the potatoes, or cut into pieces and distribute. Dot with butter. Bake in the center of a preheated 375°F (190°C) oven 25–35 min until the cheese is melted and bubbling and the top is golden. Rest 5 min; serve hot with cornichons and a green salad.

drink.description: Local white or red from the Alps.
steps: Serve chilled with the tartiflette.

Bourgogne-Franche-Comté.description: Burgundy's iconic braise: beef chuck, lardons, pearl onions, and mushrooms in red wine. Technique: dry the meat for a proper sear; deglaze with wine and reduce; low, steady heat so the collagen breaks down without boiling. The garniture (onions and mushrooms) is cooked separately and added at the end so it keeps texture and color.
ingredients: 2 1/2 lbs (1.1 kg) beef chuck or beef bourguignon cut, cut into 2-inch (5 cm) cubes, patted very dry
6 oz (170 g) slab bacon or thick-cut bacon, cut into lardons (1/4 by 1 inch)
1 bottle (750 ml) Burgundy or other dry, fruity red wine
2 cups (480 ml) beef stock, preferably homemade or low-sodium
1 lb (450 g) pearl onions, blanched 1 min and peeled (or frozen, thawed)
10 oz (280 g) small button or cremini mushrooms, trimmed and quartered if large
1 bouquet garni (3 sprigs thyme, 2 bay leaves, 1 small stalk celery, tied in cheesecloth or leek green)
2 tbsp neutral oil or rendered bacon fat
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: In a large Dutch oven over medium heat, render the lardons until golden; transfer to a plate. Leave fat in the pot (add 1 tbsp oil if needed).
Season the beef with salt and pepper. Sear in the fat in a single layer, in batches—do not crowd—until deeply browned on at least two sides, 4–5 min per batch. Transfer to the plate with the bacon.

Lower heat; add the chopped onion and carrots. Sauté until the onion is soft and starting to color, 6–8 min. Add the garlic and tomato paste; stir 1 min. Sprinkle with the flour; stir 1 min to cook the raw flour taste off.

Deglaze with the wine, scraping up all the browned bits (fond). Add the stock, bouquet garni, and a pinch of salt. Return the beef and bacon; bring to a gentle simmer. Partially cover and braise in a 325°F (165°C) oven (or on the lowest burner setting) 2 1/2–3 hours until the beef is fork-tender. Skim fat from the surface if needed.

While the beef braises: in a skillet, brown the pearl onions in a little butter until golden; add a splash of water and cover to finish softening. In the same pan, sauté the mushrooms in butter until golden. Set aside.

When the beef is tender, remove the bouquet garni. Add the pearl onions and mushrooms; simmer 10–15 min. Taste and adjust seasoning. Serve with mashed potatoes, buttered noodles, or crusty bread; garnish with chopped parsley.

drink.description: Pinot noir from the Côte de Beaune or Nuits.
steps: Serve at room temperature (cellar temp) with the stew.

Bretagne.description: A buckwheat (blé noir) crêpe from Brittany filled with ham, Gruyère, and a runny egg. Technique: pure buckwheat batter with no wheat (gluten-free); resting hydrates the flour; a well-seasoned or nonstick crêpe pan and the right heat give a lacy, crisp-edged galette. The egg is cracked onto the galette and cooked just until the white is set so the yolk stays runny.
ingredients: 1 cup (120 g) buckwheat flour (farine de sarrasin)
Per galette: 1 thin slice jambon blanc or good ham, 1/4 cup (25 g) grated Gruyère, 1 large egg, salt and pepper
steps: In a bowl, whisk the buckwheat flour and salt. Make a well; add the egg and half the water. Whisk from the center outward until smooth, then whisk in the rest of the water. The batter should be the consistency of thin cream. Cover and rest at room temperature at least 1 hour (or up to 12 hours in the fridge; bring back to room temp and thin with 1–2 tbsp water if needed).

Heat a 9- or 10-inch crêpe pan or nonstick skillet over medium heat. When hot, rub with a little butter. Pour about 1/3 cup (80 ml) batter into the center; immediately tilt and swirl so the batter coats the bottom in a thin, even layer. Cook until the top is set and the edges lift easily, 1–2 min.

Place the ham and cheese on one half of the galette. Crack the egg into the center. Fold the opposite half over the filling (or fold the two sides in toward the center to leave the egg visible). Add a small knob of butter to the pan around the galette.

Cook until the egg white is set and the cheese has melted, 2–3 min. The yolk should remain runny. Season with salt and pepper. Slide onto a plate and serve immediately. Repeat with remaining batter and fillings. Serve with Breton cider in a bolée.

drink.description: Dry or demi-sec apple cider from Brittany.
steps: Serve cold in a bowl-shaped cup (bolée).

Centre-Val de Loire.description: Upside-down caramelized apple tart from the Loire. Technique: dry caramel (or butter-and-sugar) in the pan; apples are arranged cut-side up in a tight spiral so they hold their shape; the pastry is baked on top, then the tart is inverted in one confident flip so the apples sit on a crisp, buttery base. Rest briefly before inverting so the caramel sets slightly and does not run off.
ingredients: 6–8 firm, tart apples (e.g. Granny Smith or Reine des Reinettes), peeled, cored, and cut into quarters (or sixths if large)
1 sheet all-butter puff pastry, thawed if frozen, rolled to a round 1 inch larger than your pan
1/2 cup (1 stick / 115 g) unsalted butter, cut into pieces
steps: Use a 10-inch (25 cm) ovenproof skillet (stainless or cast iron). Melt the butter in the pan over medium heat; add the sugar and salt. Stir until the sugar dissolves, then cook without stirring until the mixture turns a deep amber caramel (watch carefully—it can burn quickly). Remove from heat.

Arrange the apple quarters in the pan in a tight spiral, rounded side down, packing them so they hold together when inverted. Fill any gaps with smaller pieces. Return the pan to medium-low heat and cook 15–25 min so the apples release juice and the caramel thickens. The apples should be tender but not mushy. Remove from heat.

Lay the pastry over the apples and tuck the edges down between the apples and the pan. Pierce the pastry in a few places with a knife so steam can escape. Bake in a preheated 400°F (200°C) oven until the pastry is golden and cooked through, 20–28 min.

Let rest 5–10 min (so the caramel is less runny). Place a large serving plate over the pan. Using oven mitts, firmly hold the plate and pan together and invert in one motion. Lift the pan off. If any apples stick, rearrange them. Serve warm with crème fraîche or vanilla ice cream.

Corse.description: A light, flourless Corsican cheesecake made with brocciu or ricotta, eggs, and lemon. Technique: no crust—the mixture is blended until smooth, poured into a buttered mold, and baked until set with a slight wobble in the center. The eggs provide structure; the lemon zest is essential. Traditionally served at room temperature, often for Easter.
ingredients: 2 cups (500 g) brocciu (Corsican fresh cheese) or whole-milk ricotta, drained if watery
Zest of 2 untreated lemons, finely grated
1 tsp vanilla extract or 1/2 tsp lemon juice
Butter and flour for the pan (or use a nonstick 9-inch round pan, buttered)
steps: If using ricotta, drain in a sieve 15–30 min if it is wet; press gently. Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan and dust with flour, or use a springform and butter it well.

In a large bowl, beat the brocciu or ricotta with a whisk or wooden spoon until smooth and free of lumps. Add the eggs one at a time, mixing well after each. Stir in the sugar, lemon zest, and vanilla until fully combined. The mixture should be homogeneous and slightly fluid.

Pour the batter into the prepared pan and smooth the top. Bake on the middle rack 35–45 min until the edges are golden and the center is set with a slight jiggle (it will firm up as it cools). Do not overbake or the texture will be dry.
Cool in the pan on a rack 15–20 min, then unmold if using a regular pan. Cool completely. Serve at room temperature, optionally with a dusting of powdered sugar or a drizzle of honey.

Grand Est.description: Alsatian sauerkraut braised with juniper, white wine, and an array of pork and sausages. Technique: rinse the sauerkraut to control salt and soften flavor; layer with aromatics and fat (bacon, duck fat, or lard); slow braise so the kraut becomes tender and infused. Meats are nestled in and added according to cooking time—long-cook cuts first, sausages last so they do not burst.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) raw sauerkraut (choucroute crue), rinsed in cold water and squeezed dry in batches
1 lb (450 g) smoked bacon (piece, e.g. poitrine fumée), rind scored
1 lb (450 g) pork shoulder or smoked pork knuckle (jarret)
4–6 Strasbourg-style or frankfurter sausages (saucisses de Strasbourg)
1 1/2 cups (360 ml) dry Alsace white wine (Riesling or Sylvaner)
1 medium onion, peeled and stuck with 2 cloves
2 tbsp duck fat or lard (optional but traditional)
Waxy potatoes (e.g. Charlotte), boiled in salted water, to serve
steps: Rinse the sauerkraut in a colander under cold water; squeeze out excess liquid in handfuls. This reduces salt and softens the flavor. Set aside.

In a large heavy pot (or cocotte), melt the duck fat if using. Spread half the sauerkraut in the bottom. Scatter half the juniper berries, the onion with cloves, bay leaves, and peppercorns. Lay the bacon and pork shoulder or knuckle on top. Cover with the remaining sauerkraut. Pour the wine and add enough water or stock to come about halfway up the kraut (do not drown it). Bring to a gentle simmer.

Cover with a tight lid or parchment and a lid. Simmer on low heat (or in a 325°F / 165°C oven) 2–2 1/2 hours until the sauerkraut is tender and the pork is cooked. Check liquid occasionally; add a little water if the bottom is dry.

Add the sausages, pushing them into the sauerkraut. Simmer 15–20 min until the sausages are heated through. Remove the onion and bay leaves. Slice the bacon and pork; arrange the meats on a platter with the sauerkraut and boiled potatoes. Serve with strong Dijon mustard and the same Alsace wine, chilled.

drink.description: Dry Alsace white.
steps: Serve chilled with choucroute.

Hauts-de-France.description: Flemish beef and onion stew braised in brown beer, with a touch of brown sugar and vinegar. Technique: beef is seared in batches for fond; onions are cooked slowly until deeply golden; the pain à la moutarde (bread spread with Dijon) is laid on top to thicken and flavor the sauce. Long, gentle simmer so the meat is tender and the sauce is rich and glossy.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) beef chuck, cut into 1 1/2-inch (4 cm) cubes, patted dry
3 large yellow onions, halved and sliced 1/4 inch thick
2 (12 oz / 355 ml) bottles brown ale or Flanders red (e.g. Belgian dubbel)
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: In a Dutch oven over medium-high heat, heat 1 tbsp oil. Season the beef with salt and pepper. Sear in a single layer in batches until well browned on at least two sides, 4–5 min per batch. Transfer to a plate. Do not crowd the pan or the meat will steam.
Lower the heat to medium. Add the remaining oil and the onions. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the onions are soft and deeply golden, 20–25 min. This builds sweetness and depth.

Return the beef and any juices to the pot. Add the beer, brown sugar, vinegar, thyme, and bay leaves. Bring to a simmer. Spread one side of each bread slice with a thin layer of Dijon and place mustard-side down on top of the stew (the bread will dissolve and thicken the sauce). Partially cover and simmer on low 2–2 1/2 hours until the beef is fork-tender. Remove the thyme and bay leaves; discard any remaining bread. Taste and adjust salt and pepper. Serve with frites, boiled potatoes, or crusty bread.

Île-de-France.description: Parisian ham-and-cheese sandwich gratinéed with béchamel and Gruyère. Technique: a proper béchamel (roux then milk, no lumps) with nutmeg; the sandwich is assembled, coated with béchamel and cheese, then baked until the sauce is bubbling and the top is golden. For Croque-Madame, add a fried egg on top.
ingredients: 8 slices pain de mie or good white sandwich bread, about 1/2 inch thick
4 thin slices jambon blanc or good cooked ham
steps: Béchamel: In a small saucepan over medium heat, melt the butter. Add the flour and stir with a wooden spoon for 1–2 min (do not let it color). Off the heat, add the warm milk in a steady stream while whisking to avoid lumps. Return to medium heat and bring to a gentle simmer; cook, stirring, until thickened, 2–3 min. Season with nutmeg, salt, and white pepper. Off the heat, stir in 1/4 cup (25 g) of the Gruyère until melted. Set aside; if it thickens too much, thin with a drop of milk.

Assemble: Lay 4 slices of bread on a baking sheet. Top each with 1 slice of ham and a good sprinkle of Gruyère. Cover with the remaining bread slices. Spread the béchamel evenly over the tops (and optionally the sides), then sprinkle with the remaining Gruyère.

Bake in a preheated 425°F (220°C) oven 10–14 min until the béchamel is bubbling and the cheese on top is golden and spotted brown. Rest 1–2 min. Serve hot, with a green salad. Optional: top each with a fried egg for Croque-Madame.

Normandie.description: Mussels steamed in dry cider with cream, shallots, and apple—a taste of the Norman coast. Technique: sweat the aromatics in butter without browning; add cider and cream, then the mussels; cover and steam over high heat so they open quickly and stay tender. Discard any that do not open. The sauce is finished with parsley and a knob of butter (monter au beurre) for shine.
ingredients: 4 lbs (1.8 kg) mussels, scrubbed and debearded (pull or cut the beard), rinsed in cold water
1/2 cup (120 ml) crème fraîche or heavy cream
1 crisp apple (e.g. Granny Smith or Reinette), peeled, cored, and cut into small dice
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: Check mussels: discard any that are broken or that do not close when tapped. Rinse and drain. Set aside.

In a large pot with a tight-fitting lid (wide and deep enough to hold the mussels), melt 2 tbsp butter over medium heat. Add the shallots and sweat until soft and translucent, 2–3 min—do not brown. Add the apple and cook 1 min. Pour in the cider and bring to a boil; let reduce 1–2 min. Add the crème fraîche, stir, and bring back to a simmer.

Add the mussels all at once and cover. Increase heat to high and steam 4–6 min, shaking the pot once or twice, until the mussels have opened. Remove from heat. Discard any mussels that did not open. Stir in the remaining 1 tbsp butter and the parsley. Taste the sauce and season with salt and pepper (cider may be salty). Serve immediately in large bowls with the sauce, with frites or crusty bread and Norman cider.

drink.description: Norman apple cider.
steps: Serve cold.

Nouvelle-Aquitaine.description: Duck leg preserved and slow-cooked in its own fat (confit), then crisped in a pan for serving—a Gascon and Périgord classic. Technique: dry-salting draws moisture and seasons the meat; cooking in fat at a low temperature (around 85–90°C) renders the connective tissue without boiling. Stored under fat, confit keeps for weeks. To serve, the skin is crisped in a hot pan, flesh-side briefly, then skin-side until golden.
ingredients: 4 duck legs (cuisses de canard), whole with skin
1 1/2–2 lbs (700–900 g) duck fat, or enough to submerge the legs completely
steps: Salt the duck legs on both sides with the sea salt; add the peppercorns and optional bay. Place in a dish, cover, and refrigerate 12–24 hours. This draws out moisture and seasons the meat.

Rinse the legs and pat very dry. Preheat the oven to 285°F (140°C). In a heavy ovenproof pot just large enough to hold the legs in one layer, melt the duck fat. Add the garlic and thyme. Submerge the duck legs completely in the fat (they must be covered). Bring to a very gentle simmer on the stovetop, then transfer, uncovered, to the oven. Cook 2–2 1/2 hours until the meat is tender and pulls easily from the bone. The fat should never boil—only gentle bubbles.

To store: cool the legs in the fat, then transfer to a container and cover completely with the strained fat. Refrigerate; they keep for weeks. To serve: remove the legs from the fat and scrape off excess fat. In a cold skillet, place the legs skin-side down. Turn heat to medium; cook 8–12 min until the skin is golden and crisp. Flip and warm the flesh side 1–2 min. Serve with potatoes sautéed in duck fat, or a simple green salad.

Occitanie.description: Slow-cooked white beans with duck confit, Toulouse sausage, and pork—the soul of Languedoc. Technique: beans are cooked until tender and their cooking liquid becomes the base; meats are layered with the beans in a deep vessel; a breadcrumb crust forms on top and is deliberately broken and pushed back in (casser la croûte) several times so it thickens and flavors the whole dish. Long, gentle baking melds everything.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) dried Tarbais or cannellini beans, soaked overnight in cold water, drained
4 duck confit legs (from your own confit or store-bought)
1 lb (450 g) Toulouse sausage or other garlic pork sausage, pricked
8 oz (225 g) pork shoulder or fresh pork belly, cut into 1 1/2-inch cubes
1 (14 oz / 400 g) can whole tomatoes, crushed by hand, with juice
1 bouquet garni (thyme, bay leaf, parsley stems)
2 tbsp duck fat or olive oil
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: Put the soaked beans in a large pot with the quartered onion, halved carrot, smashed garlic, and bouquet garni. Cover with cold water by 2 inches. Bring to a simmer and cook until the beans are tender but not mushy, 1–1 1/2 hours (timing depends on the bean). Add salt in the last 15 min. Drain, reserving the cooking liquid; remove the bouquet garni and aromatics. You need about 4–5 cups of bean liquid.

In a skillet, brown the sausage and pork cubes in duck fat; set aside. In a large cassole or Dutch oven, build layers: a third of the beans, half the chopped onion and diced carrot, half the minced garlic, half the tomatoes, the pork cubes, then more beans, the sausages (whole or halved), and the duck confit. Top with the remaining beans. Add enough reserved bean liquid to come just to the top of the beans. Bring to a simmer on the stovetop.

Sprinkle the top evenly with breadcrumbs. Bake uncovered at 300°F (150°C) for 2–3 hours. Every 30–45 min, break the crust (casser la croûte) with a spoon and push it into the cassoulet; add a little bean liquid if it looks dry. The final result should be creamy beans with a golden, broken crust. Rest 15 min; serve from the pot with a green salad and red wine.

Pays de la Loire.description: Shredded pork (or goose) slow-cooked in fat and its own juices, then potted—a classic of Le Mans and the Loire. Technique: equal parts shoulder and belly (or mostly shoulder with some belly for fat); very low heat so the meat confits in fat and water without frying; shredding while still warm so the fat distributes; pressing into jars and sealing with a thin layer of fat for keeping. Served cold on bread with cornichons.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) pork shoulder, cut into 2-inch cubes
1/2 lb (225 g) pork belly, cut into 2-inch pieces (rind removed)
2–3 cups (480–720 ml) water, or enough to just cover the meat
steps: Put the pork shoulder and belly in a heavy pot (Dutch oven or cocotte). Add the salt, peppercorns, thyme, and bay leaves. Pour in enough water to just cover the meat. Bring to a very gentle simmer over low heat—the surface should barely move. Do not boil.

Partially cover and cook 4–5 hours, checking occasionally. The meat should be falling apart and the liquid mostly reduced to a fatty, gelatinous layer. Add a splash of water if the bottom threatens to dry before the meat is tender.

Remove the thyme and bay leaves. Using two forks or your hands, shred the meat in the pot, mixing it with the fat and juices until you have a coarse, spreadable consistency. Taste and adjust salt. Pack the rillettes into clean jars, pressing down to remove air pockets. Smooth the top and, if you have extra fat, pour a thin layer over the surface. Cool to room temperature, then refrigerate. The fat layer helps preserve. Serve cold, spread on toasted bread or baguette with cornichons and optionally a little Dijon.

Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur.description: Provençal vegetable stew: eggplant, zucchini, bell peppers, and tomatoes, each given attention so they keep their character. Traditional technique: onions and garlic form the base; vegetables are often cooked separately or in sequence (sautéing eggplant and zucchini so they take color, then peppers, then tomatoes) so they do not turn to mush. Herbes de Provence and basil; serve warm or at room temperature with bread.
ingredients: 1 large eggplant (about 1 lb), cut into 1-inch chunks, salted 20 min and patted dry
2 bell peppers (red and/or yellow), cored and cut into 1-inch pieces
4–5 ripe tomatoes, peeled, seeded, and chopped (or 1 [14 oz] can whole tomatoes, crushed)
2 sprigs thyme, 1 bay leaf, 3–4 tbsp torn basil
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: If salting the eggplant: toss chunks with 1 tsp salt, let drain in a colander 20 min, then pat dry. This reduces bitterness and excess moisture.
In a large Dutch oven or heavy pot, heat 2 tbsp olive oil over medium heat. Sauté the onions until soft and golden, 8–10 min. Add the garlic and cook 1 min. Transfer to a bowl.

In the same pot, add 2 tbsp oil and sauté the eggplant until golden on several sides, 8–10 min. Transfer to the bowl. Add 1 tbsp oil and sauté the zucchini until lightly colored, 5–6 min; add to the bowl. Sauté the peppers 5–6 min until softened; add to the bowl.

Return the onions to the pot. Add the tomatoes, thyme, and bay leaf. Bring to a simmer and cook 10 min. Add the eggplant, zucchini, and peppers. Stir gently, reduce the heat to low, and simmer uncovered 30–45 min, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables are tender and the sauce has thickened. Remove the thyme and bay leaf. Stir in the basil; season with salt and pepper. Drizzle with a little olive oil. Serve warm or at room temperature with crusty bread, as a side to grilled meat or fish, or with rice or pasta.

drink.description: Anise apéritif of the south.
steps: Pour pastis over ice; add water. Serve with the ratatouille or as an apéro.

FRO.description: Salt cod mashed with potatoes and butter, gratinated in the oven.
steps: Poach cod. Flake it.
Mash with potatoes, onion, and milk.
Bake at 400°F until golden.

drink.description: Beer is commonly consumed in the Faroe Islands.
steps: Serve chilled and pour into a glass.

GBR.description: The dish that fueled the Industrial Revolution. Fresh cod or haddock is encased in a crispy, golden beer batter and served with thick-cut chips. It is a national institution best eaten with plenty of salt and malt vinegar.
ingredients: 1 cup All-purpose Flour (plus extra for dredging)
steps: Cut potatoes into thick chips (fries). Soak in cold water for 30 mins. Drain and dry thoroughly.
Heat oil to 320°F (160°C). Blanch chips for 3-4 mins (do not brown). Remove and cool.
Batter: Whisk flour, baking powder, and cold beer until smooth (consistency of heavy cream).
Increase oil heat to 375°F (190°C).
Season fish. Dredge in flour, dip in batter, and carefully lower into hot oil.
Fry fish for 4-5 mins until golden and crisp. Drain.
Fry chips again at 375°F until golden brown.
Serve immediately with salt and plenty of malt vinegar.

drink.description: A classic British summer drink: Pimm’s No. 1 lengthened with lemonade and packed with fresh garnishes.
ingredients: Garnish: cucumber slices, orange slice, strawberries, mint (use what you have)
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice.
Add Pimm’s.
Top with lemonade and stir gently.
Add lots of garnishes (cucumber + mint is the core).
Serve immediately.

GEO.description: The legendary cheese boat. A soft dough gondola filled with molten cheese, topped with a raw egg yolk and butter.
steps: Shape dough into a boat.
Fill with cheese.
Bake at 450°F for 15 mins.
Top with raw egg yolk and butter immediately upon serving.

drink.description: Georgia’s ancient wine culture is closely tied to qvevri winemaking traditions.
steps: Serve at appropriate temperature.

GGY.description: A rich, slow-cooked bean stew with pork trotter.
steps: Combine all ingredients in a pot.
Cover with water.
Bake at 300°F for 6-8 hours until creamy.

drink.description: Guernsey’s drink culture commonly includes local beer and cider.
steps: Serve chilled and pour into a glass.

GIB.description: A savory baked pancake made from chickpea flour and olive oil.
steps: Whisk ingredients into thin batter. Rest 1 hour.
Pour into hot oiled pan.
Bake at 425°F for 45-60 mins.

drink.description: A classic G&T reflecting Gibraltar’s British ties and Mediterranean climate.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add gin and top with tonic.
Garnish with lime.

GLP.description: A delicious collision of French and Indian cultures. Created by indentured laborers from India in the 19th century, this curry uses 'Colombo powder'—a Caribbean evolution of curry powder with toasted rice and mustard seeds—to transform pork into a fragrant yellow stew.
steps: Marinate pork with lime, garlic, and 1 tbsp Colombo powder for 1 hour.
Brown pork in oil. Add onion and garlic.
Add water to cover, remaining Colombo powder, and thyme. Simmer 30 mins.
Add vegetables and whole scotch bonnet (for flavor, not heat).
Simmer until sauce thickens and veggies are soft.
Serve with rice.

drink.description: A French-Caribbean classic from rum agricole islands: rum, lime coin, and sugar—no juice, just perfume.
ingredients: 1 lime coin (a small round slice, lightly squeezed)
1 tsp cane sugar or 1 sugar cube
steps: Add sugar and the lime coin to a small glass.
Pour in rhum agricole and give it a brief stir (some prefer no ice).
Sip slowly.
Mix all spices thoroughly.
Store airtight up to 2–3 months.

GRC.description: A culinary monument of the Mediterranean. Layers of fried eggplant and potatoes are bound by a cinnamon-spiced meat sauce and crowned with a thick, velvety béchamel layer that puffs up golden brown in the oven.
ingredients: Béchamel: 4 tbsp Butter, 4 tbsp Flour, 3 cups Milk, Nutmeg, 2 Egg yolks
steps: Salt eggplant slices and let drain for 30 mins. Rinse and pat dry. Fry in oil until golden. Set aside.
Meat Sauce: Sauté onion and meat. Add wine, tomato puree, cinnamon, salt, and pepper. Simmer until thick.
Béchamel: Melt butter, whisk in flour. Gradually add milk, whisking constantly until thick. Remove from heat, stir in cheese, nutmeg, and egg yolks.
Assemble: Layer half the eggplant in a baking dish. Top with meat sauce. Top with remaining eggplant.
Pour the béchamel sauce over the top. Sprinkle with more cheese.
Bake at 350°F (180°C) for 45-50 minutes until golden and bubbly. Let stand 15 mins before cutting.

drink.description: The iconic Greek iced coffee: instant coffee shaken into a thick foam, then poured over ice with water (and optionally milk).
ingredients: 2 tbsp cold water (30 ml) (to foam the coffee)
1/2 cup cold water (120 ml), plus more to taste
Optional: 2–4 tbsp milk or evaporated milk (30–60 ml)
steps: In a shaker (or jar), combine instant coffee, sugar, and 2 tbsp water.
Shake hard 20–30 seconds until thick and foamy.
Fill a tall glass with ice and spoon in the foam.
Top with cold water (and milk if using).
Stir gently and drink with a straw.

East Macedonia and Thrace.description: An ancient Thracian preservation technique born of necessity: cubes of lamb and goat are slow-braised for hours in their own rendered fat with cumin, paprika, and black pepper until meltingly tender, then packed into earthenware crocks where the fat seals the meat for months. In winter, a chunk is dug out of the crock and reheated in a skillet until the fat sizzles and the meat crisps at the edges. Served with crusty village bread, raw onion, and pickled peppers—shepherd's sustenance from the Rhodope mountains.
ingredients: 3 lbs boneless lamb shoulder, cut into 1-inch cubes (1.4 kg)
1 lb lamb fat or suet, diced (450 g)
For serving: crusty bread, raw red onion rings, pickled hot peppers
steps: In a heavy-bottomed Dutch oven or deep cast-iron pot, combine the diced lamb fat and 1 cup water. Cook over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until the fat has fully rendered and the water has evaporated—about 30 minutes. The fat should be clear and liquid.
Season the lamb cubes with cumin, paprika, pepper, allspice, and salt. Toss to coat evenly.
Add the seasoned lamb to the rendered fat. The meat should be mostly submerged. Bring to a gentle simmer.
Reduce heat to the lowest setting, cover, and cook 3–4 hours, stirring occasionally, until the lamb is butter-tender and falling apart. The meat is essentially confiting in its own fat.
To serve immediately: spoon the kavourma with some of its fat into a hot skillet. Fry until the edges crisp and sizzle. Serve on crusty bread with raw onion rings and pickled peppers.

To preserve (traditional method): pack the hot kavourma into sterilized clay or glass jars, ensuring the fat covers the meat completely. Seal and store in a cool place. It keeps for months—dig out portions as needed and reheat in a skillet.

drink.description: The firewater of northern Greece: a clear, potent grape-marc spirit distilled in copper stills across Thrace and Macedonia. Unlike ouzo, tsipouro is uncut—no anise (or with anise, depending on the village). Served neat in small glasses alongside meze, it is the drink of every Thracian evening gathering. The ritual is: one sip tsipouro, one bite meze—never one without the other.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) tsipouro (without anise, Thracian style), chilled
Small glass of cold water on the side
Meze plate: olives, feta, pickled peppers
steps: Chill the tsipouro in the refrigerator (never the freezer—it's already 40–45% ABV).
Pour into a small shot glass or tumbler. Serve alongside a glass of cold water and a plate of meze.
Sip slowly, alternating with bites of meze and sips of water. The Greeks call this 'tsimpisi kai meze'—a nip and a bite.

Central Macedonia.description: Thessaloniki's legendary street pastry: impossibly thin, hand-stretched filo sheets layered around a thick, vanilla-scented semolina custard cream (krema), baked until shatteringly crisp and golden, then cut into pieces and showered with powdered sugar and cinnamon. Bougatsa arrived with the Asia Minor refugees in 1923 and became Thessaloniki's soul food. The bougatsadiko (bougatsa shop) is a Thessalonikian institution—you queue at dawn and eat it standing, the cream still warm.
ingredients: 1 lb handmade or store-bought filo dough (450 g)
For the cream: 4 cups whole milk (960 ml), 3/4 cup fine semolina (120 g), 3/4 cup sugar (150 g), 3 large eggs, 1 tsp vanilla extract, 2 tbsp unsalted butter, pinch of salt
1/2 cup melted unsalted butter for brushing filo (115 g)
Powdered sugar and ground cinnamon for serving
steps: Make the cream: Heat the milk in a heavy saucepan until steaming. In a bowl, whisk the eggs with the sugar until pale, then whisk in the semolina. Slowly pour the hot milk into the egg mixture, whisking constantly to temper.

Return the mixture to the saucepan over medium heat. Stir constantly with a wooden spoon until the cream thickens dramatically—it should be very thick, like pastry cream that holds its shape. This takes 5–8 minutes. Remove from heat, stir in butter, vanilla, and salt. Press plastic wrap directly onto the surface and cool to lukewarm.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Butter a large baking pan. Layer 6–7 sheets of filo on the bottom, brushing each generously with melted butter and letting the edges drape over the sides.
Spread the lukewarm cream evenly over the filo in a thick layer. Fold the overhanging filo edges inward over the cream.
Layer another 5–6 sheets of filo on top, buttering each one. Tuck the edges neatly under. Brush the top generously with butter. Score the top lightly into portions with a sharp knife.
Bake 35–40 minutes until deep golden and crisp. Let cool 10 minutes, then cut into pieces. Dust generously with powdered sugar and a whisper of cinnamon. Serve warm.

drink.description: The ritual that defines Greek mornings: finely ground coffee simmered in a briki (small copper pot) with sugar and water, producing a thick, aromatic brew with kaimaki (crema foam) on top. You specify your sweetness: sketos (no sugar), metrios (medium), or glykos (sweet). The grounds settle in the cup—never stir, and never drink the last sip. Reading the grounds afterward (kafemandeia) is optional but traditional.
ingredients: 1 heaping tsp very finely ground Greek/Turkish coffee (about 7 g)
1 demitasse cup cold water (about 2.5 oz / 75 ml)
1 tsp sugar (for metrios; 2 tsp for glykos; none for sketos)
steps: In a briki (small, long-handled copper pot), combine the coffee, sugar, and cold water. Stir once to mix.
Place over low heat. Do not stir again. Watch carefully—the coffee will slowly begin to foam.
As the foam (kaimaki) rises toward the rim, remove from heat immediately. Do not let it boil over—the kaimaki is sacred.

Pour slowly into a demitasse cup, tilting the briki to preserve the foam layer on top. Serve with a glass of cold water and a loukoumi (Turkish delight). Let the grounds settle 1 minute before sipping.

West Macedonia.description: A festive spit-roast from the mountains of Western Macedonia: large chunks of pork shoulder and belly threaded on a spit, rubbed with Kozani saffron (krokos), oregano, garlic, and lemon, then slow-turned over charcoal for hours until the exterior is mahogany-crisp and the interior is succulent and perfumed with the world's most expensive spice. Kozani, near Kastoria, is the only saffron-producing region in Greece and one of the few in the world.
ingredients: 4 lbs boneless pork shoulder and belly, mixed, cut into 2-inch chunks (1.8 kg)
1/2 tsp Kozani saffron threads (krokos), steeped in 2 tbsp warm water
4 garlic cloves, minced to a paste
steps: In a large bowl, combine the saffron with its soaking water, garlic paste, oregano, lemon juice, olive oil, salt, pepper, and paprika. Mix into a marinade. Add the pork chunks and toss to coat thoroughly. Marinate in the refrigerator at least 4 hours, ideally overnight.
Thread the marinated pork onto a spit or heavy metal skewers, alternating leaner shoulder with fattier belly pieces. Pack tightly so the meat bastes itself as it rotates.
Prepare a charcoal fire and let it burn down to glowing embers. Mount the spit about 12 inches above the coals. If using skewers on a grill, cook over indirect medium heat.

Roast slowly, turning constantly, for 2–3 hours (spit) or 1.5–2 hours (grill/oven at 350°F/175°C), basting occasionally with any remaining marinade mixed with olive oil. The exterior should be deeply caramelized and crisp; the interior should be moist and golden from the saffron.
Rest 10 minutes. Slide the meat off the spit, cut into chunks, and serve on a platter with lemon wedges, village bread, and a tomato-onion salad dressed with oregano.

drink.dish: Tsai tou Vounou me Krokos (Mountain Tea with Saffron)
drink.description: A warming herbal infusion unique to Western Macedonia: wild mountain tea (sideritis/ironwort) gathered from the slopes of Mount Vermion, steeped with Kozani saffron threads and sweetened with local thyme honey. This is the tisane of Greek mountain villages, drunk daily for health—sideritis is revered for its anti-inflammatory and immune-boosting properties.
ingredients: 2–3 stalks dried sideritis (Greek mountain tea / tsai tou vounou)
steps: Place the dried sideritis stalks and saffron threads in a small pot.
Add the boiling water. Simmer gently for 8–10 minutes—do not boil hard, or the delicate flavor turns bitter.
Strain into cups. Stir in honey to taste.
Drink hot on a cold mountain evening. In Kozani, this tea is believed to cure everything from colds to heartbreak.

Thessaly.description: The fiery signature dish of the Pelion peninsula: chunks of rustic Pelion sausage (loukaniko horiatiko), loaded with orange peel, fennel, and leek, are seared then braised with roasted sweet peppers, hot peppers, tomato, and a splash of tsipouro. The Pelion villages cling to forested mountainsides above the Aegean, and spetzofai is the dish that warms every taverna table in autumn. The secret is the quality of the sausage—coarsely ground pork with assertive spicing.
ingredients: 1.5 lbs Greek country sausage (loukaniko horiatiko or Italian sausage as substitute), cut into 2-inch pieces (680 g)
3 bell peppers (red, green, yellow), seeded, cut into thick strips
2 long mild peppers (horn peppers or Anaheim), sliced
1 hot green pepper (or 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes)
1 can (14 oz) crushed tomatoes or 4 ripe tomatoes, grated
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in a wide, heavy skillet or clay pot over medium-high heat. Brown the sausage pieces on all sides until caramelized, about 5 minutes. Remove and set aside.
Add the remaining olive oil to the same pan. Add all the pepper strips and cook, tossing occasionally, 8–10 minutes until softened and slightly charred at the edges.
Add garlic and hot pepper, cook 1 minute. Pour in the tsipouro—it will sizzle and deglaze the pan. Let it evaporate.
Add the crushed tomatoes, oregano, salt, and pepper. Stir, bring to a simmer.
Return the sausages to the pan, nestling them among the peppers. Reduce heat and simmer, uncovered, 20–25 minutes until the sauce is thick and the peppers are silky.
Serve straight from the pan with thick slices of crusty village bread to soak up the spicy, oily sauce. This is taverna food—rustic, generous, unapologetic.

drink.description: The legendary tsipouro of Tyrnavos, Thessaly's distilling capital: a grape-marc spirit distilled in small copper pot stills, clear as water, with an anise-perfumed version and a 'without anise' version for purists. Every autumn after the grape harvest, the tsipouro kazania (distilleries) fire up, and the scent of distillation fills the Thessalian plain. Always served with meze—never alone.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Tsipouro Tyrnavou (with or without anise), chilled
Splash of cold water (to release the anise oils, if using the anise version)
Meze: olives, feta, grilled octopus, tomato wedges
steps: Pour the tsipouro into a small glass. If drinking the anise version, add a small splash of cold water—the liquid will turn milky-white (the louche effect), releasing the anise oils.
Serve alongside meze. The Thessalian way: one sip tsipouro, one bite of meze, one laugh with friends.
Repeat until the plate is empty and the bottle needs replacing.

Epirus.description: The legendary meat pie of Ioannina: layers of hand-stretched filo enclose a slow-braised filling of lamb and goat in tomato, onion, and rice, seasoned with cinnamon and mint. Epirus is the kingdom of Greek pies—every village, every grandmother has her pita. But kreatopita is the queen: a festive pie made for holidays and name days, baked in a wood-fired oven until the filo shatters like glass and the filling steams fragrant. The Epirote method of hand-stretching filo on a floured tablecloth is the ancestor of all phyllo traditions.
ingredients: For the filling: 2 lbs boneless lamb shoulder, cut into small dice (900 g), 1 large onion (diced), 2 garlic cloves, 1/2 cup tomato puree (120 ml), 1/4 cup short-grain rice, 1/4 cup olive oil (60 ml), 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 2 tbsp fresh mint (chopped), salt, pepper
For the filo: 1 lb store-bought or handmade filo (450 g), 1/2 cup melted butter mixed with 1/4 cup olive oil for brushing
1 egg yolk + 1 tbsp milk for egg wash
steps: Make the filling: Heat olive oil in a heavy pot. Brown the diced lamb in batches until deeply colored. Add onion and garlic, cook until softened.

Add tomato puree, cinnamon, salt, and pepper. Add 1 cup water. Simmer, covered, for 1.5 hours until the lamb is very tender and the liquid is mostly absorbed. Stir in the rice and mint. Cook 10 more minutes until the rice is just tender. The filling should be moist but not soupy. Cool.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Brush a deep baking pan with butter-oil. Layer 7–8 sheets of filo on the bottom, brushing each with the butter-oil mixture, letting edges drape over the sides.
Spread the cooled lamb filling evenly over the filo.
Fold overhanging edges inward. Layer 6–7 more sheets on top, brushing each. Tuck edges under neatly. Brush the top with egg wash. Score the top into diamond or square portions with a sharp knife.
Bake 40–45 minutes until deep golden and crisp. Let rest 15 minutes before cutting. The filo should crackle; the filling should be fragrant with cinnamon and mint.

drink.description: Tsipouro from the stone villages of Zagori in the Pindus mountains: small-batch, artisanal, distilled from the Debina grape that grows only in Epirus. Zagorochoria tsipouro is clean, floral, and slightly herbaceous—served in the stone-built guesthouses where hikers and pilgrims have warmed themselves for centuries.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Zagorochoria tsipouro (without anise), chilled
Meze: local pita pieces, grilled halloumi, walnuts, honey
steps: Pour into a small glass, chilled but not ice-cold.
Sip between bites of warm pita dipped in honey and walnuts—the classic Epirote meze.
In Zagori, tsipouro is served by the fireplace with the windows open to the Vikos Gorge.

Ionian Islands.description: Corfu's Sunday masterpiece: a whole rooster (or beef) braised for hours in a rich tomato sauce perfumed with cinnamon, cloves, allspice, and bay—the Venetian-Greek spice cabinet—then served over thick bucatini or penne. Pastitsada reveals 400 years of Venetian rule over Corfu: the slow braise, the sweet spices, the pasta. Every Corfiot family has their grandmother's version, debated fiercely at every taverna. The sauce must be dark red, thick enough to coat the pasta, and deeply aromatic.
ingredients: 1 whole rooster or chicken (about 4 lbs / 1.8 kg), cut into 8 pieces (or 3 lbs beef chuck, cubed)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 lb thick bucatini or penne (450 g)
Grated kefalotyri or Pecorino Romano for serving
steps: Season the rooster pieces with salt and pepper. Heat olive oil in a large Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Brown the pieces deeply on all sides, about 10 minutes. Remove and set aside.
Reduce heat to medium. Add onions and cook until deeply golden and caramelized, 12–15 minutes. Add garlic, cook 1 minute.
Pour in the red wine, scraping up all the fond. Let it reduce by half.
Add crushed tomatoes, tomato paste, cinnamon stick, ground cinnamon, cloves, allspice, bay leaves, and nutmeg. Stir well. Return the rooster to the pot. The sauce should nearly cover the meat.

Bring to a gentle simmer, cover, and cook over very low heat for 2–2.5 hours (for rooster) or 1.5 hours (for chicken/beef), until the meat is falling-off-the-bone tender. Stir occasionally. Remove whole spices.
Cook the bucatini in salted water until al dente. Drain. Toss with generous ladlefuls of the sauce. Plate the pasta, place the braised meat alongside, and shower with grated kefalotyri.

drink.description: A sparkling, non-alcoholic ginger drink unique to Corfu—a legacy of the British protectorate (1815–1864). Fresh ginger root, lemon, and sugar are fermented briefly with yeast to produce a fizzy, spicy-sweet drink served cold from the bottle. Tsitsibira is sold at Corfu's cricket matches (yes, another British legacy) and at every local festival. It is the taste of Corfiot summers.
ingredients: 4 oz fresh ginger root, peeled and finely grated (110 g)
steps: Boil 4 cups of water. Add the grated ginger and sugar. Stir until sugar dissolves. Simmer 5 minutes. Remove from heat and add the remaining 4 cups of cold water and lemon juice. Let cool to lukewarm (body temperature).
Sprinkle the yeast over the surface. Stir gently. Cover loosely and let ferment at room temperature 24–48 hours. It will become slightly fizzy.
Strain through cheesecloth into clean bottles. Cap tightly and refrigerate at least 12 hours. Open carefully—it's carbonated.
Serve ice-cold. The flavor should be sharp ginger, bright lemon, and gentle sweetness with a natural fizz.

Western Greece.description: A wine-dark stew from the villages of Achaia and Aitoloakarnania: rabbit (or hare) braised with a mountain of sweet pearl onions in red wine, aged vinegar, tomato, cinnamon, and cloves until the sauce is thick enough to coat a spoon and the rabbit falls from the bone. The ratio of onions to meat should be nearly 1:1—the onions collapse into a jammy sweetness that defines stifado. This dish descends from Venetian stufato and is the ultimate autumn comfort in Western Greece.
ingredients: 1 whole rabbit, cut into 8 pieces (about 3 lbs / 1.4 kg), or 3 lbs beef chuck
2 lbs pearl onions, peeled (leaving them whole) (900 g)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: Season the rabbit pieces with salt and pepper. Heat olive oil in a heavy Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Brown the rabbit deeply on all sides. Remove and set aside.
In the same pot, add the pearl onions. Cook, shaking the pan, until they color lightly, about 5 minutes. Do not break them—they should stay whole.

Return the rabbit. Add wine and vinegar. Let bubble for 2 minutes. Add crushed tomatoes, tomato paste, garlic, cinnamon, cloves, allspice, bay leaves, rosemary, and honey. Add enough water to just cover the meat.

Bring to a simmer, cover, and cook over very low heat for 2–2.5 hours. Do not stir aggressively—shake the pot gently instead so the onions stay whole. The stifado is done when the rabbit is tender, the onions are translucent and sweet, and the sauce is thick and mahogany-dark.
Remove cinnamon stick, bay leaves, and rosemary. Serve in deep bowls with crusty bread to soak up the sauce. Crumbled feta on the side is optional but excellent.

drink.description: A fortified sweet red wine from the vineyards around Patras, made from the Mavrodaphne grape since 1873. Rich, dark, and redolent of dried figs, raisins, and chocolate, it is Greece's answer to Port. Traditionally served as a dessert wine or a pairing with dark chocolate, but also used in cooking stifado. Legend has it the grape was named after the dark-haired woman its creator loved.
ingredients: 3 oz (90 ml) Mavrodaphne of Patras PDO, served at 60°F (16°C)
steps: Pour into a small wine glass at slightly below room temperature.
Swirl gently. Aromas of dried fig, raisin, and cocoa should emerge.
Sip slowly alongside dark chocolate, walnut baklava, or a wedge of aged Graviera cheese.

Central Greece.description: A dish from the mountain village of Arachova on the slopes of Mount Parnassus, above Delphi: thick slices of Formaella—a semi-hard, barrel-aged sheep's milk cheese made only in Arachova—pan-fried in a blazing-hot skillet until a golden crust forms, then drizzled with thyme honey and cracked pepper. Saganaki means 'little frying pan,' and the sound of cheese hitting hot metal is the overture. Formaella has PDO status; no other village in Greece can make it.
ingredients: 14 oz Formaella Arachovas cheese (or halloumi or kefalotyri as substitute), cut into 1/2-inch thick slices (400 g)
steps: Pat the cheese slices dry. Dredge lightly in flour, shaking off excess—the flour helps create the golden crust.
Heat olive oil in a heavy skillet (ideally a small two-handled saganaki pan) over high heat until the oil shimmers.
Add the cheese slices. Fry without moving for 2–3 minutes until a deep golden crust forms on the bottom. Flip carefully and fry the second side another 2 minutes.
Transfer immediately to a warm plate. Drizzle with thyme honey, crack pepper generously over the top, sprinkle with oregano and sesame seeds if using.
Squeeze the lemon wedge over just before eating. Serve immediately—saganaki waits for no one.

drink.dish: Tsai tou Vounou Parnassou (Parnassus Mountain Tea)
drink.description: Wild mountain tea (sideritis scardica) handpicked from the slopes of Mount Parnassus above Arachova and Delphi. Steeped in boiling water with honey, it is believed by Greeks to cure colds, aid digestion, and bring calmness. Every family in Central Greece has bundles of dried sideritis hanging in the kitchen. The taste is earthy, floral, and faintly citrusy.
steps: Place the dried sideritis stalks in a small pot with the boiling water.
Simmer gently for 8–10 minutes. Do not boil hard.
Strain into cups. Add honey and a slice of lemon if desired.
Drink hot, sitting on a stone terrace with a view of the Parnassus peaks.

Peloponnese.description: A Peloponnesian classic baked in a clay pot (youvetsi/giouvetsi): bone-in lamb shanks braised on a bed of kritharaki (orzo pasta) in a tomato-cinnamon sauce until the pasta absorbs every drop of the lamb's juices and the top develops a golden crust. The clay pot goes straight from the village baker's wood-fired oven to the Sunday table. This is Greek home cooking at its most nurturing—the pasta underneath becomes almost risotto-like, infused with lamb fat and spice.
ingredients: 4 lamb shanks or 3 lbs bone-in lamb shoulder, cut into large pieces (1.4 kg)
2 cups hot water or beef broth (480 ml)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
Grated kefalotyri or Pecorino for serving
steps: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Season the lamb generously with salt and pepper. Heat olive oil in a Dutch oven or clay pot over medium-high heat. Brown the lamb deeply on all sides. Remove.
Add grated onion to the pot. Cook until softened, 5 minutes. Add garlic, cook 1 minute. Pour in the wine and let it bubble and reduce by half.

Add crushed tomatoes, cinnamon stick, bay leaves, oregano, 2 cups hot water, and the lamb. The liquid should mostly cover the meat. Cover and braise in the oven for 1.5 hours until the lamb is very tender.
Remove the pot from the oven. Take out the lamb pieces. Stir the orzo directly into the tomato braising liquid. Add another cup of hot water if the liquid seems low—the orzo will absorb a lot.
Nestle the lamb back on top of the orzo. Return to the oven, uncovered, for 25–30 minutes, until the orzo is cooked through and has absorbed most of the liquid, with a slight golden crust on top.
Let rest 5 minutes. Serve from the pot with generous grated kefalotyri and crusty bread.

drink.description: The great red wine of the Peloponnese: Agiorgitiko grapes from the valley of Nemea, where Heracles slew the Nemean lion. Deep garnet, velvety, with flavors of dark cherry, plum, and a hint of spice. Nemea Agiorgitiko is Greece's most important red wine and pairs magnificently with lamb youvetsi.
ingredients: 1 bottle Nemea Agiorgitiko PDO, served at 62–65°F (17–18°C)
steps: Open the bottle 30 minutes before serving to let it breathe. Pour into large red wine glasses.
Swirl to release the aromas of ripe cherry and violet.
Pair with lamb youvetsi, grilled meats, or aged Graviera cheese. This is the wine of the Peloponnesian table.

Attica.description: The definitive street food of Athens: small cubes of pork marinated in oregano, lemon, and olive oil, grilled over charcoal on small wooden skewers, then stuffed into a warm, lightly grilled pita with tomato, red onion, tzatziki, and—crucially—crispy fried potatoes tucked inside the wrap. The Athenian souvlaki wrap is not a plate; it is architecture. Each layer matters: the pita must be warm and supple, the meat charred, the tzatziki cool, the fries hot and crispy, the onion sharp. This is eaten standing, at 2 AM, after the bars close, or at noon on Monastiraki Square.
ingredients: 2 lbs boneless pork shoulder, cut into 3/4-inch cubes (900 g)
Marinade: 1/4 cup olive oil (60 ml), juice of 2 lemons, 2 tbsp dried oregano, 4 garlic cloves (minced), 1 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp black pepper
Tzatziki: 1 cup strained Greek yogurt, 1/2 cucumber (grated, squeezed dry), 1 garlic clove (grated), 1 tbsp olive oil, 1 tsp white wine vinegar, salt
steps: Combine all marinade ingredients. Add the pork cubes and toss. Marinate 2 hours minimum, overnight is better.
Make the tzatziki: mix all tzatziki ingredients. Refrigerate.
Thread the pork onto wooden skewers (soaked). Grill over hot charcoal or a very hot grill, turning frequently, 8–10 minutes until charred on the outside and juicy inside.
Warm the pita breads on the grill for 30 seconds per side—they should be soft and pliable, not crispy.

Assemble the wrap: lay a pita flat. Spread a generous line of tzatziki down the center. Slide the meat off 1–2 skewers onto the tzatziki. Add tomato, onion, and a handful of hot fries. Dust with paprika.
Roll tightly, wrapping the bottom in paper or foil. Eat immediately, standing up. This is souvlaki.

drink.description: Athens' modern coffee obsession: a double shot of espresso shaken with ice and sugar until thick and frothy, served in a tall glass with a crown of cold foam. Freddo espresso has replaced the old frappé as the daily caffeine ritual of young Athenians—you will see it on every café table from Exarchia to Glyfada. The foam is the point; without it, it's just iced coffee.
ingredients: 1 double shot espresso (50–60 ml), freshly pulled
2 tsp sugar (or to taste; omit for 'sketos')
Cold water or milk (optional, for a freddo cappuccino variation)
steps: Pull a double espresso into a small pitcher or shaker cup. Add sugar while the espresso is still hot. Stir to dissolve.
Add 4–5 ice cubes to a cocktail shaker or tall jar. Pour the hot espresso over the ice. Shake vigorously for 10–15 seconds until thick, frothy, and ice-cold.
Fill a tall glass with fresh ice cubes. Strain the shaken espresso over the ice. The foam should sit on top like a cap.
Drink slowly through a straw. In Athens, a freddo espresso lasts at least 45 minutes—it's not fuel, it's lifestyle.

North Aegean.description: The legendary salt-cured sardines of Lesbos (Mytilini): fresh sardines from the Gulf of Kalloni—one of the richest sardine fisheries in the Mediterranean—are layered with coarse sea salt in wooden barrels and cured for months. The result is firm, intensely savory, and eaten raw: peeled, drizzled with olive oil and lemon, served with bread and ouzo. Kalloni sardines have PGI status and are the cornerstone of Lesbos cuisine. No cooking required—only the finest raw materials and patience.
ingredients: 12 salt-cured sardines from Kalloni (sardeles pastes), or 1 lb very fresh whole sardines + coarse sea salt
steps: If using store-bought salt-cured sardines: remove them from the salt. Rinse briefly under cold water. Carefully peel off the skin and remove the backbone—the flesh should separate easily into two fillets. Arrange on a plate.

If curing fresh sardines: gut and clean the sardines, leaving heads on. Layer in a dish: a bed of coarse salt, then sardines in a single row, then more salt. Repeat. Cover and refrigerate for 24–48 hours. Rinse, peel, and fillet as above.
Arrange the sardine fillets on a plate. Drizzle generously with extra-virgin olive oil and fresh lemon juice. Crack black pepper over the top. Scatter with parsley.
Serve at room temperature with crusty bread and a glass of ouzo. Eat a fillet on bread, sip ouzo, repeat. This is the eternal meze of the Aegean.

drink.description: Ouzo from Plomari, Lesbos—the ouzo capital of Greece. Distilled from grape must with star anise, fennel, mastic, and other botanicals, Plomari ouzo is considered the finest in the Aegean: silky, aromatic, and perfectly balanced. When water or ice is added, it turns milky white—the louche effect that signals authentic, well-made ouzo. In Plomari, ouzo is not a drink; it is a way of life.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) ouzo from Plomari (Barbayiannis, Plomari, or similar)
1–2 ice cubes (optional, added after the water)
Meze: sardeles pastes, olives, octopus, cheese
steps: Pour the ouzo into a tall, narrow glass.
Add cold water slowly—watch the ouzo turn milky white as the anise oils emulsify. The ratio should be about 1 part ouzo to 1.5–2 parts water.
Add an ice cube if desired (always after the water, never before—adding ice first 'shocks' the oils).
Sip slowly alongside meze. Ouzo is never drunk alone—it demands company, conversation, and small bites.

South Aegean.description: The iconic fritters of Santorini: the island's intensely sweet, sun-dried cherry tomatoes (tomataki Santorinis, a PDO product grown in volcanic soil without irrigation) are hand-grated, mixed with fresh mint, onion, and a whisper of flour, then deep-fried into crispy, golden patties that burst with concentrated tomato flavor. These exist nowhere else because no other tomato on earth tastes like Santorini's. The volcanic terroir, the extreme heat, and the complete absence of water produce tomatoes that are tiny, wrinkled, and explosively sweet.
ingredients: 1.5 lbs Santorini cherry tomatoes (or the ripest, sweetest cherry tomatoes you can find) (680 g)
1/2 cup all-purpose flour (60 g), plus more if needed
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
Olive oil for frying (about 1 cup / 240 ml)
steps: Cut the tomatoes in half and grate them on the large holes of a box grater (cut side against the grater), discarding the skins. You should have a thick tomato pulp. Do NOT drain—the juice is essential.

In a bowl, combine the grated tomato with onion, mint, parsley, oregano, salt, and pepper. Add the flour and baking powder. Stir until you have a thick, spoonable batter (not pourable—it should hold its shape on a spoon). Add more flour if too wet.
Let the batter rest 15 minutes. It will thicken slightly as the flour hydrates.

Heat 1/2 inch of olive oil in a deep skillet to 340°F (170°C). Drop heaping tablespoons of batter into the oil, flattening slightly with the back of the spoon. Fry in batches, 2–3 minutes per side, until deeply golden and crisp.

Drain on paper towels. Serve hot or at room temperature with a dollop of Greek yogurt or tzatziki on the side. In Santorini, these are eaten at sunset with a glass of Assyrtiko wine, watching the caldera turn gold.

drink.description: A citron liqueur produced only on the island of Naxos from the leaves and fruit of the citron tree (Citrus medica), which has grown in Naxos's Tragea valley since antiquity. Kitron comes in three colors: green (strongest, most aromatic), yellow (medium), and clear (sweetest). The green version—distilled, not just macerated—has the most character: herbaceous, intensely citrusy, and bracingly aromatic.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Kitron Naxou (green label), chilled
steps: Chill the bottle in the refrigerator (not freezer).
Pour into a small liqueur glass.
Sip cold after dinner as a digestivo. The flavor is unlike any citrus liqueur—floral, herbal, and unmistakably Naxian.

Crete.description: The wildest dish in the Greek canon: live Cretan vineyard snails (chochlioi) are placed face-down in a screaming-hot skillet with a thick layer of coarse salt and olive oil. The snails sizzle and seal against the pan, creating a crust on their opening. They're then doused with rosemary-infused wine vinegar, which erupts into fragrant steam. The name 'boubouristi' is onomatopoeia—it mimics the sound of the snails sizzling and popping in the pan. This is primal Cretan cooking: ingredients foraged from the land, cooked with fire, salt, and wild herbs.
ingredients: 2 lbs live or cleaned Cretan snails (or canned escargot as substitute) (900 g)
1/2 cup coarse sea salt (for purging, if using live snails)
1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oil (80 ml), Cretan (robust, peppery)
Coarse sea salt and cracked black pepper
steps: If using live snails: purge them by placing in a bucket with coarse salt and a splash of vinegar for 2 hours (they foam out impurities). Rinse thoroughly under running water. Blanch in boiling water 5 minutes, drain, and remove from shells if desired (traditional is in-shell).
Dust the open side of each snail lightly with flour. This helps create the golden crust.

Heat the olive oil in a large, heavy cast-iron skillet over high heat until almost smoking. Place the snails face-down (opening against the pan) in a single layer. The oil will sputter and pop—this is the 'boubouristi.'
Cook without moving for 3–4 minutes until the flour crust is golden and crisp. Toss the snails in the pan.
Add the rosemary sprigs. Pour the vinegar over the snails—it will hiss and steam dramatically. Toss for 30 seconds as the vinegar evaporates into a glaze.
Season with salt and pepper. Serve immediately in the hot skillet with bread to soak up the rosemary-vinegar oil. Pick the snails out with toothpicks. Drink raki between every few bites.

drink.description: Crete's beloved winter drink: tsikoudia (Cretan grape-marc spirit, also called raki) warmed with thyme honey, cinnamon, and cloves. Rakomelo means 'raki + honey,' and every Cretan village kafeneio serves it on cold nights. The honey softens the fire of the spirit; the spices perfume the steam. It is medicine, ritual, and comfort in a single glass.
steps: Combine the tsikoudia, honey, cinnamon stick, cloves, and orange peel in a small saucepan.
Warm over low heat, stirring to dissolve the honey. Do not boil—you want the alcohol to stay; just warm enough to steam and release the spice aromas.
Strain into a small heat-proof glass (or serve with the cinnamon stick in the glass for presentation).
Drink warm on a cold night in a stone-walled kafeneio, or after a meal of Cretan mezedes. Yamas!

GRD.description: The ultimate communal one-pot meal from the 'Spice Isle'. Breadfruit, salted meat, and dumplings are steamed in turmeric-infused coconut milk until all the liquid is absorbed and only the savory coconut oil remains—hence the name 'Oil Down'.
steps: Layer the pot: Seasoned meat at the bottom.
Add breadfruit slices and dumplings on top.
Top with callaloo leaves to seal steam in.
Mix coconut milk with turmeric and pour over everything.
Cover and simmer on low heat until liquid is absorbed and oil separates ('oil down'). Do not stir.

drink.description: Grenada is the “Spice Isle”—nutmeg shows up everywhere, including in creamy punch-style cocktails.
ingredients: 1/2 tsp freshly grated nutmeg (plus more to garnish)
steps: Shake rum, milk, simple syrup, and nutmeg with ice.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
Garnish with extra grated nutmeg.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

GRL.description: Survival in a bowl. This traditional Inuit soup provided essential warmth and energy in the Arctic. While historically made with seal meat for its rich fat content, modern versions often feature reindeer or muskox, thickened with barley or rice.
ingredients: 2 lbs Meat (Lamb, Reindeer, or Seal), cut into chunks
steps: Boil the meat in water. Skim off any foam.
Add chopped onions. Simmer until meat is nearly tender (approx 1 hour).
Add potatoes and rice (or barley).
Cook until rice and potatoes are soft and soup thickens slightly.
Season with salt and pepper. Serve hot.

drink.description: A warm, spiked coffee drink often served with a layered, flamed presentation.
steps: Add Kahlúa and whisky to a warm mug.
Pour in hot coffee.
Float orange liqueur and (optionally) flame briefly.
Top with whipped cream.

GTM.description: Guatemala's national dish. A rich, dark, spicy stew made with roasted seeds and chilies. It is a fusion of Spanish and Mayan cuisines, often served on special occasions.
ingredients: Sauce Base: 4 Tomatoes, 4 Tomatillos, 2 Dried Guaque chilies, 2 Dried Pasa chilies
Thickener: 1/2 cup Pumpkin seeds (Pepitoria), 1/2 cup Sesame seeds, 1 Tortilla (toasted)
steps: Boil chicken in water with onion and salt to make broth.
Dry roast the seeds, chilies, and tortilla on a comal/pan until fragrant. Grind to a powder.
Char the tomatoes and tomatillos. Blend them with the seed powder and a little broth.
Fry this sauce in a little oil. It should be thick and dark.
Add the chicken and vegetables to the sauce. Simmer until vegetables are tender.
Serve with rice and corn tortillas.

drink.description: A widely recognized Guatemalan beer.
steps: Serve chilled.

GUF.description: A legendary Easter stew said to possess a charm: 'If you eat the Bouillon d'Awara, you will return to Guiana.' It takes days to prepare, centering on the bright orange pulp of the Awara palm fruit, smoked meats, and local seafood.
ingredients: 2 lbs Awara Pulp (or palm nut concentrate)
steps: Dilute Awara pulp in water to make a thick broth. Simmer for 2 hours.
Add salted meat and fish (desalted beforehand). Simmer 1 hour.
Add vegetables and smoked chicken. Simmer 1 hour.
Add crab last. The stew is done when oil rises to the top and it is a uniform orange color.
Serve with white rice.

drink.description: In French Guiana, infused “rhum arrangé” styles are common—rum steeped with fruit/spice.
ingredients: 1 vanilla bean (split) or 1 tsp vanilla extract
steps: Combine rum, fruit, vanilla, and sugar in a jar.
Infuse 7–21 days, tasting as you go, then strain.
Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) over ice or neat.

GUY.description: An ancient Amerindian dish that became the national Christmas breakfast. Its deep black color and preservative qualities come from Cassareep (boiled cassava juice), allowing this spicy, rich meat stew to sit on the stove and develop flavor for days.
ingredients: 2 lbs Mixed Meat (Beef, Pork, Oxtail, Cow heel)
steps: Wash meat with lime. Place in a large pot.
Add water to cover, cassareep, cinnamon, sugar, peppers, and garlic.
Bring to a boil, then simmer on low heat for 3-4 hours until meat is tender and sauce is thick and dark.
The flavor improves over days (traditionally left on the stove).
Serve with dense homemade plait bread to soak up the sauce.

drink.description: Guyana’s identity is tied to Demerara rum—this punch keeps it simple: rum, citrus, and tropical juice.
ingredients: 1 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz / 15 ml simple syrup)
steps: Shake everything with ice until cold.
Strain over fresh ice in a rocks glass.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: Store-bought cassareep (recommended for safety and authenticity)
steps: Cassareep is traditionally made by extracting cassava juice, fermenting/settling, and boiling it down for a long time with spices.
Because raw cassava juice can contain cyanogenic compounds, the safest approach is to use reputable store-bought cassareep.
If you are set on making it from scratch, follow a trusted Guyanese/Caribbean method and boil the liquid thoroughly for an extended time; do not use any ‘quick’ method.

HND.description: The fuel of Honduras. Legend says a woman named Baleada sold these thick flour tortillas, or that they resemble 'bullets' (balas) of beans. Regardless of origin, this folded comfort food of beans, salty cheese, and mantequilla is a daily necessity.
ingredients: Tortillas: 3 cups Flour, 1 tsp Baking powder, 1/3 cup Oil, Warm water/Milk
Mantequilla (Honduran style sour cream - slightly runny and salty)
steps: Dough: Mix flour, baking powder, and oil. Add warm liquid until soft dough forms. Knead well. Let rest 30 mins.
Divide into balls. Pat and stretch by hand (or roll) into thick tortillas.
Cook on a dry comal/skillet until bubbly and browned spots appear.
Assembly: Spread a generous layer of hot refried beans on one half.
Sprinkle with cheese and drizzle with mantequilla.
Fold in half like a taco. Eat warm.

drink.description: A traditional Honduran drink made from toasted corn and cacao ground into a powder, then cooked with milk and sweetened.
ingredients: For pinol powder: 2 lb toasted white corn, 1/2 cup toasted cacao, 1 cinnamon stick, 2 cloves, 1 1/2 cups grated rapadura/panela (or piloncillo), crushed
For the drink: 2 cups milk, 1/4 cup sugar, 6 cups water, 1 Tbsp vanilla extract
steps: Make pinol powder: Grind the toasted corn with the toasted cacao, cinnamon, and cloves to a fine powder. Sweeten the powder by mixing in the grated rapadura/panela.
In a pot, heat the milk and add the sugar. Bring just to a gentle boil, stirring so it dissolves.
Whisk in 1 cup of the pinol powder and stir constantly until the mixture is smooth and thickened slightly.
Remove from heat. Stir in the water (lukewarm or room temperature) and the vanilla.
Serve warm (or chill and serve cold).

HRV.description: The crown jewel of Dalmatian cuisine. A beef round is stuffed with garlic and bacon, marinated in vinegar overnight, then slow-cooked for hours with prunes, dessert wine (Prošek), and root vegetables to create a rich, dark, sweet-and-sour sauce.
ingredients: Bacon strips and Garlic slivers (for larding)
Sauce: Onions, Parsley root, Carrots, Prunes, Prošek (or Port wine), Tomato paste
steps: Pierce beef and stuff with bacon and garlic. Marinate in vinegar water overnight.
Sear the beef. Remove.
Sauté chopped vegetables. Add beef back with marinade and wine.
Simmer for 3 hours. Add prunes and spices (cloves, nutmeg).
Remove beef. Blend the sauce until smooth and thick.
Slice beef, return to sauce, and serve with homemade gnocchi.

drink.description: A sour built around Dalmatian maraschino liqueur (famously produced in Zadar). Bright citrus and a floral-cherry backbone.
ingredients: 1/2 oz simple syrup (15 ml) (or 2 tsp sugar)
Optional: 1 egg white (for a silky foam)
Garnish: lemon peel or cocktail cherry

steps: Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar dissolves (do not boil hard).
Cool completely, then store covered in the fridge up to 2 weeks.
Add maraschino, lemon juice, simple syrup (and egg white if using) to a shaker.
If using egg white, dry-shake (no ice) 10 seconds to foam.
Add ice and shake hard 10–15 seconds.
Double-strain into a chilled coupe (or over fresh ice in a rocks glass).
Garnish with a lemon peel or cherry.

HTI.description: The undisputed king of Haitian cuisine. Pork shoulder is bathed in sour orange and scotch bonnet, boiled until tender, and then fried to a golden crisp. It's a celebration of texture, especially when paired with spicy Pikliz and twice-fried plantains.
ingredients: 2 lbs Pork Shoulder, cut into large cubes
Marinade: 1 cup Sour Orange juice (or Lime/Orange mix), Scotch Bonnet pepper, Thyme, Parsley, Garlic, Scallions
Pikliz: Cabbage, Carrots, Scotch Bonnet, Vinegar (pickled beforehand)
steps: Clean pork with lime. Blend marinade ingredients. Pour over pork and marinate overnight.
Place pork and marinade in a pot. Add water to cover. Boil until meat is tender and water evaporates completely.
Allow the pork to fry in its own rendered fat (add oil if needed) until dark golden and crispy.
Remove pork.
Slice plantains, fry once, smash flat, fry again (Banyann Peze).
Serve pork and plantains topped with spicy Pikliz.

drink.description: Haiti’s traditional cane spirit (clairin/kleren) is often taken with lime and a little sweetness.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) clairin (or unaged cane rum)
1 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz / 15 ml simple syrup)
steps: Stir clairin, lime juice, and sugar in a small glass (ice optional).
Sip slowly.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: 2 cups green cabbage, very thinly sliced
1–2 Scotch bonnet peppers (whole or sliced; adjust heat)
steps: Pack cabbage, carrots, onion, peppers (and garlic/spices if using) into a clean jar.
Pour vinegar over to fully submerge; add salt and stir/shake.
Cover and refrigerate at least 24 hours (better after 3–7 days). Keeps 2–3 weeks refrigerated.

HUN.description: The soup of the Magyar herdsmen. Often misunderstood abroad as a stew, authentic Gulyás is a rich soup heavily spiced with paprika, loaded with tender beef, potatoes, and handmade 'csipetke' noodles.
steps: Fry onions in lard/oil. Remove from heat, stir in paprika (to prevent burning).
