Sardegna.description: Sardinia's hand-pinched ravioli from the wild Ogliastra coast: a thin semolina dough enclosing a filling of potato, aged Pecorino, mint, and garlic, sealed with an elaborate braid called sa spighitta (the wheat ear) that only Sardinian hands know by heart. Each pinch creates a decorative ridge that also seals the dumpling perfectly. Served with a simple fresh tomato sauce and basil.
ingredients: For dough: 3 cups fine semolina flour (360 g), 3/4 cup warm water (180 ml), 1 tbsp olive oil, pinch of salt
For filling: 1.5 lbs potatoes, boiled and riced (680 g), 1 cup grated aged Pecorino Sardo (100 g), 2 garlic cloves minced, 12 fresh mint leaves (finely chopped), 2 tbsp olive oil, salt
For sauce: 1 can (14 oz) San Marzano tomatoes, 2 tbsp olive oil, 1 garlic clove, basil, salt
steps: Make the filling: Boil potatoes until tender, peel and rice while hot. Mix with Pecorino, garlic, chopped mint, and olive oil. Season with salt. The filling should be smooth and fragrant. Cool.
Make the dough: Knead semolina, water, olive oil, and salt into a smooth, elastic dough, 10–12 minutes. Rest 30 minutes under a towel.

Roll the dough very thin. Cut into 3-inch circles. Place a tablespoon of filling in the center of each. To close: pinch and fold the edge over itself in a continuous braid from one end to the other, creating the decorative spighitta pattern. Press firmly at the end to seal.
Make the sauce: Heat olive oil with garlic until fragrant. Add crushed tomatoes and basil. Simmer 15 minutes. Season.
Cook the culurgiones in gently simmering salted water for 3–4 minutes (they will float). Remove with a slotted spoon.
Place in a warm bowl, spoon tomato sauce over the top, and finish with grated Pecorino Sardo.

drink.description: Sardinia's signature liqueur, distilled from the wild myrtle berries that grow in the island's macchia (scrubland). Mirto rosso (red, from the berries) is the most common—deep purple, bittersweet, and herbal. Always served ice-cold from the freezer as a digestivo.
ingredients: 1 lb fresh myrtle berries (mirto), rinsed (450 g)
2 cups (480 ml) grain alcohol or high-proof vodka
steps: Place the myrtle berries in a large glass jar. Pour over the alcohol. Seal tightly and steep in a cool, dark place for 40–60 days.
Make syrup: dissolve sugar in water over heat. Cool completely.
Strain the berry-infused alcohol through cheesecloth (press the berries to extract flavor). Combine with the syrup.
Bottle and rest in the freezer for at least 2 weeks. Serve ice-cold in small glasses after dinner.

JAM.description: A breakfast that tells a story of the triangular trade. Saltfish from the North Atlantic meets Ackee from West Africa (brought by Captain Bligh). When cooked, the poisonous-if-unripe ackee turns into a buttery, egg-like delicacy that perfectly balances the salty cod.
steps: Soak saltfish overnight or boil in water for 20 mins to remove excess salt. Flake the fish and remove bones.
Sauté onion, peppers, and scallion in oil until soft.
Add the flaked fish and thyme. Cook for 5 mins.
Gently fold in the ackee (be careful not to mash it).
Place the whole scotch bonnet pepper on top for flavor (do not burst it). Steam for 3-5 mins.
Remove pepper. Serve with fried dumplings, boiled green bananas, or yam.

drink.description: A rum-forward tropical punch associated with Jamaica: rum, citrus, and a touch of spice.
ingredients: 1/2 oz (15 ml) grenadine (or 1/2 oz simple syrup)
steps: Shake everything with ice until cold.
Strain into a tall glass over fresh ice.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool before using.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.
Warm pomegranate juice and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (avoid a hard boil).
Cool; stir in orange blossom water if using.
Bottle; add vodka if using for shelf-life.
Refrigerate and use within 3–4 weeks (longer if vodka added).

JEY.description: The Jersey version of the bean jar, using a mix of beans and pig's trotter.
steps: Soak beans.
Cook all ingredients in crock pot for 8+ hours.
Remove bone. Serve.

drink.description: Jersey has a long tradition of cider production.
steps: Serve chilled and pour into a glass.

JOR.dish: Mansaf (منسف) — Jordanian Lamb with Jameed Sauce
JOR.description: Jordan’s iconic celebratory platter: lamb simmered tender, served over shrak bread and rice, and drenched in tangy jameed (dried yogurt) sauce with toasted nuts and sumac-like brightness.
ingredients: 3 lb (1.4 kg) lamb shoulder or shanks, bone-in chunks
2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
3 cups (600 g) long-grain rice, rinsed and soaked 20 minutes, drained
3 tbsp (45 g) ghee or unsalted butter
To serve: shrak or markook bread (or very thin lavash), chopped parsley
Garnish: 1/2 cup (70 g) slivered almonds or pine nuts, toasted
steps: Simmer lamb with onion, water, bay, cardamom, peppercorns, and salt until very tender, 1 1/2–2 hours. Skim as needed.
Remove lamb; keep warm. Strain broth; reserve.
Prepare jameed sauce base (see preliminary steps), then keep it warm on low.
Cook rice: in a pot, heat ghee, add drained rice and stir 1 minute. Add 4 1/2 cups (1.1 L) hot lamb broth and a pinch of salt. Bring to a boil, cover, cook on low 15 minutes; rest 10 minutes.
Assembly: Lay shrak bread on a large platter and splash with a little warm jameed sauce to soften. Mound rice on top. Arrange lamb over rice.
Ladle plenty of jameed sauce over everything. Top with toasted nuts and parsley. Serve extra sauce on the side.

ingredients: 8–10 oz (225–280 g) jameed (dried yogurt), broken up (or 2 cups jameed paste if available)
4–6 cups (950 ml–1.4 L) warm water, as needed
1 cup (240 ml) plain whole-milk yogurt (helps stability)
Reserved lamb broth (from mansaf), as needed
steps: Soak jameed in warm water at least 4 hours (overnight is best) until softened.
Blend soaked jameed with its soaking liquid until completely smooth. Strain if gritty.
Whisk in yogurt (and cornstarch if using).
Warm gently over low heat, stirring constantly. Thin with lamb broth/water to a pourable sauce. Do not let it boil hard.
Keep warm; stir occasionally until serving.

drink.description: A classic Levantine drink: jallab is a dark, caramel-fruity molasses syrup diluted over ice with rose water and topped with pine nuts and raisins.
ingredients: 1/3 cup (80 ml) jallab syrup (date and/or grape molasses blend)
steps: In a pitcher, stir jallab syrup with cold water until fully dissolved.
Stir in rose water. Taste and adjust with more syrup or water.
Fill glasses with ice, pour, and top with pine nuts and raisins.

JPN.description: Vinegared rice paired with seafood. It's all about the rice preparation.
steps: Wash rice repeatedly until water runs clear. Cook in rice cooker.
While rice is hot, transfer to a wooden tub (hangiri).
Drizzle vinegar/sugar/salt mix over rice. Use a paddle to 'slice' and fold rice (don't mash). Fan the rice to cool it to body temp.
Nigiri: Wet hands. Form a small log of rice. Smear a dot of wasabi. Drape a slice of fish over it.
Maki: Place nori on bamboo mat. Spread rice. Add filling. Roll tightly.
Serve with soy sauce and pickled ginger.

drink.description: Junmai sake gently warmed in a hot-water bath (a common traditional serve).
steps: Pour sake into a small heat-safe carafe (tokkuri).
Set the carafe in a saucepan of hot (not boiling) water and warm until the sake reaches about 104°F (40°C).
Pour into small cups (ochoko) and serve immediately.

Jammu and Kashmir.description: A signature dish of Kashmiri Wazwan cuisine. Braised lamb chunks are cooked with a gravy flavored with browned onions, yogurt, garlic, ginger, and aromatic spices (cloves, bay leaves, cardamom, and cinnamon). Its brilliant red color comes from dried Kashmiri chilies.
ingredients: 2 tbsp Kashmiri Chili Powder (for color, mild heat)
steps: Fry lamb in mustard oil.
Add whole spices and chili powder dissolved in water.
Whisk yogurt and add to the pot (keep stirring to prevent splitting).
Add fennel and ginger powders.
Cover and slow cook until meat is tender and oil floats on top.

drink.description: A saffron-and-spice green tea from Kashmir, typically served hot and fragrant.
steps: Simmer water with saffron and spices 3–5 minutes.
Add green tea and steep 1–2 minutes off heat (avoid bitterness).
Strain, sweeten lightly if desired, and top with almonds.

KAZ.description: A Central Asian feast dish strongly associated with Kazakhstan: tender boiled meat served over broad handmade noodles with onion broth. Traditionally eaten communally—its name means ‘five fingers.’
ingredients: 3 lb (1.4 kg) bone-in lamb shoulder (or beef shank/short ribs)
1 tbsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
For noodles: 3 cups (360 g) all-purpose flour, plus more for dusting
steps: Boil the meat: combine meat, water, bay, salt, and peppercorns. Bring to a boil, skim, then simmer 2–3 hours until very tender.
Remove meat; keep warm. Strain broth; reserve.
Make noodle dough: mix flour and salt, add egg and water, knead until smooth. Rest covered 30 minutes.
Roll dough thin (about 1/16 in / 2 mm) and cut into large squares or wide ribbons.
Onion sauce: simmer sliced onions in 2 cups (475 ml) broth 5–7 minutes until softened; season lightly.
Cook noodles in the remaining simmering broth in batches, 2–3 minutes until tender; remove with a slotted spoon.
Slice or shred meat. Arrange noodles on a platter, top with meat, spoon onion broth over. Serve with bowls of broth on the side.

drink.description: A traditional steppe drink made by fermenting mare’s milk into a lightly tangy, gently sparkling beverage. Home versions often use cultured starters with cow’s milk.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (120 ml) plain kefir (as starter) or 1/2 cup active yogurt whey
steps: Combine milk, kefir, and sugar (if using) in the jar. Stir well.
Cover loosely (or use an airlock). Leave at room temperature 18–24 hours, shaking or stirring a few times to keep it mixed.
Refrigerate 6 hours to chill and slow fermentation. Stir before serving.
Serve cold. Use 1/2 cup of this batch as starter for the next batch.

KEN.description: Roasted meat, usually goat, served as a communal meal. Simple, smoky, and chewy.
ingredients: 2 lbs Goat meat (leg or shoulder), cut into chunks
steps: Prepare a charcoal grill. The heat should be medium.
Rub meat with oil and salt.
Place meat on the grill. Roast slowly, turning frequently.
Baste occasionally with salty water to keep it moist.
Cook until the outside is charred and the inside is well done (approx 45-60 mins).
Chop into bite-sized pieces on a wooden board.
Serve with a pile of salt, Kachumbari salad, and Ugali.

drink.description: Spiced milk tea common in Kenya.
steps: Simmer tea in water 3–5 minutes.
Add milk and simmer 2 minutes.
Strain and sweeten.

KGZ.description: Kyrgyzstan’s best-known celebratory meal: boiled meat and noodles dressed with onion broth. It’s a dish tied to nomadic hospitality and communal eating.
ingredients: 3 lb (1.4 kg) bone-in mutton or beef (shanks/short ribs work well)
1 tbsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
For noodles: 3 cups (360 g) all-purpose flour
steps: Simmer meat with water, salt, peppercorns, and bay leaves until very tender, 2–3 hours; skim foam.
Remove meat; strain and reserve broth.
Knead flour, egg, water, and salt into a smooth dough; rest 30 minutes.
Roll thin and cut into large squares/ribbons. Cook noodles in simmering broth 2–3 minutes; remove.
Simmer onions in a ladle or two of broth until softened; season.
Serve noodles on a platter topped with sliced meat and onions; moisten with broth and serve extra broth in bowls.

drink.description: A traditional Kyrgyz beverage made from roasted grain flour cooked in salted water and lightly fermented. It’s nourishing, slightly tangy, and served chilled.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (60 g) barley flour (or whole-wheat flour)
2 tbsp (30 g) butter or rendered fat
1/4 tsp active dry yeast (or 2 tbsp of a previous batch as starter)
steps: In a pot, melt butter/fat over medium heat. Add flour and cook, stirring, until nutty and medium-brown, 6–8 minutes (do not burn).
Whisk in water gradually to avoid lumps. Add salt (and sugar if using). Bring to a boil, then simmer 20 minutes, stirring often.
Cool to lukewarm (about 90°F / 32°C). Stir in yeast (or starter).
Cover and ferment at room temperature 6–10 hours until lightly tangy and faintly fizzy.
Chill thoroughly, then shake/stir and serve cold.

KHM.dish: Amok Trey (អាម៉ុកត្រី) — Cambodian Fish Amok
KHM.description: Cambodia’s most famous curry: delicate fish in a fragrant kroeung paste with coconut milk and kaffir lime, steamed into a soft custard in banana-leaf cups.
ingredients: 1 1/2 lb (680 g) white fish fillets (cod, tilapia, or catfish), cut into chunks
1 tsp palm sugar or brown sugar
6 kaffir lime leaves, finely sliced (or zest of 1 lime as substitute)
1 cup (30 g) packed spinach or mustard greens (optional lining)
Banana leaves or parchment for cups (optional)
steps: Make kroeung paste (see preliminary steps).
In a bowl, whisk coconut milk, egg, fish sauce, sugar, and 3–4 tbsp kroeung paste. Stir in lime leaves.
Fold in fish (and greens if using).
Divide into small ramekins or banana-leaf cups. Steam over simmering water 15–20 minutes until set like a soft custard.
Rest 5 minutes. Serve with rice and extra lime leaves on top.

preliminary_steps.item: Kroeung Paste (គ្រឿង) — Lemongrass Aromatic Curry Paste
ingredients: 1 tbsp fresh turmeric (or 1 tsp ground turmeric)
steps: Pound in a mortar (or blend) lemongrass, shallot, garlic, galangal, turmeric, and zest until a fine paste forms, adding a little water if needed.
If using shrimp paste, mix it in at the end.
Use immediately or refrigerate airtight up to 3 days.

drink.dish: Kafi Thuk Dak Ko (កាហ្វេទឹកដោះគោ) — Cambodian Iced Coffee
drink.description: Dark coffee sweetened with condensed milk and poured over ice—street-stall fuel across Cambodia.
steps: Stir condensed milk into hot coffee until dissolved.
Fill glasses with ice and pour coffee over. Taste and adjust sweetness.

KNA.description: A colorful plate reflecting the islands' history. Salted cod, a staple of the colonial era, is revitalized in a tomato stew and served with 'droppers' (coconut dumplings) and spicy plantains, creating a sweet, savory, and spicy harmony.
ingredients: Dumplings: 1 cup Flour, 1/2 cup Grated Coconut, Water
steps: Soak and boil saltfish to remove salt. Flake it.
Sauté onion, pepper, and tomato. Add fish and simmer.
Dumplings: Mix flour, coconut, and water. Form shapes. Boil in water.
Plantains: Slice ripe plantains. Toss with ginger and chili. Fry until golden.
Serve all components together with seasoned breadfruit if available.

drink.description: A straightforward island rum punch: rum, lime, tropical juice, and spice.
ingredients: 1 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz / 15 ml simple syrup)
steps: Shake rum, lime juice, pineapple juice, and sugar with ice.
Strain over fresh ice; add nutmeg if you like.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

KOR.description: Fire meat. Thinly sliced beef marinated in a sweet and savory soy sauce mixture, grilled to perfection.
ingredients: 1 lb Ribeye or Sirloin, thinly sliced (freeze slightly to slice thin)
Marinade: 1/2 cup Soy Sauce, 3 tbsp Sugar, 2 tbsp Sesame Oil, 1 tbsp Minced Garlic, 1 tbsp Sesame Seeds, Black Pepper
steps: Mix the marinade ingredients with the grated pear.
Combine beef and onions with the marinade. Massage well. Let sit for at least 30 mins (or overnight).
Heat a grill pan or skillet over high heat.
Add the meat in a single layer. Cook quickly until browned and caramelized (2-3 mins).
Garnish with scallions and sesame seeds.
Serve with steamed rice, lettuce leaves for wrapping, and kimchi.

drink.description: Korea’s iconic clear spirit, often served chilled and shared at the table.
steps: Chill the bottle well.
Pour into small glasses; traditionally, pour for others first.
Sip alongside food.

KOS.description: A labor of love consisting of layers of crepe-like batter and cream, broiled one by one to create a sun-ray pattern.
steps: Pour stripes of batter from center to edge. Broil.
Brush empty spaces with cream.
Pour batter over cream spaces. Broil.
Repeat for hours until pan is full.

drink.description: A Balkan fruit brandy widely consumed in Kosovo.
steps: Serve neat, at room temperature, as a small pour.

KWT.dish: Mutabbaq Zubaidi (مطبق زبيدي) — Kuwaiti Fish & Rice
KWT.description: A classic Kuwaiti table dish: spiced basmati rice cooked in a tomato-scented broth and layered with fried fish (traditionally zubaidi/pomfret).
ingredients: 2 lb (900 g) whole pomfret or firm white fish fillets
3 cups (600 g) basmati rice, rinsed and soaked 20 minutes, drained
4 1/2 cups (1.1 L) water or fish stock
Optional: pinch saffron steeped in 2 tbsp hot water
steps: Season fish with 1 tsp salt, pepper, and turmeric. Fry in 2 tbsp oil until golden and cooked; set aside.
In the same pot, add remaining oil and sauté onion until golden. Add garlic 30 seconds.
Add tomatoes and tomato paste; cook until thick. Add loomi, cardamom, cinnamon, bay, remaining salt, and water/stock. Simmer 5 minutes.
Add drained rice. Bring to a boil, cover tightly, cook on low 15 minutes; rest 10 minutes.
Fluff rice, drizzle saffron water if using, and serve topped with fish.

drink.dish: Shai Zafran (شاي زعفران) — Saffron Cardamom Tea
drink.description: A simple Gulf favorite: black tea infused with cardamom and saffron, served sweet.
ingredients: 2 tsp loose black tea (or 2 tea bags)
steps: Bring water to a boil. Add tea, cardamom, and saffron; simmer 3–4 minutes.
Strain and sweeten to taste.

LAO.dish: Laap (ລາບ) — Lao Minced Meat Salad
LAO.description: Often described as Laos’s national dish: minced meat seasoned bright with lime, fish sauce, herbs, and toasted rice powder (khao khua) for signature nuttiness.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) ground chicken, pork, or turkey
1/4 cup (60 ml) water or light stock
2 tbsp lime juice, plus more to taste
1–2 tsp crushed dried chili, to taste
3 tbsp toasted rice powder (khao khua) (see preliminary steps)
steps: In a skillet, cook ground meat with water/stock over medium heat, breaking it up, until just cooked through but still juicy.
Off heat, stir in fish sauce, lime juice, and sugar. Taste and adjust salty/sour/sweet.
Fold in shallots, mint, cilantro, scallions, chili, and toasted rice powder.
Serve warm or room temp with sticky rice and raw vegetables.

preliminary_steps.item: Khao Khua (ເຂົ້າຄົວ) — Toasted Rice Powder
ingredients: 1/2 cup (90 g) uncooked sticky rice (or jasmine rice)
steps: Toast rice in a dry skillet over medium heat, stirring constantly, until deep golden and nutty, 10–15 minutes.
Cool completely, then grind to a coarse powder (mortar/pestle or spice grinder).
Store airtight up to 1 month.

drink.dish: Kafae Lao (ກາເຟລາວ) — Lao Iced Coffee
drink.description: A Southeast Asian classic in Lao style: very strong coffee sweetened with condensed milk and served over ice.
ingredients: 2 cups (475 ml) very strong brewed coffee
Optional: 2 tbsp evaporated milk for extra creaminess
steps: Stir condensed milk (and evaporated milk if using) into hot coffee until dissolved.
Pour over ice. Adjust sweetness to taste.

LBN.description: The national dish of Lebanon. A croquette of spiced ground meat and bulgur wheat, stuffed with more meat and pine nuts.
ingredients: Shell: 1 lb Lean Ground Beef/Lamb, 2 cups Fine Bulgur (soaked), 1 Onion (grated), Spices (Cumin, Allspice)
Filling: 1/2 lb Ground Beef/Lamb, 1 Onion (chopped), 1/2 cup Pine Nuts, 1 tsp Sumac, Salt/Pepper
steps: Filling: Sauté onion and meat until brown. Add pine nuts and spices. Let cool.
Shell: Knead the soaked bulgur, lean meat, grated onion, and spices into a smooth dough (use a food processor if needed).
Forming: Take a ball of shell dough. Make a hole with your finger to create a cup. Stuff with filling. Seal the top and shape into a football (torpedo) shape.
Deep fry at 350°F (180°C) until dark brown and crispy.
Serve hot with yogurt sauce or hummus.

drink.description: Lebanese arak is traditionally diluted with water and served with ice.
steps: Add arak to a glass.
Add water, then ice.

LCA.description: Don't be fooled by the name—'Green Figs' are actually unripe bananas, a major island crop. Boiled until firm and starchy, they replace potatoes as the perfect foil for savory, flaked salted cod sautéed with aromatic herbs and peppers.
steps: Cut ends off green bananas. Score the skin. Boil in salted water until tender (skin turns dark). Peel.
Soak and boil saltfish. Flake it.
Sauté onion, garlic, pepper, and herbs in oil.
Add flaked fish. Cook for 5-10 mins to meld flavors.
Serve the boiled green bananas alongside the stewed saltfish.

drink.description: A St Lucian herbal rum infusion (bois bandé) often served as a local “bush rum” style drink.
ingredients: 2 tbsp bois bandé bark (or 1–2 small pieces, if available)
steps: Combine rum, bois bandé bark, and sugar in a jar; seal.
Infuse 7–21 days, shaking occasionally, then strain.
Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) neat or over ice.

LIE.description: The principality's answer to mac and cheese. Small flour dumplings (knöpfle) are layered with pungent local cheese (Sura Kees or Gruyère) and topped with sweet, crispy caramelized onions.
steps: Mix flour, eggs, salt, and water to make a sticky dough.
Press dough through a colander or spaetzle maker into boiling salted water.
When dumplings float, skim them out.
Layer dumplings and cheese in a dish. Repeat.
Fry onions in butter until dark brown and crispy. Top the dish.
Serve immediately with applesauce on the side.

drink.description: A simple alpine spritz: local white wine topped with sparkling water—light, crisp, and easy.
steps: Chill a wine glass and fill with ice.
Pour in the wine.
Top with sparkling water and stir once.
Add a lemon wedge if you like.

LKA.dish: Kottu Roti (කොත්තු රොටි) — Sri Lankan Chopped Flatbread Stir-Fry
LKA.description: Sri Lanka’s street-food icon: shredded godamba roti chopped on a hot griddle with aromatics, curry spices, egg, and often chicken—savory, loud, and addictive.
ingredients: 4–5 godamba roti (or thin plain parathas), sliced into ribbons (see preliminary steps for homemade)
1 tbsp soy sauce (optional, common in modern kottu)
1/2 cup (120 ml) chicken stock or water
steps: Heat oil on a large skillet/griddle. Sauté onion until soft, then add garlic, ginger, and chili; cook 1 minute.
Add cabbage and carrot; stir-fry 2–3 minutes.
Add chicken (if using), curry powder, pepper, and a pinch of salt; stir to coat.
Push everything aside. Scramble eggs in the empty space, then mix through.
Add sliced roti, soy sauce (if using), and stock/water. Chop and toss continuously until roti absorbs flavor and everything is hot, 3–5 minutes.
Serve with lime.

preliminary_steps.item: Godamba Roti (Sri Lankan Flatbread) — Quick Home Version
ingredients: 2 tbsp (30 ml) neutral oil, plus more for cooking
steps: Mix flour, salt, and sugar. Add water and oil and knead 8–10 minutes until very smooth.
Rest covered 1 hour.
Divide into 6 balls. Oil hands and surface. Flatten each ball and stretch/roll very thin (as thin as you can).
Cook on a hot lightly oiled skillet 1–2 minutes per side until lightly browned and pliable.
Cool, then slice for kottu.

drink.description: A Sri Lankan-style sour built around Ceylon arrack (coconut sap spirit): bright lime, soft sweetness, and a foamy head.
ingredients: 3/4 oz (22 ml) simple syrup (see preliminary steps)
1 egg white (optional but traditional for foam)
steps: Dry-shake (no ice) arrack, lime, syrup, and egg white 15 seconds.
Add ice and shake hard 10–12 seconds.
Double-strain into a chilled coupe or rocks glass. Add bitters on top if using.
Warm water and sugar together just until dissolved (no need to boil).
Cool and refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

LTU.description: Named after the Zeppelin airships they resemble. These massive potato dumplings are a labor of love, made from a unique mix of raw and cooked potato dough, stuffed with meat, and drenched in a bacon-sour cream sauce.
ingredients: For filling: 1 lb ground pork (450 g)
For filling: 1 small onion, finely grated
For filling: 1 tsp kosher salt, 1/2 tsp black pepper, optional 1 clove garlic
For potato dough: 4 lb russet potatoes, peeled (1.8 kg)
For potato dough: 1 tsp kosher salt
For potato dough: 1 tbsp potato starch (optional, helps bind)
For serving: 6 oz bacon, diced (170 g)
For serving: sour cream and chopped dill
steps: Mix filling: combine ground pork with grated onion, salt, pepper (and garlic if using). Refrigerate.
Grate potatoes finely. Wrap in a towel and squeeze hard to remove liquid; let the liquid sit, then pour off and keep the potato starch at the bottom.
Combine grated potato with salt, reserved starch, and optional potato starch. The mixture should hold together when pressed; add a little starch if too wet.
With wet hands, take a large handful of potato mixture, flatten, add 1–2 tbsp filling, and shape into an oval ‘zeppelin’ around the filling. Seal well.
Bring a wide pot of salted water to a gentle simmer (not a violent boil). Slide in dumplings and simmer 25–30 minutes, turning gently once or twice.
Meanwhile, fry diced bacon until crisp; add onion and cook until golden.
Lift dumplings with a slotted spoon. Serve topped with bacon-onion, sour cream, and dill.

drink.description: A lightly fermented rye-bread drink—sweet-tart, low alcohol, and traditionally served cold.
ingredients: 8 oz dark rye bread, sliced (225 g)
1/2 cup sugar (100 g), plus more to taste
1/4 tsp active dry yeast (optional, speeds fermentation)
Optional: lemon peel or a few mint leaves
steps: Toast rye bread slices until very dark (but not fully burned) to deepen flavor.
Pour boiling water over the toasted bread in a heatproof bowl; cover and steep 6–12 hours.
Strain out the bread, pressing gently; stir in sugar until dissolved.
Cool to lukewarm; add yeast (or rely on wild yeast/raisins). Add raisins if using.
Ferment loosely covered at room temp 12–24 hours until lightly fizzy.
Strain, bottle, and refrigerate. Serve cold.

LUX.description: The national dish of Luxembourg. Smoked collar of pork (Judd) is soaked to remove salt, then boiled with vegetables and served with a creamy sauce of broad beans (Gaardebounen) and savory.
ingredients: 2 1/2 lb smoked pork collar/neck (or smoked pork shoulder), rinsed (1.1 kg)
2 lb fresh or frozen fava/broad beans (or large lima beans), shelled (900 g) (see note)
To serve: boiled potatoes and Dijon/mustard
steps: Put smoked pork in a pot and cover with water. Add onion, carrot, celery, bay leaves, and peppercorns.
Bring to a gentle simmer and cook 1 1/2–2 hours until the pork is tender (skim if needed).
Meanwhile, cook beans in salted water until tender (fresh fava beans often need 10–20 minutes; frozen are faster). Drain and keep warm.
Remove pork from broth and keep warm. Strain and reserve about 2 cups of the cooking broth.
Make a light sauce: melt butter in a saucepan, whisk in flour 1 minute, then whisk in reserved broth until lightly thickened. Season to taste.
Fold beans into the sauce (and parsley if using).
Slice pork and serve with the beans and boiled potatoes, with mustard on the side.

drink.description: A Luxembourg-leaning riff: crème de cassis topped with local Crémant—lightly sweet and very dry.
ingredients: 4–5 oz chilled Crémant de Luxembourg (120–150 ml)
steps: Chill a flute.
Add crème de cassis.
Top with Crémant and stir once gently.
Serve immediately.

LVA.description: Grey Peas with Bacon. A dish once served at Christmas to ensure prosperity, now a national staple. The unique local grey peas (similar to chickpeas) are stewed and topped with fried speck (bacon) and onions.
ingredients: 1 lb dried grey peas (or dried whole peas) (450 g)
8 cups water (1.9 L), plus more if needed
1 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
6 oz thick-cut bacon or salted pork belly, diced (170 g)
To serve: rye bread and/or sour cream (optional)
steps: Rinse peas and soak in plenty of water overnight (8–12 hours). Drain.
Simmer peas in fresh water with a pinch of salt until tender but not mushy, 45–90 minutes (time varies by pea). Drain well.
While peas cook, render diced bacon/pork belly in a skillet over medium heat until browned and the fat renders.
Add onion and cook until soft and lightly golden.
Toss drained peas into the skillet; stir to coat in the bacon fat. Add butter if using.
Season with black pepper (and more salt if needed). Serve hot.

drink.description: A popular hot serve using Riga Black Balsam Currant—warming, citrusy, and slightly bitter.
ingredients: 1 2/3 oz Riga Black Balsam Currant (50 ml)
steps: Combine balsam, red wine, and orange juice in a small saucepan.
Heat gently until hot but not boiling.
Pour into a heatproof mug or toddy glass.
Garnish with orange peel and serve hot.

Ladakh.description: A warming noodle soup essential for the cold high-altitude desert. Hand-pulled noodles are cooked in a flavorful broth with meat (mutton or yak) and local vegetables.
steps: Sauté ginger, garlic, and meat.
Add vegetables and stock. Boil.
Add noodles and cook until done.
Season with soy sauce and chili. Serve piping hot.

drink.description: A Ladakhi butter tea variant—salty, warming, and traditionally churned for froth.
steps: Blend hot tea with butter, salt, and optional milk until foamy.
Serve hot.

Lakshadweep.description: A unique island curry where the masala is made by roasting grated coconut until it is dark brown, giving the gravy a rich, nutty, and smoky flavor.
steps: Roast coconut with spices until dark brown. Grind to a paste.
Sauté onions and tomatoes.
Add chicken and seal.
Add the roasted coconut paste and water.
Simmer until chicken is tender and gravy is thick.

drink.description: Lakshadweep’s simplest and most authentic island drink: tender coconut water, ice-cold.
ingredients: 1 young coconut (or 8–12 oz / 240–355 ml coconut water)
steps: Chill and serve straight.

MAR.description: A slow-cooked stew named after the conical clay pot. Aromatic with ginger, saffron, and tangy preserved lemons.
ingredients: Spices: 1 tsp Ginger, 1 tsp Turmeric, 1/2 tsp Cumin, Saffron threads
steps: Marinate chicken with spices, garlic, and herbs for 1 hour.
In a tagine or heavy pot, sauté onions in olive oil.
Add chicken and brown slightly.
Add 1 cup water. Cover and simmer on low heat for 45 minutes.
Add the preserved lemon strips and olives. Simmer for another 15 minutes until sauce is thick.
Serve with crusty bread (Khobz) to scoop up the sauce.

drink.description: Sweet mint tea served throughout North Africa—green tea brewed with fresh mint and plenty of sugar.
ingredients: 1 tbsp Chinese green tea (gunpowder) per 3 cups water
steps: Rinse the tea leaves briefly with a splash of hot water; discard the rinse (optional but traditional for gunpowder tea).
Add tea and water to a teapot and steep 3 minutes.
Add mint and sugar; steep 2 more minutes.
Pour a small amount into a glass and return it to the pot (to mix), then serve. Traditionally poured from height to aerate.

MCO.description: Meaning 'Uncle John' in the local dialect. These savory fritters are stuffed with Swiss chard and ricotta and are traditionally eaten on Monaco's National Day. They are the taste of the Riviera.
ingredients: For dough: 2 cups all-purpose flour (260 g)
For dough: 1/2 cup water (120 ml), plus more as needed
For filling: 10 oz Swiss chard (or spinach), chopped (280 g)
For filling: 1 small onion, finely chopped
For filling: 1/2 cup grated Parmesan (50 g)
For filling: pinch of nutmeg, salt, and black pepper
steps: Make dough: mix flour and salt; add egg and water and knead until smooth, adding a little water if needed. Cover and rest 30 minutes.
Cook filling: sauté onion in olive oil until soft, add garlic 30 seconds, then add chard/spinach and cook until wilted. Cool and squeeze out excess moisture.
Mix filling with ricotta, Parmesan, egg, nutmeg, salt, and pepper.
Roll dough thin (about 1/16 inch). Cut into 3–4 inch squares or circles.
Place a spoonful of filling on each, fold, and seal well (press edges firmly).
Fry in 350°F/175°C oil until golden, 2–3 minutes, turning once. Drain on a rack.
Serve warm.

drink.description: A spirit-forward classic named for Monte Carlo: rye whiskey sweetened with Benedictine and sharpened with bitters.
steps: Fill a mixing glass with ice.
Add rye whiskey, Bénédictine, and bitters.
Stir 20–30 seconds until well chilled.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice (or serve up in a coupe).
Express an orange peel over the drink and drop it in.

MDA.description: The bread of the mountains. A dense cornmeal porridge (firmer than polenta) turned out onto a board, sliced with a string, and served with salty sheep cheese and sour cream.
ingredients: To serve (traditional): crumbled brânză/feta, sour cream, and/or fried pork (optional)
steps: Bring water and salt to a boil in a heavy pot.
Whisk in cornmeal in a steady stream to avoid lumps.
Lower heat and cook, stirring often, 15–20 minutes until very thick and pulling from the sides.
Stir in butter if using.
Turn out onto a board (it should hold its shape); slice with a string or thin knife.
Serve hot with cheese and sour cream (and/or fried pork) as desired.

drink.description: A classic sour-style cocktail using Moldovan brandy (‘Divin’): bright citrus, orange liqueur, and a sugar rim if you like.
ingredients: 3/4 oz Cointreau or other orange liqueur (22 ml)
Optional: sugar rim and lemon twist
steps: Optional: rim a coupe glass with lemon and dip in sugar; chill the glass.
Add Divin, orange liqueur, and lemon juice to a shaker with ice.
Shake hard 10–12 seconds.
Double-strain into the chilled coupe.
Garnish with a lemon twist.

MDV.dish: Mas Huni (މަސް ހުނި) — Maldivian Tuna & Coconut Salad
MDV.description: A beloved Maldivian breakfast: flaked tuna folded with grated coconut, onion, chili, and lime. Typically eaten with roshi (flatbread) and black tea.
ingredients: 2 cups (300 g) cooked tuna, flaked (or 2 cans tuna in water, drained well)
1 1/2 cups (120 g) freshly grated coconut (or unsweetened dried coconut, rehydrated)
1 small red onion, very finely chopped
2 tbsp lime juice, plus more to taste
1 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
steps: Combine tuna, coconut, onion, and chili in a bowl.
Add lime juice and salt; mix well. Taste and adjust lime/salt.
Serve with roshi or flatbread.

drink.dish: Kalhu Sai (ކަޅު ސައި) — Maldivian Black Tea
drink.description: Strong black tea served hot and sweet (sometimes with condensed milk). The everyday companion to hedhikaa and mas huni.
ingredients: 2 tsp black tea leaves (or 2 tea bags)
steps: Bring water to a boil. Add tea and steep 4–5 minutes (or simmer briefly for stronger tea).
Strain, sweeten, and add condensed milk if desired.

MEX.description: The pinnacle of Mexican gastronomy. Born in the convents of Puebla, this dark, baroque sauce blends indigenous chilies and chocolate with Old World spices and nuts. It is not just a sauce but a symphony of over 20 ingredients representing Mexico's mestizo heritage—toasted, ground, and fried until profound and silky.
ingredients: 1 disk Mexican chocolate (e.g. Ibarra or Abuelita)
1 whole chicken or turkey breast (or legs), for serving
steps: Stem and seed the dried chiles. Heat a dry skillet; toast chiles briefly until fragrant (do not burn). Soak in hot water 20–30 minutes until soft. Drain, reserving a little soaking liquid.

In the same skillet, toast almonds, peanuts, sesame seeds, cinnamon, cloves, and peppercorns until fragrant. In a blender, combine soaked chiles, toasted nuts and spices, chocolate, plantain, tortillas, charred tomato and onion, garlic, and a splash of soaking liquid; blend until very smooth.

Heat lard in a large heavy pot over medium heat. Add the mole paste (it will splatter); fry, stirring constantly, 5–8 minutes until darkened and thick. Add broth and bring to a simmer; reduce heat and cook uncovered 1–1½ hours, stirring occasionally, until thick and glossy. Season with salt.
Poach or roast the chicken or turkey separately until cooked through. Shred or slice. Serve the mole generously over the meat with white rice, warm tortillas, and a sprinkle of sesame seeds.

drink.description: Mexico's beloved highball: blanco tequila with fresh lime and grapefruit soda. One drink, one recipe—bright, salty, and refreshing.
ingredients: 4–6 oz (120–180 ml) grapefruit soda (e.g. Jarritos Toronja, Squirt, or 1:1 sparkling water + grapefruit juice)
steps: If desired, rim a highball glass with salt: rub the rim with a lime wedge and dip in a shallow dish of salt.
Fill the glass with ice. Add tequila and lime juice; add a pinch of salt and stir once.
Top with grapefruit soda and stir gently. Garnish with a lime wedge. Serve immediately.

Aguascalientes.description: Red enchiladas from the heart of Mexico: corn tortillas dipped in guajillo sauce, filled with chicken or cheese, topped with lettuce, crema, and queso fresco. Named for the state's thermal waters.
steps: Blend rehydrated guajillos, tomatoes, onion, garlic; fry into a smooth sauce.
Dip tortillas in sauce, fill with shredded chicken or cheese, roll. Place in a baking dish, top with more sauce.
Bake until heated through. Serve with crema, queso fresco, and shredded lettuce.

drink.description: Hibiscus agua fresca: tart, crimson, refreshing. One drink, one recipe.
steps: Bring water to a boil. Add hibiscus, remove from heat, cover and steep 15–20 minutes.
Strain into a pitcher; stir in sugar until dissolved. Add lime juice. Chill. Serve over ice.

Baja California.description: The original Baja-style fish taco: beer-battered white fish, crisp cabbage, crema, and salsa. Born in Ensenada, now a global icon.
ingredients: Salsa verde or pico de gallo
steps: Cut fish into strips. Dip in beer batter, fry until golden and crisp.
Warm tortillas. Top with fish, cabbage, crema, salsa, and a squeeze of lime.

drink.description: The classic: tequila, lime, and orange liqueur with a salted rim. One recipe.
steps: Rim a rocks glass with salt. In a shaker with ice, combine tequila, lime juice, Cointreau, and syrup; shake well.
Strain into the glass over fresh ice. Garnish with lime wedge.

Baja California Sur.description: Pacific coast delicacy: tender chocolate clams (almeja chocolata) 'cooked' in lime with cucumber, tomato, and cilantro. Clean, briny, and refreshing.
ingredients: 1 lb fresh chocolate clams (or small clams)
steps: Shuck clams, chop meat. Marinate in lime juice until opaque, 15–20 min.
Drain slightly; mix with diced tomato, cucumber, onion, cilantro, salt. Serve on tostadas.

drink.description: Sweet-tart tamarind agua fresca. One drink, one recipe.
ingredients: 1 lb tamarind pods (or 4 oz tamarind paste)
steps: Break tamarind pods and boil in 2 cups water 10 min. Mash and strain through a sieve into a pitcher; discard solids.
Add remaining water and sugar; stir until dissolved. Chill. Serve over ice.

Campeche.description: Layers of tortillas, black beans, shredded dogfish (cazón), and tomato sauce—a Gulf state casserole that’s hearty and distinctly Campechano.
steps: Shred cooked cazón. Fry tortillas briefly.
Layer: tortilla, beans, cazón, tomato sauce. Repeat. Top with sauce and epazote; heat through.

drink.description: Rice and cinnamon agua fresca. One drink, one recipe.
steps: Soak rice and cinnamon in 2 cups water overnight (or 2 hours). Blend until smooth; strain through cheesecloth into a pitcher.
Add remaining water, milk, sugar, and vanilla; stir. Chill. Serve over ice.

Chiapas.description: Chiapas’s Sunday feast: pork shoulder marinated in achiote, vinegar, and spices, wrapped in banana leaves and slow-roasted until fall-apart tender. Served with rice, beans, and pickled onions.
steps: Marinate pork in achiote, vinegar, garlic, cumin, and citrus overnight.
Wrap in banana leaves; roast at 300°F for 3–4 hours until tender. Serve with rice, black beans, and cebolla en escabeche.

drink.description: Pre-Hispanic maize and cacao drink: cold, frothy, lightly sweet. One recipe.
steps: Mix masa with 1 cup water until smooth; add cacao. Bring remaining water to a boil; whisk in masa-cacao mix and sugar. Simmer 10 min, stirring. Add salt.
Cool; blend until frothy or whisk vigorously. Chill. Serve cold over ice.

Chihuahua.description: The norteño burrito: large flour tortillas stuffed with machaca (dried beef), refried beans, cheese, and salsa. Hearty ranch and border food.
ingredients: Machaca (dried shredded beef) or carne seca
steps: Rehydrate and fry machaca with onion; scramble with eggs if desired.
Warm tortillas. Fill with beans, machaca, cheese, salsa. Roll and serve.

drink.description: Spiced coffee brewed with piloncillo and cinnamon. One drink, one recipe.
steps: In a pot, bring water, piloncillo, cinnamon, and orange peel (if using) to a boil; stir until piloncillo dissolves.
Add coffee; simmer 5 min. Remove from heat, cover, steep 5 min. Strain into mugs. Serve hot.

Ciudad de México.description: The capital’s street icon: thin slices of pork marinated in achiote and pineapple, cooked on a vertical trompo, then carved onto small tortillas with cilantro, onion, and lime. Lebanese-Mexican fusion at its best.
steps: Marinate pork in achiote, vinegar, blended guajillos, and pineapple juice. Stack on a spit or roast in oven with pineapple.
Slice crispy edges onto tortillas. Top with cilantro, onion, lime, and a bite of pineapple.

drink.description: Beer with lime, salt, Worcestershire and hot sauce. One drink, one recipe.
ingredients: Salt and Tajín or chile powder for rim
steps: Rim a tall glass with lime juice and salt (or Tajín). Fill with ice. Squeeze in lime juice; add Worcestershire and hot sauce.
Pour beer into the glass; stir gently. Serve immediately.

Coahuila.description: Whole kid goat roasted over mesquite—the definitive norteño celebration dish. Tender, smoky, and served with tortillas, salsa, and beans.
steps: Season cabrito with salt and lime. Roast over mesquite (or in a very hot oven) until skin is crisp and meat is tender.
Carve and serve with warm tortillas, salsa verde, and frijoles charros.

drink.description: Red wine with citrus and a splash of soda. One recipe.
ingredients: 2 cups lemon-lime soda or sparkling water
steps: In a pitcher, combine wine, orange juice, and sugar; stir until sugar dissolves. Add orange and lime slices.
Chill 1 hour. To serve, add soda and ice; stir gently.

Colima.description: Pork braised in a rich, dark sauce of chilies, vinegar, and spices—Colima’s beloved weekend dish. Served with rice and tortillas.
steps: Sear pork; set aside. Blend rehydrated chiles with vinegar, garlic, spices.
Return pork to pot; add sauce. Braise 1½–2 hours until tender. Serve with rice and tortillas.

drink.description: Fresh limeade: tart, sweet, refreshing. One recipe.
steps: In a pitcher, stir lime juice and sugar until sugar dissolves. Add water and stir.
Serve over ice with lime slices.

Durango.description: Beef and green tomato stew with potatoes and green chile—comfort food from the high desert. Simple, warming, and satisfying.
steps: Brown beef; add blended tomatillos, garlic, and chile. Simmer.
Add potato cubes; cook until tender. Finish with cilantro. Serve with tortillas.

drink.description: Spiced coffee with piloncillo and cinnamon. One recipe.
steps: Bring water and piloncillo to a boil in a pot; add cinnamon. Stir until piloncillo dissolves.
Add coffee; simmer 5 min. Steep 5 min off heat. Strain into mugs. Serve hot.

Guanajuato.description: Mining country enchiladas: tortillas dipped in guajillo sauce, filled with cheese or chicken, topped with potatoes, carrots, and crema. Hearty and colorful.
steps: Make guajillo sauce; fry tortillas briefly in oil, dip in sauce. Fill with cheese.
Top with boiled potato and carrot dice, crema, and shredded lettuce.

drink.description: Mexican hot chocolate with cinnamon. One recipe.
steps: Heat milk with cinnamon stick until steaming; do not boil. Add chocolate and salt; whisk until melted and frothy.
Remove cinnamon. Add almond extract if using. Pour into mugs. Serve hot.

Guerrero.description: Acapulco and Chilpancingo’s green pozole: hominy and pork in a vibrant sauce of pumpkin seeds, tomatillos, and green chile. Topped with radish, oregano, and lime.
steps: Cook pork and hominy until tender. Blend tomatillos, pumpkin seeds, and chile for green sauce.
Add sauce to the broth; simmer. Serve in bowls with cabbage, radish, oregano, and lime.

drink.description: Coconut limeade: creamy and tart. One recipe.
ingredients: 1 cup coconut cream or full-fat coconut milk
steps: In a pitcher, whisk lime juice, coconut cream, and sugar until sugar dissolves. Add water; stir.
Chill. Serve over ice.

Hidalgo.description: Lamb or mutton slow-steamed in maguey leaves (or banana leaves) until meltingly tender. The original barbacoa—served with consommé, salsa, and tortillas.
ingredients: Lamb or mutton (head, ribs, or leg)
steps: Season meat; wrap in leaves. Steam in a pit or large pot 6–8 hours until fall-apart tender.
Strain cooking liquid for consommé. Serve meat with consommé, salsa, cilantro, and tortillas.

drink.description: Warm atole with guava: thick, sweet, comforting. One recipe.
ingredients: 1 cup guava paste or puréed guava
steps: Whisk masa with 1 cup milk until smooth. In a pot, heat remaining milk with cinnamon and piloncillo; add masa mixture and guava. Cook over medium heat, stirring, 10–15 min until thick.
Remove cinnamon. Serve hot in mugs.

Jalisco.description: Goat or beef stewed in a complex mix of dried chiles, vinegar, and spices. Served as a consomé with tender meat, or in tacos dipped in the broth. The soul of Jalisco.
steps: Blend rehydrated chiles with vinegar and spices. Marinate meat; braise until tender, 2–3 hours.
Strain broth. Shred meat. Serve as consomé with meat, or dip tortillas in broth, fill with meat, and pan-fry for birria tacos.

drink.description: Tequila, lime, and grapefruit soda. Jalisco signature cocktail. One recipe.
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice. Add tequila, lime juice, and salt; stir. Top with grapefruit soda. Garnish with lime wedge.

México.description: Lamb barbacoa slow-steamed in the traditional way—often in a pit or large pot with maguey leaves. Served with consommé, salsa borracha, and fresh tortillas.
steps: Season lamb; wrap in leaves. Steam 6–8 hours until very tender.
Reserve consommé. Serve meat with consommé, salsa, onion, cilantro, and tortillas.

drink.description: Oat atole: creamy, warm, lightly spiced. One recipe.
steps: Blend oats with 1 cup milk until smooth. In a pot, heat remaining milk with cinnamon and piloncillo; add oat mixture. Simmer 8–10 min, stirring, until thick.
Remove cinnamon; add salt and vanilla. Serve hot.

Michoacán.description: Pork confit: chunks of pork shoulder and belly simmered in lard (or oil) until crisp outside and tender inside. A Michoacán original, served with tortillas, salsa, and lime.
ingredients: 3 lbs pork shoulder (and belly if possible)
steps: Cut pork into chunks. Cook in lard with orange, cinnamon, bay leaf, and salt (and a splash of milk for crispness) until golden and tender.
Serve with warm tortillas, salsa verde, lime, and cilantro.

drink.description: Blackberry atole: fruity and warm. One recipe.
steps: Whisk masa with 1 cup milk. Puree blackberries; strain seeds. Heat remaining milk with cinnamon and sugar; add masa mix and berry puree. Cook, stirring, 10 min until thick.
Remove cinnamon. Serve hot.

Morelos.description: Cuernavaca’s 'armored' tacos: a bed of rice topped with breaded beef or milanesa, salsa, and avocado. A full meal on a plate.
steps: Cook rice. Bread and fry beef cutlets (milanesa).
Serve a portion of rice with a milanesa on top, salsa, and avocado. Eat with tortillas.

drink.description: Mexican eggnog: rich, spiced, silky. One recipe.
steps: Heat milk with cinnamon and half the sugar until steaming. Whisk yolks with remaining sugar; temper with hot milk, then pour back into pot. Cook over low heat, stirring, until thick (do not boil).
Remove cinnamon; add vanilla and rum if using. Chill. Serve cold.

Nayarit.description: Whole fish (often red snapper) butterflied, marinated in achiote, soy, and lime, then grilled over wood. A Pacific coast classic from San Blas and beyond.
steps: Butterfly fish; marinate in achiote, soy, lime, and butter 1–2 hours.
Grill over medium heat until charred and cooked through. Serve with tortillas, lime, and salsa.

drink.description: Tequila, lime, and grapefruit soda. One recipe.
steps: Rim glass with salt. Fill with ice. Add tequila and lime; top with grapefruit soda. Garnish with lime wedge.

Nuevo León.description: Kid goat roasted in the oven—Monterrey’s signature. Tender, mild, and served with salsa, beans, and flour tortillas.
steps: Season cabrito with salt, pepper, garlic, lime. Roast in oven at 300°F until tender and golden.
Carve; serve with salsa, frijoles a la charra, and flour tortillas.

drink.description: Espresso with Licor 43: sweet, creamy, strong. One recipe.
steps: Brew espresso. Pour Licor 43 into a glass; add hot espresso and stir (or pour over ice for iced).
Garnish with lemon peel if desired. Serve immediately.

Oaxaca.description: Oaxaca’s most famous mole: a deep, complex sauce of chilhuacle negro, mulato, pasilla, chocolate, nuts, seeds, and fruit. Days of work for a dish that defines Mexican grandeur.
steps: Char and rehydrate chiles. Toast nuts, seeds, spices; blend with chiles, plantain, tortilla, and chocolate into a paste.
Fry paste in oil; add broth and chocolate. Simmer until thick. Poach chicken; serve mole over chicken with rice.

drink.dish: Mezcal con Naranja y Sal de Gusano
drink.description: Oaxacan way to drink mezcal: orange and sal de gusano on the rim. One recipe.
ingredients: 1 tsp sal de gusano (worm salt with chile)
steps: Rim a copita or small glass with a squeeze of orange and dip in sal de gusano.
Pour mezcal into the glass. Serve with an orange slice on the side. Sip slowly.

Puebla.description: The convent-born masterpiece: turkey or chicken in a sauce of mulato, ancho, pasilla, chocolate, nuts, seeds, and spices. Puebla’s gift to the world.
steps: Rehydrate and blend chiles with toasted nuts, seeds, fruit, chocolate. Fry paste; add broth, simmer until thick.
Poach turkey or chicken. Serve mole over the meat with sesame and rice.

drink.description: Puebla's eggnog: rich, spiced, silky. One recipe.
steps: Heat milk with cinnamon and half the sugar until steaming. Whisk yolks with remaining sugar; temper with hot milk, then pour back into pot. Cook over low heat, stirring, until thick (do not boil).
Remove cinnamon; add vanilla and rum if using. Chill. Serve cold.

Querétaro.description: Tortillas in a guajillo and ancho sauce, filled with cheese and onion, topped with potato, carrot, crema, and queso fresco. A hearty, colorful plate.
steps: Make red sauce from guajillo and ancho. Dip fried tortillas in sauce; fill with cheese and onion.
Top with boiled potato and carrot dice, crema, and queso fresco.

drink.description: Mexican hot chocolate with cinnamon. One recipe.
steps: Heat milk with cinnamon until steaming. Add chocolate and salt; whisk until melted and frothy. Remove cinnamon. Serve hot in mugs.

Quintana Roo.description: Yucatecan pork marinated in achiote and sour orange, wrapped in banana leaves and slow-roasted. Quintana Roo shares this Caribbean-Maya classic—tender, tangy, and unforgettable.
steps: Marinate pork in achiote and sour orange overnight. Wrap in banana leaves.
Roast at 300°F for 2–3 hours until tender. Shred; serve in tacos with pickled red onion and habanero salsa.

drink.description: Rice and cinnamon agua fresca. One recipe.
steps: Soak rice and cinnamon in 2 cups water overnight (or 2 hours). Blend until smooth; strain through cheesecloth into a pitcher.
Add remaining water, milk, sugar, and vanilla; stir. Chill. Serve over ice.

San Luis Potosí.description: Red enchiladas made with cheese-stuffed masa (the tortilla itself contains cheese). Served with more cheese, crema, and lettuce—rich and satisfying.
steps: Mix masa with cheese; form small thick tortillas. Fry lightly.
Dip in guajillo sauce; serve with crema and shredded lettuce.

drink.description: Spiced coffee with piloncillo and cinnamon. One recipe.
steps: Bring water and piloncillo to a boil; add cinnamon. Stir until piloncillo dissolves. Add coffee; simmer 5 min. Steep 5 min off heat. Strain into mugs. Serve hot.

Sinaloa.description: Raw shrimp or fish 'cooked' in lime and puréed cucumber, serrano, and cilantro. Sinaloa’s answer to ceviche—spicy, bright, and addictive.
steps: Blend cucumber, serrano, cilantro, and some lime into a smooth liquid. Season with salt.
Toss shrimp in lime and aguachile mix; let sit 5–10 min. Serve on tostadas with sliced onion.

drink.description: Beer with lime, salt, and spices. One recipe.
steps: Rim a tall glass with lime and salt (or Tajín). Fill with ice. Squeeze in lime; add Worcestershire and hot sauce. Pour beer; stir gently. Serve immediately.

Sonora.description: Grilled beef (often arrachera or skirt steak) with flour tortillas, frijoles, and salsa. The definitive norteño grill—simple, bold, and perfect.
steps: Marinate beef with lime, salt, and optional beer. Grill to desired doneness.
Slice; serve with warm flour tortillas, beans, salsa, lime, and guacamole.

drink.description: Fresh limeade. One recipe.
steps: In a pitcher, stir lime juice and sugar until sugar dissolves. Add water. Serve over ice with lime slices.

Tabasco.description: Garfish (pejelagarto) baked in banana leaves with achiote and herbs—a Tabasco river specialty. Unique flavor and texture.
steps: Season fish with achiote. Wrap in banana leaves with tomato and herbs.
Bake until cooked through. Serve with rice and pickled onions.

drink.description: Fermented cacao drink or Tabasco’s famous chocolate.
steps: Make pozol or hot chocolate; serve cold or hot.

Tamaulipas.description: A full plate: grilled beef strip, enchilada, guacamole, refried beans, and rice. Born in Tampico—hearty and satisfying.
steps: Grill beef. Make enchiladas with guajillo sauce.
Plate: rice, beans, sliced beef, one or two enchiladas, guacamole. Serve with tortillas.

drink.description: Fruit and wine punch. One recipe.
steps: In a pitcher, combine wine, orange juice, brandy, and sugar; stir until sugar dissolves. Add fruit; chill 1–2 hours. Serve over ice.

Tlaxcala.description: Goat meat and spine in a rich, spicy mole—a Tlaxcalan festival dish. Complex and deeply traditional.
steps: Cook goat until tender. Blend chiles, tomato, garlic, spices into mole.
Combine meat and mole; simmer. Serve with rice and tortillas.

drink.description: Oat atole: warming and comforting. One recipe.
steps: Blend oats with 1 cup milk until smooth. Heat remaining milk with cinnamon and piloncillo until steaming.
Whisk in oat mixture; simmer, stirring, 8–10 min until thick. Remove cinnamon. Serve hot.

Veracruz.description: Whole red snapper in a sauce of tomatoes, olives, capers, and jalapeños—Spanish-Mexican fusion from the port. Bright, briny, and iconic.
steps: Sauté onion, garlic; add tomatoes, olives, capers, jalapeños, bay leaf. Simmer into a sauce.
Place fish in a pan; pour sauce over. Bake or poach until fish is cooked. Serve with rice.

drink.description: Veracruz peanut-and-rum cream drink. One recipe.
steps: Blend rum, peanut butter, condensed milk, and ice until smooth and frothy. Pour into a glass. Serve immediately.

Yucatán.description: Pork marinated in achiote and sour orange, wrapped in banana leaves and slow-roasted until tender. The Yucatán’s most famous dish—served in tacos with pickled red onion.
steps: Marinate pork in achiote and sour orange 4–24 hours. Wrap in banana leaves.
Roast at 300°F for 2–3 hours. Shred; serve in tortillas with cebolla en escabeche and habanero salsa.

drink.description: Rice and cinnamon agua fresca. One recipe.
steps: Soak rice and cinnamon in 2 cups water overnight (or 2 hours). Blend until smooth; strain through cheesecloth into a pitcher.
Add remaining water, milk, sugar, and vanilla; stir. Chill. Serve over ice.

Zacatecas.description: Pork in a rich, sweet-savory sauce of ancho chiles, cinnamon, and piloncillo—Zacatecas’s wedding dish. Served with rice and tortillas.
steps: Blend rehydrated anchos with piloncillo, spices, garlic, vinegar. Strain.
Brown pork; add sauce. Simmer until tender. Serve with rice and tortillas.

drink.description: Spiced coffee with piloncillo and cinnamon. One recipe.
steps: Bring water and piloncillo to a boil; add cinnamon. Stir until piloncillo dissolves. Add coffee; simmer 5 min. Steep 5 min off heat. Strain into mugs. Serve hot.

MKD.description: Beans in a skillet. White beans are stewed with paprika and mint, then baked in traditional earthenware pots until a crust forms. It is the Friday lunch staple of North Macedonia.
ingredients: 1 lb dried white beans (Great Northern or cannellini) (450 g)
8 cups water (1.9 L), plus more as needed
steps: Soak beans overnight in plenty of water. Drain.
Simmer beans in fresh water with bay leaves until just tender, 45–75 minutes. Drain, reserving 2 cups of cooking liquid.
Sauté onion and pepper in olive oil until very soft and lightly caramelized.
Stir in paprika (and tomato paste if using) for 30 seconds, then add beans, mint, salt, and pepper.
Transfer to a baking dish (ideally an earthenware tavче). Add enough reserved bean liquid to keep beans just covered.
Bake at 375°F/190°C for 30–45 minutes until the top is lightly crusted and the sauce thickens.
Rest 10 minutes and serve warm.

drink.description: A honey-sweetened rakija infusion popular across the Balkans; easy to make at home and served as a digestif.
steps: Combine rakija, honey, lemon peel (and cinnamon if using) in a clean jar.
Seal and shake until the honey is dissolved.
Let steep 2–3 days, shaking once daily.
Strain if you want a clearer drink; bottle.
Serve at room temp or lightly chilled.

MLT.description: Rabbit Stew. A dish of resistance—when the Knights of St. John restricted rabbit hunting, locals mastered cooking it as a form of defiance. Slow-cooked in red wine, tomato, and garlic until tender.
steps: Marinate rabbit in wine and garlic overnight.
Sear rabbit pieces. Remove.
Fry onions and garlic. Add tomato paste and the marinade wine.
Return rabbit. Simmer for 2 hours until tender.
Add peas near the end.
Serve sauce with pasta first, then rabbit as main, or all together with potatoes.

drink.description: A Maltese highball built on Kinnie’s bitter-sweet citrus bite—mixed with gin and amaro, finished with mint.
ingredients: 1–2 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz simple syrup) (to taste)
Garnish: mint sprig and lime wedges
steps: Add gin, amaro, lime juice, sugar, a mint sprig, and ice to a shaker.
Shake briefly to chill, then strain into a highball filled with fresh ice and lime wedges.
Top with Kinnie.
Garnish with mint and serve.

MMR.dish: Mohinga (မုန့်ဟင်းခါး) — Myanmar Fish Noodle Soup
MMR.description: Myanmar’s national dish: a fragrant fish broth thickened lightly, poured over rice noodles, and finished with crispy toppings, eggs, and herbs—breakfast, comfort, and identity in a bowl.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) catfish fillets (or other firm fish)
2 tbsp fish sauce, plus more to taste
2 tbsp toasted rice powder (see preliminary steps) or 3 tbsp chickpea flour
1 lb (450 g) rice vermicelli noodles, cooked
To serve: hard-boiled eggs, chopped cilantro, lime wedges, fried onions, chili oil
steps: Simmer fish with water and lemongrass 12–15 minutes until cooked. Remove fish; strain broth and discard lemongrass.
Flake fish finely, removing bones.
In a pot, heat oil and sauté onion until soft. Add garlic, ginger, and turmeric; cook 1 minute.
Add strained broth, flaked fish, and fish sauce. Simmer 10 minutes.
Whisk toasted rice powder (or chickpea flour) with a little cool water to make a slurry. Stir into soup and simmer 5 minutes until lightly thickened. Adjust seasoning.
Serve over cooked noodles with eggs, herbs, lime, and toppings.
Toast rice in a dry skillet over medium heat until golden and nutty, 10–12 minutes.
Cool, then grind to a fine powder.
Store airtight up to 1 month.

drink.dish: Laphet Yay Cho (လက်ဖက်ရည်ချို) — Burmese Milk Tea
drink.description: Rich, sweet black tea balanced with condensed milk (often with evaporated milk). Tea-shop essential across Myanmar.
ingredients: 2 tbsp loose black tea (or 3 tea bags)
steps: Bring water to a boil and steep tea 5 minutes for a strong brew; strain.
Stir in condensed milk (and evaporated milk if using). Taste and adjust sweetness.
Serve hot or over ice.

MNE.description: A heavy mountain dish designed for energy. Potatoes and wheat flour are mashed together for an hour until elastic, then melted with 'kajmak' (clotted cream) and cheese. It is a fondue-like texture eaten with wooden spoons.
ingredients: 2 large potatoes, peeled and diced small (about 12 oz / 340 g)
1 cup crumbled white cheese (sir/young cheese, feta works) (150 g)
steps: Boil diced potatoes in salted water until very tender, 12–15 minutes. Do not drain; keep the starchy water.
With the pot at a gentle boil, whisk in cornmeal in a steady stream.
Lower heat and cook, stirring often, until thick and pulling from the sides, 10–15 minutes.
Stir in butter and half the cheese until glossy.
Spoon into bowls and top with the remaining cheese. Serve hot.

drink.description: A Balkan winter warmer: rakija heated gently with sugar and spices—served hot, never boiled.
ingredients: 1 tbsp sugar or honey (15–20 g), to taste
steps: Combine rakija, sugar/honey, lemon peel, peppercorns (and cinnamon if using) in a small saucepan.
Warm very gently over low heat until steaming—do not boil.
Taste and adjust sweetness.
Strain into a small heatproof glass or mug.
Serve hot.

MNG.description: Mongolia’s celebratory dumplings: juicy meat filling sealed in pleated dough and steamed, especially for Tsagaan Sar (Lunar New Year).
ingredients: For dough: 3 cups (360 g) all-purpose flour
For filling: 1 lb (450 g) ground lamb or beef
1/2 cup finely chopped cabbage (optional but common)
steps: Make dough: mix flour and salt, add water, knead until smooth. Rest 30 minutes.
Mix filling ingredients thoroughly; the water keeps it juicy.
Divide dough into 24 pieces. Roll each into a 3–4 inch (8–10 cm) round.
Place 1–2 tbsp filling in center. Pleat edges upward, leaving a small vent hole at the top.
Steam over boiling water 12–15 minutes until cooked through.
Serve hot.

drink.dish: Suutei Tsai (Сүүтэй цай) — Mongolian Milk Tea
drink.description: Salty milk tea brewed with tea leaves and sometimes enriched with a bit of fat—everyday warmth on the steppe.
ingredients: 1 tbsp loose green tea (or 2 green tea bags)
steps: Bring water to a simmer, add tea, and simmer 3 minutes.
Add milk and return to a gentle simmer 5 minutes.
Season with salt (and butter if using). Strain and serve hot.

MSR.description: The national obsession of the Emerald Isle of the Caribbean. Despite the thin-sounding name, this is a rich, dark, clove-scented stew inspired by Irish Irish stew but adapted with goat meat, rum, and tropical spices. It is the centerpiece of every celebration.
steps: Sear goat meat in oil. Remove.
Sauté onions and garlic. Add meat back.
Add water, herbs, and spices. Simmer for 2 hours until tender.
Mix flour with water to make a paste. Stir into stew to thicken slightly.
Add a splash of rum/whiskey at the end.
Serve with crusty bread rolls.

drink.description: Montserrat is known for “bush rum”—rum infused with local herbs/spices. This is a practical home version.
steps: Combine in a jar, seal, and infuse 5–14 days.
Strain.
Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) neat or over ice.

MTQ.description: A vibrant red fish stew that captures the Creole spirit. Unlike a French court-bouillon which is a poaching liquid, this is a rich tomato sauce enriched with roucou (annatto) oil and fiery peppers, in which lime-marinated fish is gently poached.
ingredients: 2 lbs Red Snapper or similar fish (whole or steaks)
steps: Marinate fish in lime juice, garlic, and salt for 1 hour.
Sauté onion, scallion, and tomatoes in oil (roucou oil traditionally for red color).
Add water and bring to a boil to make a broth.
Add the fish and the marinade liquid.
Add the whole pepper. Simmer gently for 15-20 mins.
Serve with boiled cassava or breadfruit.

drink.description: Martinique’s signature: rhum agricole, lime coin, and cane sugar—bracing and aromatic.
ingredients: 1 tsp cane sugar or 1 sugar cube
steps: Add sugar and lime coin to a small glass.
Pour in rum and stir briefly.
Sip (often without ice).

MYS.description: Malaysia's national obsession. Fragrant coconut rice served with spicy sambal, anchovies, peanuts, and egg.
ingredients: Sambal: Dried chilies (blended), Onion, Garlic, Tamarind paste, Sugar, Shrimp paste (Belacan)
Garnishes: Fried Anchovies (Ikan Bilis), Roasted Peanuts, Cucumber slices, Hard-boiled eggs
steps: Rice: Wash rice. Cook with coconut milk, water, pandan leaves, and a pinch of salt in a rice cooker.
Sambal: Fry blended chili paste with onions and garlic in oil until oil separates. Add tamarind, sugar, and salt. Cook until deep red and thick.
Fry anchovies and peanuts until crispy.
Serve a mound of coconut rice on a banana leaf.
Top with a ladle of sambal, and arrange the anchovies, peanuts, cucumber, and egg around it.

drink.description: Malaysia’s iconic “pulled tea” with froth from repeatedly pouring between cups.
steps: Steep tea 3–5 minutes and strain.
Stir in condensed milk.
Pour back and forth between two cups to aerate and foam.
Serve hot.
Soak tamarind pulp in hot water 15–20 minutes.
Mash thoroughly, then press through a sieve to remove fibers/seeds.
Use immediately or refrigerate up to 1 week.
Shrimp paste is a fermented ingredient; for authenticity, purchase it.
Toast a small piece briefly in a dry pan or wrap in foil and heat until fragrant, then mash into the sauce/curry.

NGA.description: The smoky, spicy, tomato-rice dish that defines West African cuisine. The 'party' version is best.
ingredients: Base: 4 Red Bell Peppers, 3 Habanero/Scotch Bonnet peppers, 2 Onions, 4 Tomatoes (blended)
Spices: Curry powder, Thyme, Bay leaves, Bouillon cubes
steps: Heat oil. Fry sliced onions. Add tomato paste and fry for 5 mins (remove sourness).
Add the blended pepper mixture. Cook down for 15-20 mins until oil floats on top.
Add stock, spices, and salt. Bring to boil.
Wash rice thoroughly. Add to the pot. The liquid should just cover the rice.
Cover tightly with foil and a lid (steam cooks it). Turn heat to low.
Cook for 20-30 mins. Allow the bottom to burn slightly ('party jollof' smoky flavor).
Stir and serve with fried plantains and chicken.

drink.description: A traditional West African drink made from palm sap, served fresh or lightly fermented.
steps: Serve chilled.

NIC.description: A pre-Columbian survivor. 'Old Indian' is a thick, porridge-like stew that dates back to indigenous times. Shredded beef is cooked with maize dough (masa) and flavored with sour orange and mint, creating a hearty dish that is pure Nicaraguan history.
steps: Boil beef with garlic and onion until tender. Shred the meat. Save broth.
Blend the soaked tortillas with some broth to make a smooth batter.
Sauté onion, pepper, and tomato with achiote.
Add the shredded beef and fry briefly.
Pour in the tortilla batter and remaining broth. Stir constantly as it thickens.
Add sour orange juice and fresh mint. Simmer until it reaches a porridge-like consistency.
Serve with fried plantains and cuajada (cheese).

drink.description: Nicaragua’s national cocktail: rum blended with guava and lemon—fruity, bright, and tropical.
steps: Fill a shaker with ice.
Add rum, guava juice, lemon juice, and optional simple syrup.
Shake until very cold.
Strain into an ice-filled glass and serve.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.
Toast achiote seeds 30–60 seconds.
Blend or grind seeds with vinegar, garlic, salt (and cumin) until a red paste forms.
Strain if gritty. Refrigerate up to 1 week.

NLD.description: The ultimate Dutch winter comfort. Potatoes mashed with curly kale, served with a giant smoked rookworst sausage and a dimple of gravy. It is simple, hearty, and quintessentially Dutch.
steps: Boil potatoes and kale in the same pot (kale on top) for 20 mins.
Place sausage on top to steam for the last 10 mins.
Remove sausage. Drain water.
Mash potatoes and kale with milk and butter.
Stir in crispy bacon bits.
Serve with sliced sausage and a well of gravy in the center.

drink.description: A Dutch bar tradition: an ice-cold tulip glass of genever paired with a small beer—sip the genever first, then chase with beer.
ingredients: 1 1/2 oz jonge genever, very cold (45 ml)
steps: Chill the genever glass (a small tulip) and the beer glass.
Pour genever to the brim of the tulip glass (so full you shouldn’t lift it at first).
Take the first sip by bending down to the glass.
Then drink the beer alongside it, alternating as you like.
Serve immediately while both are cold.

NOR.description: Mutton in Cabbage. Norway's national dish is deceptively simple: layers of mutton and cabbage, peppercorns, and water, steamed until tender. It is celebrated every autumn with its own national day.
ingredients: 3 lb lamb shoulder (bone-in), cut into large chunks (1.4 kg)
1 large green cabbage, cut into wedges (about 2 lb / 900 g)
1 1/2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
2 tbsp all-purpose flour (for thickening, optional but common)
2 cups water (480 ml), plus more if needed
steps: In a heavy pot, layer lamb and cabbage wedges, sprinkling some salt, peppercorns, and a little flour between layers.
Pour in water; it should come about 1/3 of the way up the ingredients (add more if needed).
Bring to a gentle simmer, cover, and cook very low 2–2 1/2 hours until lamb is tender and cabbage is soft.
Taste broth and adjust salt.
Serve hot, traditionally with boiled potatoes on the side.

drink.description: Norwegian gløgg: mulled red wine steeped with spices and citrus, often finished with a splash of aquavit and served with raisins and almonds.
steps: In a pot, warm water and sugar with orange zest/peel and spices until sugar dissolves.
Add red wine and heat gently until steaming (do not boil).
Cover and steep 20–30 minutes off heat.
Stir in raisins and almonds.
Add aquavit off heat if using.
Ladle into mugs and serve hot.

NPL.description: Nepal’s everyday national meal: lentil soup (dal) with rice (bhat) and a simple vegetable curry (tarkari). It’s practical, balanced, and endlessly variable from home to home.
ingredients: For dal: 1 cup (200 g) red lentils, rinsed
For bhat: 2 cups (400 g) basmati rice, rinsed
To finish: chopped cilantro, lime wedges
steps: Dal: simmer lentils with water, turmeric, and salt until soft, 15–20 minutes.
Tadka: heat oil/ghee, add cumin; when it sizzles add onion, garlic, and ginger; cook until golden. Add tomato and cook until jammy.
Stir tadka into dal and simmer 5 minutes. Adjust thickness with water and salt to taste.
Bhat: cook rice with water (rice cooker or covered pot) until tender; fluff.
Tarkari: heat oil, add cumin. Stir in coriander/curry powder. Add potatoes and cauliflower, toss to coat, add water, cover and simmer 12–15 minutes until tender. Salt to taste.
Serve rice with a ladle of dal and a scoop of tarkari; finish with cilantro and lime.

drink.dish: Masala Chiya (मसला चिया) — Nepali Spiced Milk Tea
drink.description: Nepal’s daily tea: black tea simmered with warming spices and milk, sweetened to taste.
ingredients: 2 tsp black tea leaves (or 2 tea bags)
steps: Simmer water with ginger, cardamom, and cinnamon 4–5 minutes.
Add tea and simmer 2 minutes.
Add milk and sugar and simmer 3–4 minutes. Strain and serve hot.

NZL.description: A Sunday roast tradition. Tender leg of lamb served with sweet potatoes (Kumara) and mint sauce.
ingredients: 2 lbs Kumara (Sweet Potato), peeled and chunked
Mint Sauce: Fresh mint, Sugar, Vinegar, Boiling water
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C).
Make small incisions in the lamb. Stuff with garlic slivers and rosemary.
Rub lamb with oil, salt, and pepper. Place in roasting pan.
Roast for 1 hour 30 mins (medium).
Add kumara chunks to the pan around the lamb for the last 45 minutes. Toss in the meat juices.
Rest meat for 20 mins before carving.
Mix chopped mint with sugar and boiling water, then add vinegar. Serve sauce with the lamb.

drink.description: A classic Australian/New Zealand mixed drink: bright citrus with a few dashes of aromatic bitters.
ingredients: 1 tbsp lime cordial (or 1/2 oz fresh lime juice + 1 tsp simple syrup)
steps: Fill a glass with ice.
Add lime cordial (or lime juice + simple syrup).
Top with lemonade and add bitters.
Stir gently and garnish with lime if desired.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: Zest of 4 limes (use a microplane; avoid bitter white pith)
steps: Rub lime zest into sugar with your fingers until fragrant (this pulls out citrus oils).
Add lime juice and stir until sugar dissolves (or warm gently to dissolve faster, then cool).
Bottle and refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

OMN.description: Oman’s festival centerpiece: meat marinated with spices and aromatics and cooked slowly until it falls apart. Traditionally buried in a sand oven; at home, low-and-slow roasting gets you close.
ingredients: 2 tsp ground paprika or mild chili
1 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
1 cup (240 ml) water or stock (for roasting pan)
steps: Mix garlic, ginger, vinegar, oil, spices, and salt into a paste. Rub all over lamb. Cover and marinate 8–24 hours.
Heat oven to 300°F (150°C). Place lamb in a roasting pan; add water/stock to the pan.
Cover tightly with foil (or wrap lamb in parchment then foil). Roast 3 1/2–4 1/2 hours until very tender.
Uncover and roast 10–15 minutes to brown slightly.
Rest 15 minutes, then shred or slice. Serve with rice and salad.

drink.description: Oman’s aromatic coffee—light-bodied and spiced with cardamom and often saffron—served with dates as a ritual of welcome.
ingredients: 2 tbsp (10–12 g) lightly roasted ground coffee
steps: Bring water to a gentle boil. Add coffee and simmer 8–10 minutes.
Add cardamom, saffron (and cloves if using) and simmer 3–5 minutes.
Let settle, strain, and serve in small cups.

PAK.description: A rich, slow-cooked stew made with beef shank and marrow bones, thickened with flour. Traditionally eaten for breakfast.
ingredients: Nihari Masala: Fennel seeds, Dry Ginger, Cumin, Cloves, Cardamom, Cinnamon, Chili powder
Garnish: Ginger julienne, Green chilies, Cilantro, Lemon wedges
steps: Heat oil. Fry onions until golden. Add meat and sear well.
Add the Nihari spices and salt. Fry for a few minutes.
Add 6-8 cups of water. Cover and simmer on low heat for 4-6 hours until meat is falling off the bone.
Slowly stir in the dissolved flour to thicken the gravy.
Simmer for another 15 minutes.
Serve hot, topped generously with fresh ginger, chilies, and a squeeze of lemon. Best with Naan.

drink.description: Pakistani-style milk tea, typically strong and sweet.
steps: Bring milk to a gentle simmer.
Add tea and simmer 3–5 minutes.
Strain and sweeten.
Toast whole fennel seeds briefly and grind (if using whole).
Mix with remaining spices.
Store airtight up to 3 months.

Punjab.description: Punjab’s iconic wok-style curry: chicken and tomatoes cooked in a karahi (or heavy pan) with ginger, green chilies, and minimal spices so the poultry and tomato shine. Technique: high heat to char tomatoes and reduce the gravy; finish with fresh cilantro and ginger.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) bone-in chicken, cut into pieces
1/4 cup (60 ml) neutral oil or ghee
1 tbsp ginger paste, 1 tbsp garlic paste
1 tsp red chili powder (or to taste)
Fresh cilantro and ginger julienne, for garnish
steps: In a karahi or wide heavy pan, heat the oil. Add cumin seeds; when they sizzle, add ginger and garlic paste. Fry 1 min.
Add the chicken and sear over high heat 4–5 min. Add turmeric, chili powder, coriander powder, and salt; stir.
Add the tomatoes and green chilies. Cook over high heat, stirring, until the tomatoes break down and the oil separates, 15–20 min. The gravy should be thick and clinging to the chicken.
Garnish with cilantro and ginger. Serve hot with naan or roti.

drink.description: Cooling yogurt drink.
ingredients: Pinch of salt or sugar to taste
steps: Blend yogurt with water; season. Serve cold.

Sindh.description: Layered rice and meat biryani from Sindh: marinated meat (or potatoes), fragrant basmati, and a distinct layer of yogurt-mint-chili. Technique: parboil rice; layer with partially cooked meat and potatoes; seal and cook on dum (trapped steam) so the flavors meld.
ingredients: 2 cups (400 g) basmati rice, soaked 30 min
1 lb (450 g) beef or mutton, cubed
2 onions, sliced and fried until golden (birista)
2 tbsp biryani masala (or mix of cumin, coriander, cardamom, cloves, cinnamon)
Saffron soaked in 2 tbsp warm milk (optional)
steps: Marinate the meat with half the yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, half the biryani masala, and salt 1–2 hours. In a pot, brown the meat; add a little water and cook until nearly tender. Add potatoes and cook until just done. Set aside.
Parboil the rice in plenty of salted water until 70% done; drain.

In a heavy pot, layer: half the rice, then meat and potatoes, fried onion, mint, cilantro, remaining yogurt and masala, then remaining rice. Drizzle saffron milk and a little ghee. Cover tightly; cook on very low heat (dum) 25–30 min. Rest 10 min; fluff and serve with raita.

drink.description: Strong milk tea.
steps: Simmer milk with tea; strain and sweeten.

Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.description: Peshawari flat kebabs: minced meat (beef or mutton) with pomegranate seeds, coriander, and spices, pan-fried until crisp-edged. Technique: minimal binding so the kebab holds together but stays coarse; fry in enough oil or ghee to get a crisp crust.
ingredients: 1 1/2 lbs (680 g) ground beef or mutton
2 tbsp chickpea flour (besan) or cornmeal (optional, for binding)
steps: Mix the meat with onion, anardana, cilantro, green chilies, coriander, cumin, chili powder, besan if using, and salt. Knead 2–3 min. Rest 30 min.
Shape into flat round patties about 1/2 inch thick and 3–4 inches across.
Heat oil or ghee in a heavy skillet. Fry the kebabs over medium heat 4–5 min per side until browned and cooked through. Drain on paper towels. Serve with naan, chutney, and onion salad.

drink.description: Peshawari green tea with cardamom.
steps: Brew green tea with cardamom; sweeten to taste.
