steps: Make Bootleg mix: In a blender, blend 1 can (12 oz) frozen lemonade concentrate + 1 can (12 oz) frozen limeade concentrate + 1 packed cup fresh mint leaves until smooth; freeze until slushy.
Fill a tall glass with ice. Add gin and 2 tablespoons of the bootleg mix.
Top with club soda and stir gently to combine.
Garnish with mint and lime if desired.

ingredients: 1 packed cup fresh mint leaves (stems removed)
steps: Blend lemonade concentrate, limeade concentrate, and mint until the mint is fully pureed and the mix is vivid green.
Freeze in a covered container until slushy/scoopable (stir once during freezing if it sets too hard).
Use by the spoonful in the Bootleg; keep frozen up to 1 month for best flavor.

Mississippi.description: A viral sensation that became a modern classic. A chuck roast is slow-cooked with ranch dressing mix, au jus mix, butter, and pepperoncini peppers until it melts apart.
steps: Place roast in a slow cooker.
Sprinkle both packets of mix over the meat.
Place the stick of butter and peppers on top.
Cover and cook on Low for 8 hours. Do not add water.
Shred meat and serve with mashed potatoes.

drink.description: A classic Mississippi cocktail combining cognac/brandy, bourbon, dark rum, lemon, and honey.
steps: Add cognac/brandy, bourbon, rum, lemon juice, and honey to a shaker with ice.
Shake until well chilled and the honey dissolves.
Strain into an ice-filled Collins or rocks glass and serve.

Missouri.description: The 'gold nuggets' of BBQ. Cut from the fatty point of a brisket, these cubes are smoked, sauced, and caramelized until they are sweet, smoky, and melt-in-your-mouth tender.
steps: Smoke the brisket point until tender (internal 200°F).
Cut into 1-inch cubes.
Toss cubes with BBQ sauce and a little broth in a pan.
Return to smoker for 1-2 hours to caramelize and become sticky.
Serve as the ultimate BBQ appetizer.

drink.description: A St. Louis–style cocktail often called a ‘Missouri Mule,’ mixing bourbon and apple brandy with bitter-orange accents.
steps: Add bourbon, apple brandy, Campari, and Cointreau to a mixing glass with ice.
Stir until well chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe (or over a large cube in a rocks glass).
Express an orange peel over the drink if desired.

Montana.description: The treasure of the mountains. Wild huckleberries, which resist domestication and must be foraged by hand in bear country, are baked into a sweet-tart pie that defines Montana summers.
steps: Mix berries, sugar, flour, and lemon juice.
Pour into a pie crust lined pan. Dot with butter.
Cover with top crust, crimp edges, and cut steam vents.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 45-50 minutes until filling bubbles thickly.

drink.description: A beer-and-whiskey pairing associated with Montana in the list.
steps: Serve a shot of whiskey alongside a beer.
Sip separately or drop the shot into the beer (to preference).

Nebraska.description: A pocket of warmth from the Great Plains. Brought by Volga German immigrants, this yeast dough bread pocket is stuffed with a savory mixture of ground beef, cabbage, and onions.
ingredients: Salt and lots of Black Pepper
steps: Brown beef and onion. Add cabbage and a splash of water. Steam until soft.
Season heavily with pepper. Let cool.
Roll dough into rectangles. Place filling in center.
Fold dough over to seal (like a hot pocket).
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 20 mins until golden brown.

drink.description: A Nebraska staple: beer with tomato juice.
steps: Pour tomato juice into a pint glass.
Top gently with beer.
Season to taste and stir lightly.

Nevada.description: The high-roller's dinner. A staple of Las Vegas casino buffets and steakhouses, a massive standing rib roast is crusted in herbs and salt, roasted rare, and served with jus and horseradish cream.
steps: Make a paste of herbs, garlic, salt, pepper, and olive oil. Rub all over the roast.
Roast at 450°F (230°C) for 20 mins to sear.
Lower heat to 325°F (160°C). Cook until internal temp is 120°F (rare).
Rest for 30 minutes (crucial). Slice thick.

drink.description: A Nevada Basque-American cocktail built on Amer Picon-style bitters.
steps: Fill a glass halfway with sparkling water (and ice if desired).
Add Amer Picon and stir.
Float brandy on top and garnish with lemon.

New Hampshire.description: The scent of autumn. Fresh apple cider is reduced to concentrate its flavor, then mixed into a cake donut batter, fried, and tossed in cinnamon sugar while still hot.
ingredients: 1 cup Apple Cider (boiled down to 1/2 cup)
steps: Reduce cider. Cool.
Mix dry ingredients. Whisk butter, sugar, egg, and reduced cider.
Combine to make a sticky dough. Chill 1 hour.
Roll out and cut donut shapes.
Fry in oil at 350°F (175°C).
Toss immediately in cinnamon sugar.

drink.description: A simple vodka-cranberry highball.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add vodka and cranberry juice.
Stir and garnish with lime.

New Jersey.description: The unofficial state anthem on a roll. Taylor Ham (or Pork Roll) is a processed pork product that is sliced, griddled until the edges curl, and stacked with fried egg and American cheese on a hard roll.
steps: Score the edges of the pork roll slices (to prevent cupping).
Fry pork roll on a griddle until browned and crispy.
Fry egg (over hard or sunny side up).
Melt cheese on the egg.
Stack on the roll: Meat, Egg, Cheese. Salt and pepper.

drink.description: A classic cocktail with applejack and grenadine.
steps: Shake all ingredients with ice.
Strain into a chilled coupe.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool before using.
Warm pomegranate juice and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (avoid a hard boil).
Cool; stir in orange blossom water if using.
Bottle; add vodka if using for shelf-life.
Refrigerate and use within 3–4 weeks (longer if vodka added).

New Mexico.description: New Mexico's answer to the rolled enchilada. Corn tortillas are lightly fried flat and layered like a lasagna with cheese, chicken, and gallons of roasted Hatch green chile sauce, topped with a fried egg.
ingredients: 2 cups Roasted Hatch Green Chile Sauce
steps: Lightly fry tortillas in oil (to soften, not crisp).
Dip tortilla in warm green chile sauce.
Place on plate. Top with cheese, onion, and chicken.
Repeat for 3 layers.
Top the stack with a fried egg and more sauce.

drink.description: A New Mexico cocktail with tequila, cider, and crème de cassis.
steps: Fill a rocks glass with ice.
Add tequila and cider and stir.
Float crème de cassis and garnish if desired.

New York.description: The bar snack that changed the world. Invented at the Anchor Bar in Buffalo in 1964. Chicken wings are deep-fried naked (no batter) until crispy, then tossed in a sauce of Frank's RedHot and butter.
steps: Fry wings in oil at 375°F (190°C) for 10-12 mins until very crispy. Do not bread them.
Whisk hot sauce and melted butter.
Toss hot wings in the sauce.
Serve immediately with celery and blue cheese.

drink.description: A classic New York cocktail of whiskey and vermouth.
steps: Stir whiskey, vermouth, and bitters with ice.
Strain into a chilled coupe.
Garnish.

North Carolina.description: The definition of Piedmont BBQ. Pork shoulder is smoked over hickory and chopped (not pulled), then dressed with a 'dip' made of vinegar, ketchup, pepper, and salt. Served with red slaw.
ingredients: Dip: 1 cup Cider Vinegar, 1/4 cup Ketchup, 1 tbsp Sugar, Red Pepper Flakes
steps: Smoke pork at 225°F (107°C) for 8-10 hours until tender.
Chop the meat (don't shred).
Mix the dip ingredients. Toss the meat with some dip.
Serve on a bun with red slaw (coleslaw made with the same BBQ dip instead of mayo).

drink.description: A historic cherry-infused spirit, traditionally made by steeping cherries in brandy (often associated with the mid-Atlantic and early American period).
steps: Pack the cherries into a clean crock or large glass jar.
Pour in the brandy, then add the sugar.
Cover and let steep 3–4 months, stirring occasionally until the sugar dissolves.
Strain and bottle. Serve a small pour over ice or at room temperature.

North Dakota.description: A German-Russian comfort classic. A thick, creamy potato soup filled with chewy, handmade dumplings (knoephla) that are cut with shears directly into the pot.
ingredients: Soup: 4 Potatoes (cubed), 1 Onion, 1 stalk Celery, 6 cups Chicken Broth
steps: Make stiff dough. Roll into ropes. Cut 1-inch pieces (knoephla).
Sauté onion and celery. Add broth and potatoes. Boil until potatoes are half done.
Drop dumplings into boiling soup. Simmer 20 mins.
Stir in cream and dill. Soup should be thick.

drink.description: A creamy cola highball with coffee liqueur.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add coffee liqueur and cream; stir.
Top with cola.

Ohio.description: A Mediterranean-spiced meat sauce served over spaghetti. Flavored with cinnamon, cloves, chocolate, and allspice, it's famously ordered '5-Way': Spaghetti, Chili, Beans, Onions, and Cheese.
ingredients: 1 lb Ground Beef (boiled in water, not browned)
Spices: Cinnamon, Cloves, Allspice, Cumin, Chili Powder, Cocoa Powder
Toppings: Kidney Beans, Diced Onions, Shredded Cheddar (mountain of it)
steps: Crumble raw beef into water. Boil until cooked (fine texture).
Add tomato paste and spices. Simmer uncovered for 2-3 hours until thick.
Cook spaghetti.
Assemble 5-Way: Spaghetti, Chili, Beans, Onions, Cheese.

drink.description: An Ohio cocktail combining vodka, tart cherry, basil, balsamic, and honey—served over ice.
steps: Add vodka, tart cherry juice, basil, balsamic vinegar, and honey to a shaker with ice.
Shake hard until the honey is dissolved and the drink is very cold.
Strain over fresh ice in a rocks glass.
Garnish with a basil leaf if desired.

Oklahoma.description: Born from the Depression era to stretch beef. Thinly shaved onions are smashed directly into the beef patty on the griddle, caramelizing and fusing with the meat.
steps: Form beef into balls. Place on hot griddle.
Pile a handful of onions on top of the meat ball.
Smash flat with a spatula, driving onions into the meat.
Cook until crust forms. Flip (onions are now on bottom caramelizing).
Top with cheese. Serve on steamed bun.

drink.description: An Oklahoma party drink commonly made with beer, orange juice, and amaretto.
steps: Pour orange juice into a pint glass.
Add amaretto.
Top with beer and stir lightly.

Oregon.description: A tribute to the 'Cabernet of Blackberries'. The Marionberry, developed at Oregon State University, is baked into a bubbling, purple cobbler with a biscuit topping.
ingredients: Topping: 1 cup Flour, 1/2 cup Sugar, 1 tsp Baking Powder, Butter, Milk
steps: Toss berries with sugar and cornstarch. Place in baking dish.
Mix topping ingredients to make a wet biscuit dough.
Drop spoonfuls of dough over the berries.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 45 mins until topping is golden and fruit is bubbling.

drink.description: An Oregon café classic (often with rum, coffee, and whipped cream).
steps: Rim a warm mug with sugar.
Add rum and coffee liqueur.
Top with hot coffee and stir.
Finish with whipped cream.

Pennsylvania.description: The heavyweight champion of sandwiches. Thinly sliced ribeye steak is griddled and chopped, smothered in melted cheese (Provolone or Whiz), and stuffed into a long Amoroso roll, often 'wit' onions.
ingredients: 1 lb Ribeye Steak (partially frozen, sliced wafer thin)
steps: Sauté onions on a griddle. Push aside.
Cook steak slices quickly. Chop with spatula while cooking.
Mix onions into steak. Shape into a line the length of the roll.
Top with cheese. Let melt.
Place roll face down on meat, scoop underneath, and flip over.

drink.description: A classic cocktail with gin, raspberry, lemon, and egg white.
steps: Dry shake (no ice) if using egg white.
Shake again with ice.
Strain into a chilled coupe.
Simmer raspberries and water 5–8 minutes; mash.
Strain (optional), return liquid to pan, add sugar and lemon juice, and simmer 2–3 minutes.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

Rhode Island.description: A clam shack classic. Large Quahog clams are minced and mixed with linguica sausage, breadcrumbs, and spices, then baked back in their shells.
steps: Steam clams open. Remove meat and chop. Save shells and juice.
Sauté onion and sausage.
Mix breadcrumbs, clam meat, sausage mix, and enough juice to moisten.
Mound filling into the clam shells.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 20 mins until crispy on top.

drink.description: A tequila-and-pomegranate sour with a spicy Tajín rim.
steps: Rim a rocks glass with Tajín (rub the rim with a lime wedge, then dip into Tajín).
Add tequila, lime juice, pomegranate juice, and simple syrup to a shaker with ice.
Shake until well chilled.
Strain into the prepared glass over fresh ice and garnish with a lime wheel if desired.
Simple syrup: simmer 1 part sugar with 1 part water until dissolved; cool before using.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

South Carolina.description: Also known as Frogmore Stew. A one-pot communal feast of shrimp, sausage, corn, and potatoes boiled with Old Bay, dumped onto a newspaper-covered table for eating with hands.
steps: Boil water with Old Bay and lemons.
Add potatoes. Cook 10 mins.
Add sausage and corn. Cook 5 mins.
Add shrimp. Cook 3 mins (until pink).
Drain and dump onto table. Serve with cocktail sauce.

drink.description: A classic rum punch.
steps: Shake rum, juices, and syrup with ice.
Strain over ice in a tall glass.
Add bitters if desired.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: 2 tsp crushed bay leaves (or 1 tsp ground bay)
steps: Mix all spices thoroughly.
Store airtight up to 3 months.

South Dakota.description: The official state nosh. Cubes of red meat (traditionally mutton or lamb, sometimes beef) are deep-fried or grilled and served on toothpicks with garlic salt and saltines.
ingredients: 1 lb Lamb or Beef Sirloin, cut into 1/2 inch cubes
steps: Deep fry meat cubes at 375°F (190°C) for about 60-90 seconds (should be rare/medium rare inside).
Drain and immediately toss with garlic salt.
Serve with toothpicks and crackers.

drink.description: A South Dakota bar staple sometimes called ‘red beer’: domestic lager topped with tomato juice and garnished with olives and pickles.
steps: Chill a mug or pint glass.
Pour in the beer, then add tomato juice to fill the glass.
Drop in olives and pickle slices.
Serve immediately.

Tennessee.description: Fried chicken with a vengeance. Marinated in buttermilk, fried crisp, and then doused in a fiery oil paste made of cayenne pepper and lard. Served on white bread with pickles to soak up the heat.
ingredients: Marinade: Buttermilk, Hot Sauce, Pickle Juice
Hot Paste: 1/2 cup Lard (melted), 3 tbsp Cayenne Pepper, 1 tbsp Brown Sugar, Paprika, Garlic Powder
steps: Marinate chicken overnight.
Dredge in flour. Fry until golden and cooked through.
Whisk hot paste ingredients (use some hot frying oil to melt spices).
Brush the fried chicken heavily with the hot paste.
Serve on a slice of white bread with pickles.

drink.description: A Tennessee highball featuring Tennessee whiskey and lemonade.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add whiskey, triple sec, and lemon juice; stir.
Top with lemon-lime soda.
Whisk spices into melted lard/oil until a thick paste forms.
Cool; refrigerate up to 1 week (or freeze in portions).

Texas.description: The holy grail of BBQ. Beef brisket is rubbed simply with salt and pepper (Dalmatian rub) and smoked over post oak for 12+ hours until it has a dark bark and jiggles like gelatin.
ingredients: Rub: 1/2 cup Coarse Black Pepper, 1/2 cup Kosher Salt
steps: Trim fat cap to 1/4 inch.
Apply rub generously.
Smoke at 225°F (107°C) until internal temp hits 165°F (the stall).
Wrap in butcher paper. Continue smoking until 203°F and probe tender.
Rest in a cooler for 2-4 hours before slicing.

drink.description: A Texas highball of tequila, lime, and sparkling water.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add tequila and lime juice.
Top with sparkling water and stir.

Utah.description: A Mormon comfort food staple served at gatherings (not just funerals). Hash browns are baked in a creamy cheese sauce and topped with crunchy cornflakes.
steps: Mix hash browns, soup, sour cream, cheese, and onion (optional).
Spread into a greased casserole dish.
Mix cornflakes with melted butter. Sprinkle over top.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 45-50 mins until bubbly and golden.

drink.description: A Utah cocktail from Squatters Pub Brewery combining gin, honey, lemon, and beer.
ingredients: 4 oz beer (a crisp lager works well)
steps: Add lemon juice, honey, and gin to a shaker with ice.
Shake until very cold and the honey is dissolved.
Strain into an ice-filled pint glass.
Top with beer and give a gentle stir.

Vermont.description: A Northern twist on a Southern classic. Pure Vermont Grade B maple syrup replaces corn syrup, creating a darker, richer, and more complex pie.
steps: Whisk eggs, sugar, butter, and maple syrup.
Arrange pecans in the pie shell.
Pour filling over pecans.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 40-50 mins until set but slightly jiggly in center.

drink.description: A gin cocktail sweetened with Vermont maple syrup and brightened with citrus.
steps: Add gin, lemon juice, orange juice, maple syrup, and bitters to a shaker with ice.
Shake until well chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe (or over ice in a rocks glass).
Garnish with an orange twist if desired.

Virginia.description: A thick, tomato-based stew that claims origin in Brunswick County. Historically made with squirrel, today it features smoked chicken and pork, lima beans, and corn, cooked until the spoon stands up straight.
steps: Combine meats, tomatoes, and juices in a large pot.
Simmer for 1 hour.
Add beans, corn, and seasonings.
Simmer on low for another hour until very thick.
Serve with cornbread.

drink.description: A Virginia take on the Manhattan, using local whiskey and classic bitters and vermouth.
steps: Add whiskey, sweet vermouth, and bitters to a mixing glass with ice.
Stir until well chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe or Nick & Nora glass.
Garnish with an expressed orange peel (and a cherry if desired).

Washington.description: Seattle's ubiquitous comfort food. Chicken thighs are marinated in a sweet, ginger-heavy soy glaze, grilled over open flame for char, and served with rice and mac salad.
ingredients: Marinade/Glaze: 1 cup Soy Sauce, 1 cup Sugar, 1 tbsp Fresh Ginger (grated), Garlic
steps: Boil marinade ingredients. Thicken half with cornstarch for glaze. Cool the rest for marinade.
Marinate chicken for 4 hours.
Grill chicken over high heat to get char marks.
Slice into strips.
Drizzle heavily with the thickened glaze. Serve with rice.

drink.description: A modern cocktail often made with aquavit, sherry, and bitter liqueur.
steps: Stir all ingredients with ice.
Strain into a chilled coupe.
Garnish if desired.

West Virginia.description: The coal miner's lunch. Invented at the Country Club Bakery by Giuseppe Argiro, this soft white bread roll is baked with sticks of pepperoni inside. The spicy oil leaches into the bread, creating a soft, flavorful snack that needs no refrigeration.
ingredients: Stick Pepperoni (cut into 3-inch batons or thick slices)
steps: Divide dough into balls.
Flatten and place pepperoni inside. Roll up and seal ends tight.
Let rise for 30 mins.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 15-20 mins until golden.
Brush with butter while hot.

drink.description: A West Virginia-inspired martini using pawpaw purée and elderflower liqueur.
steps: Add vodka, St-Germain, and pawpaw purée to a cocktail shaker with ice.
Shake until very cold.
Strain into a chilled martini glass.
Serve immediately.

ingredients: Peels (zest strips) from 2 lemons (avoid the white pith)
Optional: peels from 1 orange (avoid the white pith)
steps: Use a vegetable peeler to remove wide strips of citrus peel, taking as little white pith as possible.
Put peels in a clean jar and pour in the vodka. Seal.
Infuse in a cool, dark place, shaking once daily.
Start tasting after 24 hours; strain when the citrus flavor is where you want it (often 3–7 days).
Strain through a fine mesh sieve (and coffee filter if you want it crystal clear). Bottle and store.

ingredients: 2–4 ripe pawpaws (enough for at least 1/2 cup pulp)
Optional: 1 tsp lemon juice (helps slow browning)
steps: Halve pawpaws lengthwise and scoop the pulp into a bowl.
Remove seeds (discard) and pick out any bits of skin/fibers.
Mash well, or blitz briefly with an immersion blender until smooth.
Optional: press through a fine sieve for a silkier purée.
Stir in lemon juice if using. Refrigerate up to 2 days, or freeze in small portions.

Wisconsin.description: The tailgate essential. Bratwurst sausages are simmered in a hot bath of beer and onions before being finished on the grill. Served on a hard roll with spicy mustard and sauerkraut.
steps: In a pot, simmer brats, onions, beer, and butter for 15-20 mins (do not boil hard).
Remove brats and grill over medium heat until browned and crisp.
Serve on a bun topped with the beer-soaked onions and mustard.

drink.description: Wisconsin’s brandy-forward Old Fashioned with muddled fruit.
steps: Muddle sugar, bitters, orange, and cherry in a rocks glass.
Add brandy and ice; stir.
Top with a splash of soda or sour mix.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.
Whisk lemon juice, lime juice, and simple syrup together.
Bottle and refrigerate; use within 3–4 days for best flavor.

Wyoming.description: A hearty bowl for the range. Lean, flavorful bison meat is slow-cooked with beans, tomatoes, and mild chilies. It's richer and sweeter than beef chili.
steps: Brown bison and onion. Drain any fat (bison is lean, so there won't be much).
Add tomatoes, beans, and spices.
Simmer for 1 hour to meld flavors.
Serve with cheddar cheese and cornbread.

drink.description: A classic ‘Rattlesnake’ whiskey sour variation with absinthe and egg white for a silky foam.
steps: Add rye, lemon juice, simple syrup, absinthe, and egg white to a shaker.
Dry-shake (no ice) for 10–15 seconds to build foam, then add ice and shake again until well chilled.
Double-strain into a chilled coupe (or a rocks glass).
Garnish with a lemon twist if desired.
Simple syrup: simmer 1 part sugar with 1 part water until dissolved; cool before using.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

drink.description: A classic American whiskey cocktail: spirit-forward, lightly sweetened, and perfumed with citrus and bitters.
ingredients: 1 tsp water (if using a sugar cube)
steps: In a rocks glass, add the sugar cube and bitters; add 1 tsp water and muddle into a syrup (skip water if using simple syrup).
Add a large ice cube and pour in the bourbon.
Stir 15–20 seconds until chilled and lightly diluted.
Express the orange peel over the drink (pinch to spray oils), then garnish with the peel.
Serve immediately.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

UZB.description: Uzbekistan’s national dish: rice steamed over a deeply flavored base of browned onions, lamb, and carrots with cumin (zira). Traditionally cooked in a kazan and served in generous communal platters.
ingredients: 2 lb (900 g) lamb (or beef), cut into chunks
4 large carrots, cut into matchsticks (about 6 cups / 600 g)
2 tbsp whole cumin seeds (zira), lightly crushed
1 tbsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
1 whole head of garlic, outer papery skins removed
Hot water, as needed (about 5–6 cups / 1.2–1.4 L)
steps: Heat oil in a heavy pot. Fry onions until deep golden.
Add meat and brown well. Add carrots and cook 5 minutes.
Add cumin, salt, and optional barberries/coriander. Add hot water to just cover and simmer 30–45 minutes.
Spread rice over the top without stirring. Add enough hot water to sit about 1 inch (2.5 cm) above rice.
When water is mostly absorbed, push garlic head into rice, cover tightly, and steam on very low 20–25 minutes.
Rest 10 minutes, fluff gently, and serve.

drink.dish: Kok Choy (Кўк чай) — Uzbek Green Tea
drink.description: Simple, strong green tea served throughout the day in Uzbekistan; hospitality in a bowl (piala).
steps: Heat water to about 175°F (80°C).
Steep tea 2–3 minutes. Strain and serve.

VAT.description: A Roman pasta associated with Pope Pius XII: a refined, richer cousin of carbonara—egg yolks, cheese, and prosciutto (often with onion and butter).
ingredients: 4 oz prosciutto (crudo or cotto), cut into thin strips (115 g)
Optional: 1/4 cup heavy cream (60 ml) (some modern versions)
steps: Cook pasta in well-salted water until al dente. Reserve 1 cup pasta water.
Meanwhile, melt butter in a skillet over medium-low. Add onion and cook until soft, not browned.
Add prosciutto and warm 1–2 minutes (do not crisp hard).
In a bowl, whisk egg yolks with Pecorino, Parmigiano, and lots of black pepper (and cream if using).
Drain pasta and add to skillet off heat. Toss to coat.
Quickly pour in egg-cheese mixture, tossing constantly, adding a splash of pasta water as needed to make a glossy sauce.
Serve immediately with extra pepper and cheese.

drink.description: A Roman (and Vatican-adjacent) classic: espresso ‘corrected’ with a splash of grappa—short, hot, and bracing.
steps: Brew a fresh shot of espresso.
Stir in sugar if using.
Add grappa and stir once.
Serve immediately.

VCT.description: A symbol of resilience. Breadfruit, brought by Captain Bligh to feed populations, is roasted whole over an open fire until the skin chars and the inside becomes soft and smoky. Paired with crispy fried Jackfish, it is the quintessential Vincentian lunch.
steps: Score the breadfruit stem. Roast over an open flame (charcoal or gas) turning until skin is charred and inside is soft (insert skewer to test).
Peel the charred skin and slice the breadfruit.
Clean fish with lime. Rub with seasoning.
Dust fish in flour. Fry in hot oil until crispy.
Serve slices of warm roasted breadfruit with the fried fish.

drink.description: St Vincent & the Grenadines rum punch: rum, lime, tropical juice, and spice, served ice-cold.
ingredients: 1 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz / 15 ml simple syrup)
steps: Shake with ice until cold.
Strain over fresh ice and serve.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

VEN.description: A plate that tells the story of Venezuela's mixed heritage. Shredded beef (indigenous), white rice (European), and black beans (African) are arranged to resemble the tricolor flag. Sweet fried plantains (tajadas) are the 'railings' that hold this delicious history together.
ingredients: Sofrito: Onion, Red Pepper, Garlic, Cumin
steps: Cook steak in water until tender. Shred it.
Make Sofrito: Sauté onion, pepper, and garlic. Split in half.
Fry the shredded beef with half the sofrito and tomato sauce.
Fry the cooked black beans with the other half of the sofrito.
Fry plantain slices until golden.
Serve the four components side-by-side on a large plate.

drink.description: A classic Venezuelan refresher made with panela (unrefined cane sugar) and lime—sweet, citrusy, and cooling.
ingredients: 2 oz panela (piloncillo) (or 1/4 cup packed brown sugar as a substitute)
2 tbsp fresh lime juice (or to taste)
steps: Warm 1 cup water and dissolve the panela; cool completely.
Add remaining water and lime juice; stir and adjust sweetness and acidity.
Serve over ice.

VIR.description: A dish dating back to the Danish colonial era. 'Fungi' is a smooth, polenta-like cornmeal mash that was a staple for field workers. Served with fresh fish poached in a savory butter-onion sauce, it remains the beloved comfort food of the Virgin Islands.
steps: Fungi: Boil okra in water. Whisk in cornmeal and butter. Cook until stiff and smooth (like polenta).
Fish: Clean fish with lime. Season.
Sauté onion and tomato in butter. Add a little water and vinegar to make a sauce.
Poach fish in the sauce for 10-15 mins.
Serve the fish with a scoop of fungi.

drink.description: A frozen, boozy “adult milkshake” strongly associated with the US Virgin Islands: rum, coffee liqueur, and a coconut-cream base.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) cream of coconut (store-bought or homemade)
steps: Blend everything with a generous cup of ice until smooth.
Serve immediately.
Note (quick cream of coconut): heat 1/2 cup coconut cream + 1/2 cup sugar until dissolved; cool.
Combine coconut milk, sugar, and salt in a saucepan.
Warm gently, stirring until sugar dissolves and mixture thickens slightly.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks. Shake before use.

VNM.description: Vietnam's soul in a bowl. A clear, aromatic bone broth simmered for hours.
ingredients: Spices: 5 Star Anise, 1 Cinnamon stick, 3 Cardamom pods, Cloves, Fennel
steps: Boil bones for 10 mins vigorously to release impurities. Dump water, scrub bones clean.
Char onion and ginger over open flame.
Simmer bones, brisket, charred aromatics, and toasted spices in clean water for 6-8 hours.
Remove brisket when tender. Strain broth. Season with fish sauce and sugar.
Assemble: Blanch noodles. Place in bowl. Add cooked brisket and raw sirloin.
Pour boiling broth over meat (cooking the raw slices instantly).
Serve with herbs (Thai basil, cilantro), bean sprouts, lime, and chili.

drink.description: Strong Vietnamese coffee sweetened with condensed milk and poured over ice.
ingredients: 2 tbsp Vietnamese ground coffee (or strong dark-roast coffee)
steps: Add condensed milk to a glass.
Brew coffee strongly (phin filter is traditional) into the glass.
Stir to combine, then pour over a glass full of ice.
Serve immediately.

YEM.dish: Saltah (سلتة) — Yemeni Stew with Fenugreek Froth
YEM.description: Yemen’s national comfort dish: a hot bowl of meat broth and vegetables crowned with hulbah (whipped fenugreek foam) and spooned up with bread. The topping is the signature.
ingredients: For stew: 2 tbsp (30 ml) oil or ghee
4 cups (950 ml) beef or lamb broth
1 cup (150 g) cooked shredded lamb or beef (optional but common)
1 1/2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
steps: Sauté onion in oil until soft. Add garlic and ginger 30 seconds.
Add tomato, cumin, and coriander; cook until thick and fragrant.
Add potato, carrot, broth, and meat if using. Simmer 15–20 minutes until vegetables are tender. Season with salt.
Ladle into bowls. Spoon sahawiq into the center and top generously with hulbah (fenugreek froth). Serve immediately with bread.
Soak fenugreek seeds in water 8–12 hours. Drain and rinse well.
Blend with 1/2 cup (120 ml) fresh water until pale and foamy.
Season with salt and lemon juice. Let sit 10 minutes; it will thicken slightly.
Blend tomatoes, chilies, garlic, cilantro, lemon juice, salt, and cumin to a coarse sauce.
Taste and adjust salt/lemon. Use immediately or refrigerate 2–3 days.

drink.description: A traditional Yemeni hot drink brewed from coffee husks (cascara/qishr) with ginger and warming spices—served sweet and fragrant.
ingredients: 1 tsp ground ginger (or 1-inch fresh ginger, sliced)
steps: Bring water to a boil. Add coffee husks, ginger, and cinnamon.
Simmer 8–10 minutes, then strain into cups.
Sweeten to taste and serve hot.

ZAF.description: A Cape Malay classic. Spiced minced meat baked with a savory egg custard topping.
ingredients: Topping: 2 Eggs beaten with 1 cup Milk, Bay leaves
steps: Sauté onion. Add meat and brown.
Add curry powder, chutney, raisins, and the soaked bread (squeezed dry). Mix well.
Press the meat mixture into a baking dish.
Pour the egg and milk mixture over the meat. Top with bay leaves.
Bake at 350°F (180°C) for 30-40 minutes until the custard is set and golden.
Serve with yellow rice.

drink.description: South Africa’s famous caffeine-free herbal tea from red bush (rooibos).
ingredients: 1 tsp rooibos tea (loose leaf) per 8 oz water
steps: Add rooibos to a teapot or infuser and pour over boiling water.
Steep 5–7 minutes (rooibos tolerates longer steeping well).
Serve plain or with milk/honey/lemon.
